urn:contentItem:7V14-83F0-YBDY-R0HS-00000-00United in grief2009-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisWRAPPg. 3United in griefLIAM HOULIHAN, in Buxton

HEARTBROKEN survivors of the Marysville inferno made their tragic homecoming yesterday.

The bushfire refugees wept as they returned to the ashes of their homes as police bussed them into the locked-down wasteland where only 12 houses remain standing.

And there were emotional scenes at the Alexandra relief centre as the survivors ran to hug people from their town they had feared dead.

Others, clearly traumatised, rocked back and forth, still mourning dead loved ones as the return to the scene of the tragedy approached.

Harley Ronalds, 17, screamed, then cried as the bus stopped and she saw the cinders of the house where her grandfather perished.

``Nothing was the same. It was very not like Marysville,'' she said.

Her grandfather Leonard ``Pos'' Postlethwaite perished after refusing his wife's pleas for him to flee with her.

``He was 72 and a very stubborn old man. One of my mates found grandpa by the side of the car,'' Ms Ronalds said.

In other developments:

NEW grants for bushfire victims will be officially announced today.

A CONTINGENT of 60 US fire specialists is due to arrive in Melbourne this morning.

A GROUP of Canadian firefighters is due in Victoria this week.

EXTRA white marquees were set up in the car park of the Coroner's Court yesterday where the morgue has capacity for only 40 bodies.

MORE than 1830 homes were confirmed destroyed by the fires, with at least 7000 people homeless and 413,000ha burned.

MORE than 1000 defence force personnel joined in rebuilding devastated communities.

CREWS were monitoring a new forest fire in Wilsons Promontory National Park last night -- one of 12 blazes still going across the state.

One resident, the Rev Ivor Jones, who experienced the German WWII bombing blitz as a boy, said what happened to Marysville was worse.

His wife, Yvonne Jones, was devastated by the thought that fellow resident Elizabeth Liesfield and her boys Matthew and James died there.

``As I went past I couldn't believe this beautiful woman and her two children were under the rubble still,'' she said.

The survivors drove in a convoy to Buxton and were shuttled on three buses into the grim death zone in the foothills of the Snowy Mountains.

Marysville was one of the quickest and hardest hit areas of the Black Saturday bushfires with many residents caught by its lethal speed.

The survivors described a wasteland of ash, crumpled tin, at most 12 houses and only three big chimneys standing in a barren skyline.

They had to remain on the bus and view their shattered hometown through the windows as the area was a crime scene and an asbestos risk.

Counsellors and WorkSafe officials joined the 300 residents on the three buses making five round trips.

Older residents whispered on the bus in anticipation of seeing whether there was anything salvageable from their former town and former lives.

There were tears of joy as well as sadness for the few who had standing homes in the decimated zone.

Andrew Schreuder, 81, who relies on a mobility seat, was driven out of Marysville by a local family when the fires hit.

Yesterday, returning to his home for the first time, he wept as he saw his home still standing.

``My house is still there. I'm so thankful it's incredible,'' the former Anglican priest, who ran the Marysville op-shop, said.

He said he had expected heartbreaking devastation.

``One part of me said I don't want to go. The other part said I have to go.''

Others told how children wept on the bus as they saw their burnt school and remembered lost friends.

Sue Pearce was relieved to see the location of different, more significant, ashes.

Her adult son Chris, a blind jazz musician, died last year and they buried his ashes on their property in the spot where he liked to practise.

She and her husband were also elated Chris's guide dog survived the bushfire disaster.

Others refused the bus ride saying it was too soon to return.

``I've seen enough. I've seen it start. I've seen it happen,'' Marysville chef Steve, who did not want his surname used, said.

``For some of us it's too soon. We're just too sensitive about it.

``I'm more concerned about the people who have gone -- the faces I'm not going to see again.''

The Marysville blaze is believed to have been deliberately lit.

Victoria Police Deputy Commissioner Kieran Walshe yesterday said its point of origin made it suspicious.

urn:contentItem:49KJ-J5G0-01S8-843D-00000-00<published>1988-09-18T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Tender tale of raw Southern passion</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>RANDALL ASHBOURNE</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">TWO MOON JUNCTION (M). Academy Cinema City.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Stand by for the best excursion into Southern sensuality since</p><p nitf:lede="true">the '50s and '60s.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It has been quite a while since we've seen passion tainted</p><p>with the scent of sweat and magnolia.</p><p> Two Moon Junction is a surprise - like suddenly finding Tennessee</p><p>Williams rejuvenated and writing his heart out. Here, once again,</p><p>is illicit sex - lonely, raw, isolated, almost violent. But</p><p>just as with Williams's works, the underlying current is one</p><p>of tenderness and compassion.</p><p> The story, the screenplay, the direction all flow from Zalman</p><p>King, whose 1986</p><p>movie 9 Weeks broke new ground in on-screen sensuality. He</p><p>has done it again with this tale of a Southern cotton princess</p><p>who can't keep her hands off a handsome carnival drifter.</p><p> Sherilyn Fenn, a once-brunette door bunny at the LA Playboy</p><p>Club, has been transformed into a striking blonde for her role</p><p>as the privileged sorority queen, April Delongpre.</p><p> She is about to marry Chad Douglas Fairchild (Martin Hewitt,</p><p>the impossibly precocious and handsome brat who made his screen</p><p>debut opposite Brooke Shields in Endless Love). April feels</p><p>a little confusion at the approaching lifetime commitment, though</p><p>Southern society declares the two are a perfect match.</p><p> While going through the motions of preparing for the wedding,</p><p>April takes her younger sisters to a travelling carnival. Looks</p><p>that would ignite a forest fire are exchanged with a rugged</p><p>ride attendant called Perry (Richard Tyson).</p><p> The two launch into a torrid affair - one which seems destined</p><p>to last but one weekend.</p><p> Things are made difficult by April's interfering grandmother,</p><p>Belle, and her old friend Sheriff Hawkins, who tries to run</p><p>the interloper out of town.</p><p> (Belle and Hawkins are superbly played by those old troupersLousie Fletcher and Burl Ives.)</p><p> April goes through with the wedding, but finds she still can't</p><p>give up Perry.</p><p> It's a movie where subtlety and emotional confusion are blended</p><p>with steamy sensuality to create a love story as far from plasticised</p><p>perfection as it's possible to get. It's a tale where love hurts,</p><p>love cheats - a movie that doesn't like the idea the sexual revolution is</p><p>dead.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>photo: richard tyson in two moon junction; Richard Tyson as Perry in "Two Moon Junction"</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1DN0-TXN5-R3DX-00000-00COLUMN 82002-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESColumn 8Pg. 22COLUMN 8

Matt Cheney, owner of a Clovelly cafe, CBD Coffee, is a happy man. "On Saturday afternoon, having just finished the till, I put a large amount of money in my wallet and was closing. A man walked in and asked for a couple of rolls and drinks. I put my wallet on the counter and served him. Nice guy gave me a tip. When I turned around, he had already left and a few seconds later I realised my wallet had left, too. The next hour was spent cancelling credit cards and being angry at myself for being so stupid. But joy. One and a half hours later he knocked on the door waving the wallet. Turned out we have identical wallets and he took mine by mistake. Beautiful to know there are still honest people."

A colleague who visited Young last week to feast on cherries found that cherry trees are grown to perhaps two metres, so the human pickers can reach the berries. Then why, he asks, is that platform on a mobile hoist called a cherrypicker. Are there cherry trees in this world that grow to six and seven metres?

Epping Boys' High School's third-grade cricket team were a little astonished when told their match against Homebush last week had been washed out. In the middle of the drought, the game was abandoned before the first ball could be bowled because the outfield at Marsfield Park was a swamp not a remarkably localised downpour, but a burst water main.

More thanks to Kate Sieper, of the ABC at Tamworth (Column 8, yesterday) for more so-dry jokes from listeners. The winner was:

It's sooo dry that when I went out this morning to check on the livestock I found my blooming clothes horse had died (Des, of Tamworth).

And some more:

It's sooo dry we have to put rocks on the corners of our property to stop it from rolling up (Liz , of Guyra).

It's sooo dry up our way, the economic rationalists are coming for their holidays (Jack, of Armidale).

It's sooo dry the bartender's putting real rocks in our scotch (Vince, of Laverton).

It's sooo dry the town council had to close two lanes of the swimming pool (Margaret, of Bellata).

"In fact," Kate says, "the jokes have become so dry we haven't got the joke in one in six months!"

David Meggitt, of West Pymble, has sent us a fragment of a plastic balloon, found on his back lawn, next to Lane Cove National Park. This bit of litter still has on it one logo for World Environment Day and another, Life on Earth -Department of the Environment-SAVE OUR SEAS. The balloon, apparently released on June 5, made two bloomers. First, it caused litter, second, had it floated to sea then burst, the Save our Seas hope would have been dashed.

Ding, dong, are you there? A year later, and Avon cosmetics hasn't woken up. Andreas Tillmann, of Armidale, found among male deodorants in the Avon catalogue: Forces of Nature Deodorant Body Sprays, scents inspired by nature ... Ground Zero. He wasn't impressed by another deodorant title, either Forest Fire.

urn:contentItem:46SM-6JG0-015G-T2RY-00000-00<published>2002-09-17T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 15</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Woman tells of roof fall</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>PHILIP CULLEN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Ceiling came up like a tidal wave</p><p nitf:lede="true">A CHRISTMAS Hills woman thrown from the roof of her home as it lifted in ferocious wind was yesterday sore but thankful to be alive.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Katrina Brain, 28, was knocked out after being catapulted 10m to the ground on Sunday after getting on to the roof of her home to repair a chimney flue.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I pushed the flue back in and when I turned back the whole roof was coming up like a tidal wave coming to get me," she said from her Austin hospital bed yesterday.</p><p>Ms Brain regained consciousness in the arms of a friend, Carl, as he was calling an ambulance. She suffered a broken pelvis, cuts and bruises.</p><p> "I realise now I could have died. I was wrapped up in it; it rolled me up as the roof peeled," Ms Brain said.</p><p> The State Emergency Service took 850 calls from Sunday, mostly for damaged roofs and fallen trees and powerlines in the 100km/h storm.</p><p> Volunteers were called to more than 100 jobs in the Ballarat area, including a fallen 100-year-old willow tree and the collapse of a brick wall.</p><p> Wind, which peaked at 140km/h at Mt Hotham, also fanned fires across the state.</p><p> Firefighters battled almost 100 blazes yesterday before the temperature dropped and rain fell across the state. They warned of a disastrous fire season if forecasts of below-average rainfall in coming months proved correct.</p><p> Country Fire Authority volunteers saved 10 homes in Apollo Bay from a blaze that burned 550ha of dense scrub along the Gellibrand River. Two sheds and farm equipment were destroyed.</p><p> Fire destroyed about 300ha of a pine plantation at Mt Lonarch, in central Victoria, and an early morning blaze in the Yarra State Forest near Wesburn, northeast of Melbourne, destroyed 50ha of bushland.</p><p> CFA firefighters contained the fire in seven hours.</p><p> Fifty firefighters struggled to contain a blaze at Pheasant Creek, while wind reignited a fire that had been smouldering for weeks at a mulch factory in Dandenong South.</p><p> Firefighters were aided by a cool change that drifted across the state yesterday morning.</p><p> CFA spokesman John Tindall said people in fire-prone areas must immediately clean up potential fire hazards near their homes and plan what to do in a fire.</p><p> "The conditions . . . pushed us into summer six weeks early," Mr Tindall said.</p><p> "Unless we get rain in spring and early summer we can expect more of these days."</p><p> Mr Tindall said forest and bushland across the state, especially near and north of the Great Dividing Range, were already high risk.</p><p> "If we don't get the rain, we are facing a very, very serious situation -- and I really mean it," he said.</p><p> At Melbourne airport yesterday, 14 Victorian firefighters were welcomed home after six weeks fighting forest fires in the US.</p><p> Department of Natural Resources and Environment, Parks Victoria and CFA firefighters helped contain a 202,000ha forest fire in a national forest in Oregon. It caused about $280 million damage.</p><p> Eain McRae, a DNRE air attack supervisor, said Victorians were able to manage fires with fewer resources than their US colleagues.</p><p> "They enjoyed having us there because of the humour and enthusiasm we were able to contribute," he said.</p><p> Environment Minister Sherryl Garbutt said US authorities commended the Victorian firefighters for their "outstanding professionalism".</p><p> "I am delighted that our firefighters have returned home safe and sound and that they have represented Victoria and Australia with such distinction overseas."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:525H-T651-JD3N-53W5-00000-00OUT & ABOUT -- SA, WA2011-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 16OUT & ABOUT -- SA, WADAVID STRATTON, EVAN WILLIAMS, ROSEMARY NEILL, SEAN SENNETT, JOHN KINSELLA, RITA CLARKE, EAMONN KELLY

----- FILM -----

NEW RELEASES

Hereafter (M)

Clint Eastwood's new film, scripted by British writer Peter Morgan (The Queen) explores the afterlife, a tricky subject the accomplished director succeeds in making more fascinating than you might imagine. Three interlocking stories, set in three different parts of the world, finally converge and although there are rocky moments along the way, the result is amazingly satisfying.

DAVID STRATTON * * * 1/2

127 Hours (MA15+)

Trapped in a Utah canyon in 2003 with a boulder pinning his arm and unable to call for help, Aron Ralston spent an agonising six days in his rocky prison before managing to free himself. Danny Boyle's film is more than an unsparing record of Ralston's ordeal; it is a life-affirming experience, with some dazzling filmcraft and a brave central performance from James Franco. Much of it is hard to watch, all of it hard to forget.

EVAN WILLIAMS * * * *

----- SOUTH AUSTRALIA -----

STAGE

The Wau Wau Sisters

The New York-based Wau Wau Sisters (Tanya Gagne and Adrienne Truscott) are part of a new wave of burlesque performers -- most of them women -- who trade on sex and nudity while dismantling traditional notions of the demeaned stripper or prettily passive showgirl. The duo open their new show, The Wau Wau Sisters are as Naked as the Day They Were Born Again, at the Adelaide Fringe. The sisters' routines are a spicy stir-fry of kinky acrobatics and trapeze, satirical songs, comedy sketches and stripping.

ROSEMARY NEILL

The Spiegeltent. Garden of Unearthly Delights, East Terrace, Adelaide. Tomorrow, 11.30pm. Tickets: $30. Bookings: 1300 374 643. Until Feb 27.

LIVE MUSIC

A Day in the Life: The Beatles

After sold-out performances of its Norah Jones tribute show at the 2010 Adelaide Fringe, the Georgie Aue Quartet returns this year with its tribute to the music of the Fab Four. Certainly you'll be able to count on A Day in the Life with its stunning orchestral crescendos from the 1967 masterpiece Sgt Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band, but the pre-publicity promises old Beatle classics and some not so familiar songs, all given the quartet's soulful and melodic treatment.

The Promethean. 116 Grote Street, Adelaide. Saturday, 5.30pm. Tickets: $22.25. Bookings: 1300 374 643.

The Lloyd Cole Small Ensemble

Singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole is touring Australia to promote his new studio album, Broken Record. The Small Ensemble has Cole out front, with Mark Schwaber and Matt Cullen trading acoustic guitars, banjo and mandolin in support. Opening with No Blue Skies, Cole performs two sets and delves deep into his songbook. Highlights from his days with the Commotions include Perfect Skin, Are You Ready to be Heartbroken?, Forest Fire and Rattlesnakes. The older material sits well alongside recent compositions such as Writers Retreat! and favourites from the solo years such as Margo's Waltz, Like Lovers Do and the encore, Undressed. Cole's singing, buoyed by clever wordplay, is enriched throughout by a swell of acoustic instruments. Splendid.

SEAN SENNETT

The Gov. 59 Port Road, Hindmarsh. Wednesday, 5pm. Tickets: $53.60. Bookings: 1300 438 849.

WESTERN AUSTRALIA

STAGE

Waltzing the Wilarra

Yirra Yaakin theatre company is innovative, energetic, and politically charged, and David Milroy's new production is no exception. From the moment the spotlight finds vaudeville wise-cracker Old Toss (Ernie Dingo) with his sidekick Young Harry (Jessica Clarke), we are on a roller-coaster of irony, bitter social critique, affectionate humour and drama. Drawing on a club like the Coolbaroo -- which arose in Australia after World War II, and where whites and Aborigines sang and danced together -- as a potential model for a possibly more genuine mode of reconciliation, the play weaves music theatre in a Brechtian strain with contemporary drama.

JOHN KINSELLA

Subiaco Arts Centre. 180 Hamersley Rd, Subiaco. Tomorrow, noon and 7.30pm. Tickets: $54.50. Bookings: (08) 9484 1133. Until March 6.

DANCE

Ballet at the Quarry

Even the pale moon seemed to brighten, stunned by the magnificent vitality of the WA Ballet dancers at The Quarry. Attendant on Maria Callas's meticulous voice, their molten bodyline and precision made the complex seven-couple pas de deux in Jiri Kylian's Un Ballo almost transcendental. Their strong classical technique and rhythmic fidelity in Uwe Scholz's Seventh Symphony, in which Jennifer Provins shone, added a wonderful layer of interpretation to Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No 7. Although lone Australian choreographer David Jonathan's Saudade suffered from indistinct lighting, Ivan Cavallari's Chaplinesque duet Ombra Leggiera was amusingly captivating and crowned a compelling performance.

RITA CLARKE

Quarry Amphitheatre. Tonight 8pm. Tickets: $49-$63. Bookings: 136 100. Until March 5.

Human Interest Story

Mass-media news punctuates, amplifies and alters the rhythms of daily life, providing grand, exotic narratives of collective perception and authorised meaning that contrast with the modest and often mundane features of individual human existence. That is the central conceit behind this substantial dancework by Lucy Guerin, which premiered at Melbourne's Malthouse Theatre last year. Structurally, the work creates a triptych of progressive abstraction: the first section parodying news conventions, the second offering metaphorical representation of news consumption, and the third a visceral and sometimes unsettling choreographic expression of sensory overload.

EAMONN KELLY

State Theatre Centre. Roe Street, Perth. Ends tonight, 7.30pm. Tickets: $37.50-$42.50. Bookings: (08) 9484 1133.

urn:contentItem:525R-X161-JD3N-50G7-00000-00OUT & ABOUT - SA, WA2011-02-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 16OUT & ABOUT - SA, WADAVID STRATTON, EVAN WILLIAMS, ROSEMARY NEILL, SEAN SENNETT, JOHN KINSELLA, RITA CLARKE, IAN CUTHBERTSON

NEW RELEASES

Hereafter (M)

Clint Eastwood's new film, scripted by British writer Peter Morgan (The Queen) explores the afterlife, a tricky subject the accomplished director succeeds in making more fascinating than you may imagine. Three interlocking stories, set in three different parts of the world, finally converge and although there are rocky moments along the way, the result is amazingly satisfying.

DAVID STRATTON

* * * 1/2

127 Hours (MA15+)

Trapped in a Utah canyon in 2003 with a boulder pinning his arm and unable to call for help, Aron Ralston spent an agonising six days in his rocky prison before managing to free himself. Danny Boyle's film is more than an unsparing record of Ralston's ordeal; it is a life-affirming experience, with some dazzling filmcraft and a brave central performance from James Franco. Much of it is hard to watch, all of it hard to forget.

EVAN WILLIAMS

* * * *

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

STAGE

The Wau Wau Sisters

The New York-based Wau Wau Sisters (Tanya Gagne and Adrienne Truscott) are part of a new wave of burlesque performers -- most of them women -- who trade on sex and nudity while dismantling traditional notions of the demeaned stripper or prettily passive showgirl. They open their new show, The Wau Wau Sisters are as Naked as the Day They Were Born Again, at the Adelaide Fringe. The sisters' routines are a spicy stir-fry of kinky acrobatics and trapeze, satirical songs, comedy sketches and stripping.

ROSEMARY NEILL

The Spiegeltent. Garden of Unearthly Delights, East Terrace, Adelaide. Tuesday, 11.30pm. Tickets: $30. Bookings: 1300 374 643. Until February 27.

The Lloyd Cole Small Ensemble

Singer-songwriter Lloyd Cole is touring Australia to promote his new studio album Broken Record. The Small Ensemble has Cole out front, with Mark Schwaber and Matt Cullen trading acoustic guitars, banjo and mandolin in support. Opening with No Blue Skies, Cole performs two sets and delves deep into his songbook. Highlights from his days with the Commotions include Perfect Skin, Are You Ready to be Heartbroken?, Forest Fire and Rattlesnakes. The older material sits well alongside recent compositions such as Writers Retreat! and favourites from the solo years such as Margo's Waltz, Like Lovers Do and the encore, Undressed. Cole's singing, buoyed by clever wordplay, is enriched throughout by a swell of acoustic instruments. Splendid.

SEAN SENNETT

The Gov. 59 Port Road, Hindmarsh. Wednesday, 5pm. Tickets: $53.60. Bookings: 1300 438 849.

EXHIBITIONS

Home Stories

Carolina Facelli, Irmina van Niele and Lee Salamone are among eight artists to tap into their migrant heritage for this new exhibition showing as part of the Adelaide Fringe. Each has selected an item from the Migration Museum collection -- for example a letter, photograph or piece of clothing -- to form the basis of their work.

Adelaide Central Gallery. 45 Osmond Tce, Norwood. Opens tonight, 6pm-8pm. Free. Inquiries: (08) 8364 2809. Until March 19.

WESTERN AUSTRALIA

STAGE

Waltzing the Wilarra

Yirra Yaakin theatre company is innovative, energetic and politically charged, and David Milroy's new production is no exception. From the moment the spotlight finds vaudeville wise-cracker Old Toss (Ernie Dingo) with his sidekick Young Harry (Jessica Clarke), we are on a roller-coaster of irony, bitter social critique, affectionate humour and drama. Drawing on a club such as the Coolbaroo -- which arose in Australia after World War II, and where whites and Aborigines sang and danced together -- as a potential model for a possibly more genuine mode of reconciliation, the play weaves music theatre in a Brechtian strain with contemporary drama. Highlights are Ursula Yovich's soaring voice and Trevor Jamieson's sensitive rendering of his character Charlie.

JOHN KINSELLA

Subiaco Arts Centre. 180 Hamersley Rd, Subiaco. Tuesday, noon and 7.30pm. Tickets: $54.50. Bookings: (08) 9484 1133. Until March 6.

DANCE

Ballet at the Quarry

Even the pale moon seemed to brighten, stunned by the magnificent vitality of the WA Ballet dancers at the Quarry. Attendant on Maria Callas's meticulous voice, their molten bodyline and precision made the complex seven-couple pas de deux in Jiri Kylian's Un Ballo almost transcendental. Their strong classical technique and rhythmic fidelity in Uwe Scholz's Seventh Symphony, in which Jennifer Provins shone, added a wonderful layer of interpretation to Ludwig van Beethoven's Symphony No 7. Although lone Australian choreographer David Jonathan's Saudade suffered from indistinct lighting, Ivan Cavallari's Chaplinesque duet Ombra Leggiera was amusingly captivating and crowned a compelling performance.

RITA CLARKE

Quarry Amphitheatre. Wednesday, 8pm. Tickets: $49-$63. Bookings: 136 100. Until March 5.

EXHIBITIONS

The King's Speech and the Maj Connection

Thanks to Geoffrey Rush's BAFTA-winning and Oscar-nominated portrayal in The King's Speech, interest in Adelaide-born speech therapist Lionel Logue has never been greater. Now a small exhibition in Perth highlights a lesser-known side of Logue: his days as a public speaker, producer and actor. Logue was known to recite Shakespeare and Dickens in various venues across Perth, and also devised, produced and acted in plays and musicals. The exhibition includes pictures of Nicholson's music shop, in Barrack Street, where Logue ran the School of the Spoken Word, a club for public speakers.

IAN CUTHBERTSON

DownStairs at the Maj. His Majesty's Theatre, 825 Hay St, Perth. Mon-Fri 10am-4pm. Free. Inquiries: (08) 9265 0900. Until March 31.

urn:contentItem:46N5-MM50-015H-92B4-00000-00<published>2002-09-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>TRAVEL; Pg. 36</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Canberra uncorked</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>JEFF COLLERSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">CANBERRA'S turn-of-the-century temperance society members must be spinning in their graves. Their former meeting room, the Toual Public Schoolhouse built in 1888, has become a wine-tasting facility.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The schoolhouse is the focal point of Ken Helm's idiosyncratic winery, 45km on the Barton Highway from Canberra.</p><p>Mention Canberra and most of us think politics, foreign embassies and the National Gallery, Parliament House and the Australian War Memorial. Tasting wine would be at the bottom of the scale in most national capital tourists' must-visit lists.</p><p> Yet John Richard Hardy (no relation to the Hardy winemaking clan) planted grapevines in Yass, on the edge of Canberra, in 1853.</p><p> That was 23 years before James Busby lit what became a "vinous forest fire" by establishing a vineyard in the Hunter Valley.</p><p> While the Hunter wine industry never stopped growing, Canberra's had a short life until resurrected as a cottage industry in 1971 by the Lake George and Clonakilla wineries.</p><p>Canberra wine's shot-in-the-arm came when Ken Helm quit his job as a CSIRO scientist two years later and established the district's first commercial vineyard and winery.</p><p> Every successful wine region has a champion -- a local winemaker who takes it upon himself to garner publicity, extolling the virtues of his area's produce.</p><p> Helm has been so successful that his face appears regularly on Canberra Tourism promotional material and in 2000 was given the title of "Canberra's honorary ambassador".</p><p> Inside Helm's quaint cellar door, besides thumbing your nose at those temperance wowsers with a schoolhouse tasting, you can inspect a working 1920s Bordeaux wine press that goes like the clappers during vintage.</p><p> The best way to visit Canberra is to enter the region along the Barton Highway and leave via the Federal Highway. This way you can choose from six Murrumbateman area wineries, grab an excellent yet inexpensive lunch at Barrique, built in 1879, then head to Canberra.</p><p> The latest, and for mine the best, attraction is the free-entry National Museum of Australia on the Acton Peninsula, which opened in March last year and welcomed a million visitors in its first 12 months.</p><p> I'm no "culture vulture" and until my wife dragged me into the National my perception of museums was stodgy and usually boring. Put those notions aside here.</p><p> The museum houses 172,000 historical and indigenous objects.</p><p> Five permanent exhibitions comprise Nation (symbols of Australia), Horizons (peopling of Australia since 1788), Eternity (stories from the nation's emotional heart), Tangled Destinies (Australia's land and people) and First Australians (a gallery of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders).</p><p> When leaving Canberra take the Federal Highway and inspect the showpiece Kamberra Wine Tourism Complex, opened in September 2000.</p><p> Joshua Moore, who received the area's first land grant in 1824, named his property Canberra after hearing local Aborigines calling the area Kamberra.</p><p> Set on 8.5ha and surrounded by vineyards, the complex has a showcase display of Canberra's 24 wineries, a restaurant and tasting room, glassware exhibits and 11am daily tours.</p><p> For $10 visitors get a souvenir glass, taste a dozen new-release wines and a 45-minute inspection of the winery.</p><p> It's the perfect end to a varied trip.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:54FN-V9N1-F0JP-W2FF-00000-00theinformer2011-12-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisPARADISEPg. 27theinformermichael jacobson

Hello all, Informer is back, albeit minus my customary enthusiasm. Instead of returning to work on Monday as eager as a beaver with ADHD, I brought only a ham and pickle sandwich, a kiwifruit, a can of Pepsi Max and the spectre of doom.

Why? Well, the first three items comprised my lunch. The fourth, however, that spectre of doom thingy, is the real problem and it's been tracking me like David Gulpilil ever since I realised early in my holiday that my pay-TV service wants to kill me.

Informer once adored Austar - she was the partner who never answered back - and unlike those hoity-toity subscribers who fib about only watching National Geographic and the Discovery Channel, I have long relished Austar's baser options.

If pay-TV were a swimming pool, you'd find Informer splashing around in the shallow end, down there with the endless Seinfeld re-runs, the Poirot and Miss Marple repeats and the idiotic genius of Cops, I'm a Celebrity ... Get Me Out of Here! and Ladette to Lady.

Then there's all the movie channels which, while screening many films among the greatest in the cinematic pantheon, also feature those of lesser artistic and intellectual merit, but which do have bevies of half-naked, morally casual, gorgeous women shagging as if their plane was going down.

Despite such marvels, lately my affection for Austar has waned, mainly because the network keeps telling me I'm about to pop my clogs and thus consign Mrs Informer and the kids to destitution and life on the streets.

Believe me, Informer would never inflict any such fate . . . on the kids.

Yet it's difficult not to ponder one's demise when most Austar ad breaks now comprise some earnest twat/twats patronisingly flogging cheap online life insurance premiums to ensure one's family will be tickety-boo after I drop like a shot duck any minute now.

And if all that isn't depressing enough, the manner of one's departure is even more worrying. Research this week found examples of some of history's more bizarre exits. Such as -

*l 8th century Chinese poet Li Po drowned in the Yangtze River when, trying to hug the reflection of the moon, the dickhead fell out of his boat.

* 16th century Austrian crackpot Hans Steininger was nuts enough to grow his beard longer than he was tall. When fire tore through his township, a panicked Hans tripped over his beard, broke his neck and carked.

* In 1982, American David Grundman shot a 10m saguaro cactus, a chunk of which fell and crushed him. Killed and quilled. Serves him right.

* Sixth-century Greek wrestler Milo of Croton tested his strength by trying to rip a tree apart with his bare hands. When Milo's mitts got stuck, the cretin from Croton was eaten by wolves.

* In 1649, British military commander Sir Arthur Aston was beaten to death with his wooden leg.

* In 1816, American statesman Gouverneur Morris died after shoving a whale bone through his urinary tract.

* In 1991, American Carl Hulsey was butted to death by a goat he'd been training as, wait for it, a guard goat.

* In 1915, Tour de France winner Francois Faber was fighting in the trenches of World War I when, upon receiving a letter announcing the birth of his daughter, he cheered, gave away his position and was shot by a sniper.

* In 2010 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 20 people were killed when a plane crashed after a pet crocodile escaped and passengers stampeded the cockpit.

* In China last year, a 59-year-old chef died when drunken mates shoved a 50cm swamp eel up his clacker as a prank. The eel devoured his bowels, although Informer in no way suggests this proves some people's contention that Asians will eat anything.

* Turkish farmer Ismail Ayyildiz tried to cure his toothache by shooting the offending molar. You can guess the rest. Dental as anything.

* While this one is said to be an urban legend and was even adapted for a CSI episode, there might be some truth behind US firefighters finding a body dressed in full scuba gear in a scorched earth area after a forest fire.

The story goes the diver was swimming where choppers were drawing water to dump on the blaze. Yanked skyward in a bucket, he was dropped from 100m. Splash to splat.

* Finally, an Egyptian farmer lost three sons, a daughter and two cousins when each descended a well to rescue a chook and were dragged to their deaths by an undercurrent. The chook emerged alive.

There are so many ways to go and Informer really doesn't need one morbid insurance ad after another to remind me of that inevitable reality every time I turn on Austar to watch How to Look Good Naked, a 1975 episode of Columbo or the three-part series of The Brady Bunch when the family goes to Hawaii and finds Vincent Price.

Perish the thought, so to speak, but if Austar persists with this ghoulish practice I may be left with no choice but to return to the entertainment graveyard that is free-to-air TV.

Such is life, I suppose, when death comes at such a premium.

``In 2010 in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, 20 people were killed when a plane crashed after a pet crocodile escaped and passengers stampeded the cockpit

urn:contentItem:4TSD-X4Y0-TXX1-F0NR-00000-00Field guide to cyber friends and frenemies2008-10-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisCM2Pg. 44Field guide to cyber friends and frenemiesMichael Lund

The social networking website Facebook has attracted tens of millions of users and now its own book, writes Michael Lund

Profiles

THE majority of Facebook profiles can be described as one of five categories.

Newser: Always updating their profile with the latest news about themselves, usually more than three times a day.

Self-promoter: Treats their profile like a gossip column and wants to be seen, lots of photos at parties or celebrations.

The Friend Whore: Someone with way too many friends (typically in the thousands).

The Creepster: The dark side of social networks and a chance for the authors to get serious and warn people that some will use Facebook for no good. Be warned.

The Performance Artist: A profile where every word is carefully considered, all photos look professional.

The Facebook Book, by Greg Atwan and Evan Lushing. Illustrated by Aurora Andrews (Abrams, $19.95)

www.thefacebookbook.com

IT SEEMS incredible given the almost unlimited space offered on the worldwide web that so many people want to crowd together in one place.

Such is the nature of Facebook.

The social networking website has taken the world by storm, attracting more than 110 million active users in just four years.

If Facebook were a country it would be the 11th most populated nation on the planet (Australia is 54th).

Like any country then, it needs a guidebook, which is why authors Greg Atwan and Evan Lushing wrote The Facebook Book.

``We searched on Amazon for `Facebook' and realised there wasn't really a single book out there on a phenomenon that had at the time, 40 million members,'' Atwan says from his home in New York, in a conversation using Facebook.

``We thought we could fill the gap, educate people a little bit about what was going on with social networking, and get paid to write some jokes.''

The book takes a humorous look at the rise of the social networking phenomenon.

One chapter even categorises the typical Facebook user into five main types.

``We've looked at a lot of Facebook profiles,'' Atwan says.

``After the millionth or so we realised that people were just repeating other people.

``It wasn't unconscious plagiarism, though -- just that there really aren't that many different sorts of people out there.''

Atwan, 25, describes himself as a mix of ``Friend Whore'' and ``Newser'' while Evan, 28, is a ``Performance Artist''.

The book offers plenty of advice.

Q. Is it OK to break up with someone by changing your relationship status to single and just letting her figure it out?

A. No.

Every aspect of the network is examined and explored with amusing -- and useful -- tips, with illustrations by Aurora Andrews.

The authors reckon they have a good insight into Facebook as they were at Harvard University when Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg created the network there in 2004.

``Neither of us knew him well,'' Atwan says. ``He kept to his dorm room mostly.

``We all assumed he was programming, but in retrospect -- since he knew he was about to found a $15 billion company -- he was probably spending his days splashing around in a kiddie-pool filled with caviar.''

At first the social network was limited to the Harvard community but Atwan says once the word was out the interest grew rapidly.

``It spread like a forest fire,'' he says.

``At first it was just the computer geeks, then the computer nerds, then the wonks, and finally the analog geeks.

``Before anyone knew it, the president of the university was `poking' (virtual attention seeking) everyone.''

So what is it then that makes people crowd together on Facebook -- the most popular social network website in Australia, according to the internet monitors Hitwise.

Atwan attributes its success to Facebook's ability to allow users to keep an eye on what their friends are doing.

``Never before have people been afforded an opportunity to spy on their friends without being barked at by their friends' dogs,'' he says.

He also likens the networking to the online equivalent of hanging out in the village square.

``Especially in America,'' he says, ``where the actual village squares are polluted by poor former investment bankers.

``People are looking for a safe place to hang out with their friends, `frenemies' (an enemy disguised as a friend), and strangers, without the awkwardness of eye contact.''

urn:contentItem:459M-VMR0-0197-T3YN-00000-00<published>1998-08-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Kabila's troops take airport</p><p nitf:lede="true">PRESIDENT Laurent Kabila's troops retook the airport in the Democratic</p><p nitf:lede="true">Republic of the Congo's third city of Kisangani from Rwandan-backed</p><p nitf:lede="true">rebels yesterday, state radio said. Kabila arrived in Zimbabwe's</p><p nitf:lede="true">resort town of Victoria Falls yesterday for a weekend regional summit</p><p nitf:lede="true">to discuss renewed fighting in the former Zaire. He accuses former</p><p nitf:lede="true">ally Rwanda of invasion but Rwanda says the unrest is an internal</p><p nitf:lede="true">revolt in Kabila's army.</p><p>Burmese plea for junta end</p><p>BURMESE opposition groups yesterday made an impassioned plea for the</p><p>removal of their country's military junta, saying the people had lost</p><p>patience on the eve of the 10th anniversary of a bloody military</p><p>crackdown on pro-democracy protesters. "Do not lose heart," Nobel</p><p>peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi told Burmese refugees in a</p><p>pre-recorded address released to journalists in Bangkok.</p><p>Balloon up, up and away</p><p>UNITED States adventurer Steve Fossett last night began his latest</p><p>quest to become the first person to fly non-stop around the world in a</p><p>balloon with a smooth lift-off from a soccer field in Argentina. His</p><p>flight plan could take him over Australia. After a series of delays</p><p>caused by unfavourable winds, Fossett's balloon, Solo Spirit, lifted</p><p>off from the town of Mendoza at 6.30pm and soared south-east towards</p><p>the Andes mountains. It is Fossett's fourth try at the elusive</p><p>aviation milestone and his first in the southern hemisphere.</p><p>Fatal Baghdad bomb blast</p><p>A YOUNG girl was killed and about a dozen others injured last night in</p><p>an explosion in downtown Baghdad apparently aimed at a car belonging</p><p>to the militant Iranian opposition group Mojahedin Khalq. Witnesses</p><p>said the explosive charge, hidden in a sack next to a tree, was</p><p>detonated by remote control as the Mojahedin car was passing.</p><p>Czech leader getting better</p><p>CZECH President Vaclav Havel, whose life was threatened earlier this</p><p>week by a severely accelerated heartbeat, is on the mend and watching</p><p>television, his doctors said yesterday. Havel, 61, is breathing</p><p>spontaneously and the inflammation that led to his heart problems is</p><p>receding, his medical team said. "Mr President is watching television</p><p>and taking an interest in events around him," a spokesman said.</p><p>French firebug arrested</p><p>GREEK police have arrested a French tourist caught lighting a forest</p><p>fire in the western province of Thesprotia. Police said late yesterday</p><p>the suspect, on holiday in the region with his wife, was being held at</p><p>the police station in Igumenitsa. He was suspected of having caused</p><p>the huge blaze that ravaged the island of Corfu earlier in the week.</p><p>The French tourist is the third person arrested during the past few</p><p>days for trying to start forest fires. The fires around the Greek</p><p>capital of Athens for the past week have begun to abate but a blaze</p><p>continues on Mount Olympia.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5DHS-RRP1-F031-X412-00000-00Are today's leaders prepared for cyberwarfare?2014-11-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisPM6:32 PM AESTABCMark ColvinAre today's leaders prepared for cyberwarfare?

MARK COLVIN: One reason the First World War got so bogged down over four years was that generals used to 19th century warfare took so long to understand the new technologies of air and tank warfare.

Australia's general John Monash was among the first to realise the need to co-ordinate all the forces - the move that brought on the great advances of 1918.

Are today's military leaders similarly unprepared for the need to bring cyber warfare into the mix?

Peter W Singer, a strategist and senior fellow at the New America Foundation, is lecturing on cyber security and cyber war at Sydney University tonight.

We began by talking about definition of cyber warfare, and I asked him first if the 2007 internet attack which brought Estonia to an electronic standstill could have been seen as an act of war.

PETER SINGER: Yes but that's not war. Count me as a traditionalist, even though we're talking about cyber, is that there still has to be some kind of violence, some kind of physical effect, so the so-called cyber war that hit Estonia several years ago, essentially a couple of their public facing websites on government institutions got defaced, it would be a lot like someone running up to the parliament and spray painting the side of it.

And then some of the traffic was blocked, it would be like someone standing there in the road blocking it for a couple of hours. If these were physical things, if it was people doing the spray painting, or standing in the road, you wouldn't describe that as war.

MARK COLVIN: You could use another analogy, you could say that one country bombs another one's power station, kills nobody, that's defiantly an act of warfare and it makes just as much difference, just as much damaged doesn't it?

PETER SINGER: Exactly. But fortunately we've not had that happen yet. We've not had someone carry out this kind of attack that knocks power grids offline or disrupts traffic in a way that people die or the like. We haven't had...

MARK COLVIN: But if they did by cyber means, that would be an act of warfare, just as bombing a power station would?

PETER SINGER: Exactly, I don't think a prime minister or a president will care whether the means was with software or hardware. They'll judge it by the ends; they'll judge it by the final effect.

If someone lit a forest fire, even though, and hundreds of people were killed, even though they used a match rather than killing with a knife or a gun, no one would say well, that wasn't a bad deed.

So at the end of the day I think we'll judge a lot of the effects of cyber war in traditional manners.

Now the key here cyber war in all its likelihood is probably going to be involving both traditional, physical operations and computer operations. And a good illustration of this is what we've seen Israel do a couple of years ago, for example, where they use cyber means to turn Syrian air defences off and then flew jets overhead which dropped real bombs. It was the cyber and the traditional working together, that's probably the future of both war and cyber war.

MARK COLVIN: But in traditional warfare there are the Geneva conventions and a bunch of other rules, at the moment there are no rules in cyber warfare, am I right?

PETER SINGER: We have this debate as to whether the old rules should apply and if they're sufficient and then if not what can we do about them. Now we get into a problem of can we then walk the talk? So as an illustration, NATO put together a group of international legal experts and said 'you know what - we should write a manual about the laws of cyber war'.

And they wrote this manual, it's a very good document, except then the US government looked at the manual and said, 'you know what, great manual, but we're not going to say that that definitively applies to us, we want to keep all our options.' That's just within NATO...

MARK COLVIN: It took the UN to create the Geneva Conventions, is there any prospect that the UN could do anything about this?

PETER SINGER: Well it took the UN, but remember it also took the horrors of World War Two, that's unfortunately the long history of international law - in fact the foundation of international law itself, going back to the 1600s. Usually we wait for the bad thing to happen and then we collectively build up a rule based structure to try to prevent it from happening again.

Hopefully we won't repeat that pattern with cyber, but I'm not going to bet my house on it.

MARK COLVIN: Well the obvious question from that is what is the nightmare scenario?

PETER SINGER: I think to me the nightmare scenario is not the clear cut use of this in a war, it's actually the fuzzy space in between, before you get to formally declared wars, where one side may carry out a cyber attack and think it's not an act of war and the other side will interpret it as an act of war.

This fuzziness also affects the who, so not just what you're doing but the who. A number of nations, particularly the Russias and Chinas of the world, have been using cut-out groups, criminal groups, people's militia, basically to conduct attacks but say 'well that was not us, that someone else.'

And in many ways we're back to a parallel of the 1600 and 1700s where you had navies who were clearly official representatives of the King, you had pirates who were clearly criminals. And then you had this thing in the middle called privateers, they would kind of go back and forth between the legal and the illegal.

We have the cyber equivalent of that right now in a lot of different places. And that's disturbing, that's where bad things might come, from miscalculation.

MARK COLVIN: Has the United States lost moral high ground because of the Snowden revelations? I mean it's all very well to talk about China and Russia, but somebody will always now snap back with, 'well look at what the NSA did'.

PETER SINGER: It's very clear that the Snowden scandal - revelations - however you want to frame it, have been a hammer blow to Americans' standing, both in terms of our bilateral relationships, when we're pressing china on something they point their finger back at us, right now, even if it's on things justified or not, to the discourse over internet freedom has clearly been harmed by this, to frankly American technology companies themselves are very angry at the NSA because it's costs them business.

And so this is why it's had a long-term affect well beyond just the immediate sort of revelations of what they're doing.

The question is how do we move past it, how do we power through it? We'll see some reforms, it's already happening within our legislature and then other parts of it frankly, and this also applies to our Australian partners, there's things that aren't going to change and it's just the new context of a post-Snowden world.

MARK COLVIN: Peter Singer of the New America Foundation. There will be a longer version of that interview on our website from this evening. And he's giving a lecture this evening at the Centre for International Security Studies at the University of Sydney.

urn:contentItem:49N9-VVW0-01S8-D4J0-00000-00<published>1992-01-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firemen swelter in forest</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>THOM G</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">FIREFIGHTERS sweltered in 40-degree heat as they tackled a forest fire near Mt Macedon yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> About 200ha were destroyed in the deliberately lit blaze started about 1pm near Barringo, 4km south of Mt Macedon.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Swirling winds which caused spot fires and a top temperature of 43 deg. in some parts of the state added to the firefighters' woes.</p><p>The temperature in Melbourne reached 39.5 at 2.40pm, making it the hottest day since March 8 last year when the temperature reached 40.3 deg.</p><p> About 200 firefighters, with 45 water tankers and backed up by a water attack helicopter, battled the Barringo blaze, the first large-scale fire this year.</p><p> About 30 of the tankers were from Country Fire Authority units and the rest from the Conservation and Environment Department.</p><p> Firefighters thought they had controlled the blaze by mid-afternoon, but were surprised by wind changes which helped revive the flames.</p><p> At one point, the CFA forward command post co-ordinating the operation had to be moved when it was threatened by flames racing towards it through a gully.</p><p> No houses were threatened by the fire and no one was injured.</p><p> On Victoria's first total fire ban day of the summer, CFA units were kept than 45 grass and scrub fires in Melbourne's outer suburbs as well as country areas.</p><p> Fires started in a variety of areas ringing Melbourne, including Warrandyte, Boronia, Rowville, Hastings, Rye, Werribee, Rockbank and Dandenong.</p><p> Firefighters around the state were kept busy by small fires, from Traralgon in the east, to Echuca, Rochester and Corop in the north-east and Ballarat, Ballan and Stawell in the west.</p><p> Most of the state sweltered under the heat, with the hottest areas 43 deg. at Ouyen and 41 deg. at Mildura, Swan Hill, Echuca, Kerang and Geelong.</p><p> Yesterday's scorcher followed a 35 deg. top on Sunday, with predictions today of early showers before becoming fine and heading for a temperature of 30 deg.</p><p> There will be a late change tomorrow after a top in the mid-30s, mid-20s on Thursday and showers and low 20s on Friday.</p><p> There is a total fire ban today - but only in the north-eastern district.</p><p> A 33-year-old volunteer firefighter, Geoffrey Rose, was in hospital last night recovering from burns he received while battling one of three deliberately lit blazes in the Adelaide Hills on Sunday.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Temporary relief . . . Hugo Waldmanies of Bendigo takes a quick breakto grab a drink from a hose during roadworks at Mulgrave yesterday. urn:contentItem:5G2B-SM91-JC0X-K47F-00000-00Highlights of the AAP Sports Wire at 14:45 May 23, 20152015-05-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisSPORTS NEWSHighlights of the AAP Sports Wire at 14:45 May 23, 2015

  HIGHLIGHTS SPORT (ATTN EDITORS)
   RUGBY LEAGUE
   SYDNEY - The Parramatta Eels will challenge the NRL's ruling on salary cap breaches, club chairman Steve Sharp has announced. (RL Eels Cap 2nd Update (with factbox) Wrap to come
   SYDNEY - Wests Tigers v North Queensland, Campbelltown Stadium, 1930 - (RL Tigers Wrap) to come
   GOLD COAST - News from Nate Myles/Will Chambers pressers at Queensland Origin camp - (RL Origin Qld Wrap) and sidebar to come
   COFFS HARBOUR, NSW - News/interview with prop James Tamou from NSW Origin camp - (RL Origin NSW) Wrap to come
   COFFS HARBOUR - Josh Dugan looked up to NSW fullback forerunner Jarryd Hayne but is thriving on the challenge of making the position his own, according to Trent Merrin. (RL Origin Merrin Update)


   CANBERRA - Canberra are bracing themselves axed NSW five-eighth Josh Reynolds to take his State of Origin omission out on them when they host Canterbury on Sunday. (RL Raiders)
   SYDNEY - The NRL calendar hasn't even reached its halfway point, but Parramatta star Anthony Watmough admits time is running out for the team to save their season. (RL Eels)
   SYDNEY - South Sydney hero Cameron McInnes says he still has a lot more to learn in the NRL before becoming the club's bona fide hooker. (RL Souths)
   HULL - Super League champions St Helens have come through a tough examination at in-form Hull FC, winning 17-10 at the KC Stadium. (RL Super Update)
  
   AFL
   Round eight
   MELBOURNE - A defiant Mick Malthouse says he won't walk away from Carlton, but he refuses to beg to extend his tenure as senior coach at the beleaguered AFL club. (AFL Blues) Wrap to come
   MELBOURNE - St Kilda v West Coast, Etihad Stadium, 1345 - (AFL Saints Wrap) to come
   SYDNEY - GWS v Adelaide, Spotless Stadium, 1410 - (AFL Giants Wrap) to come
   GOLD COAST - Gold Coast v Collingwood, Metricon Stadium, 1635 - (AFL Suns Wrap) to come
   MELBOURNE - Hawthorn v Sydney, MCG, 1920 - (AFL Hawks Wrap) to come
   PERTH - Fremantle v North Melbourne, Domain Stadium, 1940AEST - (AFL Dockers Wrap) to come
   ADELAIDE - Port Adelaide stalwart Kane Cornes doesn't know what to expect at the final siren of his AFL career. (AFL Port)
   MELBOURNE - Western Bulldogs coach Luke Beveridge is keen to regain lost momentum when the Dogs take on Melbourne on Sunday. (AFL Bulldogs)
   MELBOURNE - Previews for Essendon v Brisbane (AFL Bombers) to come
  
   RUGBY UNION
   Super Rugby round 15
   AUCKLAND - Blues v Hurricanes, Eden Park, 1735AEST - NZN (Super Blues) to come
   SYDNEY - NSW Waratahs v Crusaders, ANZ Stadium, 1940 - (Super Waratahs Wrap) to come
   PERTH - Western Force v Highlanders, NIB Stadium, 2145AEST - (Super Force Wrap)
   AMSTERDAM - Australia's Women's Sevens team have accumulated enough points to qualify directly for the the Rio 2016 Olympics rugby tournament. (RU Women)
   BRISBANE - James O'Connor won't bear the burden of blame on his own for Queensland's deflating 21-14 Super Rugby loss to the Sharks on Friday. (Super Reds)
  
   TENNIS
   PARIS - Gen-Y stars Nick Kyrgios and Thanasi Kokkinakis are hoping to lead the changing of the guard as Australia boasts its largest French Open singles contingent this century. (Ten Open Aust Wrap (with factbox))
   PARIS - Serena Williams says that at 33 she believes that time is still on her side for her to set a new all-time record of grand slam singles title wins. (Ten Open Women)
   PARIS - Samantha Stosur is hoping a new coach and last-minute change of heart will culminate in her brightest French Open build-up since she lost the 2010 final at Roland Garros. (Ten WTA Wrap)
   PARIS - Novak Djokovic celebrated his 28th birthday on Friday and marked the occasion by pondering another landmark - his attempt to become just the eighth man to complete the grand slam. (Ten Open Men)
