urn:contentItem:5XTB-4K81-F031-X122-00000-00The role of forensic science in criminal investigations2019-12-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisScience Show2:36 PM AESTThe role of forensic science in criminal investigations

David Fisher: Today's Science Show comes from the World Science Festival in Brisbane where Robyn Williams and a thanatophilic panel (thanatophilic panel, look it up!) are about to discuss the history and future of forensic research.

Unknown: It does take quite a lot of courage to make that first cut in human skin, but once you do and you're inside the human body, it is just such an amazing world that you marvel in it, you're not repelled by it. So the first time you see your forensic case where that body, that beautiful body is disrupted, whether it's disrupted by fire, by decomposition, by trauma, whatever it may be, you almost look beyond that to what it was and you compare the two, and in the comparison of the two, it allows you to determine what happened. What happened between that perfect intact body, you know what it should look like, and what you have in front of you. So it becomes the investigation, it becomes the puzzle. And we all love puzzles.

Unknown: The power of flies and maggots is extraordinary. It's said that three flies can get rid of the flesh of a horse faster than a lion can because of the way that they lay their eggs, the eggs turn into maggots, the maggots eat the body, and the next set of flies come along, and it's this biological process that sounds quite gruesome when you talk about it and it is quite gruesome when you see it in action, but is extremely effective.

Robyn Williams: Good morning, I'm Robyn. So, forensics in the 21st century. From Sherlock Holmes to ABC's Harrow, people have always loved a good mystery, particularly the sometimes gruesome and always intriguing portrayal of forensic science in popular culture. And it seems always at dinner time Amelia Fox is extracting a liver or opening a mouth full of maggots.

But is modern forensics really like we see on CSI or those gritty and dark Scandinavian crime shows? Today we are going to indulge our inner forensic pathologist and take a glimpse into the lives and work of four real-life forensic scientists, from DNA to the dark web, they will reveal at least some of their secrets to solving a case.

Our first guest has worked in forensic science education for over 24 years and is currently director of the Leverhulme Research Centre for Forensic Science at the University of Dundee in Scotland. Please welcome Niamh Nic Daeid.

Next please welcome a leader in forensic genetics from the University of Technology in Sydney. He spent his career finding better ways to extract and analyse DNA, imparting his knowledge to students of forensic science, Professor Dennis McNevin.

Our next guest works in the area of forensic taphonomy, which is the science of estimating the time of death from animal or human remains. She is also developing methods for the successful location and recovery of victims' evidence in mass disaster scenarios. Also based at the University of Technology Sydney, please welcome Maiken Ueland.

Finally we welcome the inaugural chair of cybersecurity at the University of the Sunshine Coast and director of the Institute for Cyber Investigations and Forensics. He is also the managing director and co-founder of IDCARE, the national identity and cyber support community service. Needless to say you won't find him online: Professor David Lacey.

So Niamh, what do you think of Amelia Fox, frankly?

Niamh Nic Daeid: She is a very nice lady. Amelia Fox stars in Silent Witness, and Silent Witness is a really great program, it's entertainment folks, that's what it is.

Robyn Williams: And what about the rest of the shows we're seeing?

Niamh Nic Daeid: I would argue the same, shows like CSI and other crime dramas are exactly that, they are fantastic at what they do, which is to entertain us, but forensic science isn't like that. 40% of what you see in CSI does not exist, folks, when it comes to science, and so they build expectations. When we do have to do this job for real, they build expectations of the jury, they build expectations of the non-scientists as to what it is we can deliver and actually we can't, and so there is a real significance behind this as well.

Robyn Williams: One thing I didn't know, that forensics comes from the Latin forensis which means 'in open court', and to this day the endpoint and real value of forensic science is to find a person guilty or innocent of a crime in a public court of law. So Niamh, you were virtually born (is this right?) into forensics?

Niamh Nic Daeid: Oh look, there I am. Kind of. I was cute once! My family background...I come from a family of scientists, one is a botanist, one is a chemist. And very early on it as I was growing up they started to get involved in the investigation of fires and fire scenes and where the job to be done there is to determine the origin of the fire, the cause of the fire and how the fire spread through a building. And so as a result of that we were always exposed...because they worked for themselves, they worked in a private company for the civil courts, not criminal, we were always exposed to conversations about what the little burnt black thing looked like in the photograph and which way up should the photograph be and what does it mean and how do you put it into context of the story of the case, the story of the fire. And so I was always, as I said, exposed to that from a very early age. And to me it crystallised a number of things. The very first one was that women can be involved in science just as much as men and actually can hold their own very well indeed. The second was that science is useful, so that what you do as a scientist actually can have real-world impact because we were using our scientific understanding to unfold the story of this event. So from that early age, 10, 11, I always remember it to be a part of just our family upbringing.

Robyn Williams: Dennis, for you, DNA and your profession, was that serendipitous?

Dennis McNevin: It was. I mean, I always grew up entranced by nature, and like probably many of you in this audience, I used to love watching Life on Earth, which was a David Attenborough marvellous genre-defining documentary about the origins of life, but I studied engineering. But I used to do biochemical engineering, so it was the engineering of using bacteria to treat wastewater, as it turns out. But they do this because of their DNA.

I then moved to Canberra, and there are no engineers...well, there are very few opportunities for engineers in Canberra. I saw a job advertised for a forensic scientist at the Australian Federal Police forensic laboratories, and I thought, look, why not, I'll have a go. So I applied for the job. I'm pretty sure I was the only applicant. And to my great surprise they gave me the job. And I spent the first three months of that job hiding from people at morning tea time so that I wasn't exposed for the fraud that I was. But I did read up and immerse myself in the world of forensics for that three months and that I felt confident enough to approach people in the lunchroom and that was the start of my career in forensics.

Robyn Williams: More or less what are the issues you deal with?

Dennis McNevin: My job is to look at the use of the DNA in the courtroom, so how can we make use of DNA to answer questions that courts are interested in. And of course that generally revolves around is one person guilty, is one person innocent. And DNA can tell us a lot but not everything about that. And Niamh alluded to some of the harm that has been done by the CSI programs. The very presence of DNA tends to create an impression of guilt, and that is not the case. DNA can be at a crime scene for many different reasons, and part of my job is to try and explain those reasons.

Robyn Williams: Maiken, you come from Norway. Tell me, is taphonomy a Norwegian name?

Maiken Ueland: No, definitely not. In fact in Norway we don't really have forensics, so I was grown up always intrigued by a crime and Scandinavian crime stories. I loved puzzles and I loved just playing outdoors and was so intrigued by signs in the body and everything that was happening, but I had no idea what forensics was. And in fact when I was 15 years old we were asked to write an essay in school; Where do you see yourself in 10 years? And I was so clear when I said 'I would like to be a doctor working for the police'. And everyone was like, what is that? Because I didn't actually know what forensics or taphonomy was but I knew exactly what I wanted to do, I wanted to help police solve crime. But because I didn't know how to go about it, I thought I had to be a doctor, study medicine and then join the police force, which is not really the way it works here. I googled it, ecstatic, ran around, and I was like, yes, of course, exactly, that's what I want to do. And then I attended a lecture at university my first year on taphonomy, and I was absolutely sold. It had everything, it had all the mysteries about the human body and how we can use that to solve everything. So taphonomy deals with everything that happens to an organism from the moment it ceases to breathe and until it is found. And it deals with what happens to the environment, to the body, and everything around it and how we can use that to solve crime. And I've never looked back since.

Robyn Williams: So are you dealing always with crime, or is it also accidents or some disaster?

Maiken Ueland: So our victims can be anything from individuals that have just gone bushwalking and unfortunately they've gotten lost and eventually they perish, and then we deal with the victims of crime, but it's also victims of mass disasters which are unfortunately happening more and more commonly now due to global change, but also genocides or war crimes. So there's a series of different individuals that we are trying to help.

Robyn Williams: How do you get used to the horror of the scene?

Maiken Ueland: Well, it's not an easy situation and you never really get used to it and I don't think you should be getting used to it, but you just have to remember why you're doing the job, and what you're doing, you're helping the victim and their family, so that's why you're there.

Robyn Williams: And David, cybercrime and so on, how did you get into the field? If your name is David, that is.

David Lacey: I graduated with an accounting degree, became a graduate accountant, and within about two weeks thought this is not for me. So, much to my parents' disgust I joined the army. And I worked within the intelligence domain, and law enforcement got wind that there was somebody in intelligence that had an accounting degree, 'you've got to come to us and do fraud'. The thing that kept me interested in this field is the constant evolution of the criminal actor and how they are exploiting the environment to their own ill-gotten gain, and what occurred over that 20-year period was obviously the growth and dominance of the online environment and the need to adapt.

Robyn Williams: What you seem to be saying is if your basis is solid, you could end up in all sorts of places, including cybercrime.

David Lacey: Absolutely. At the end of the day I think what's common across all of our different disciplines is the thirst for truth and fact and being able to translate that in a way that a court can understand.

Robyn Williams: And how do you keep up with the changing technology? Every time I blink they've done something different.

David Lacey: The thing that I've benefited mostly from is the work of IDCARE. So IDCARE, for those that haven't heard of it, which is a good thing in a way, it's a community support service that is free and anonymous if you experience cybercrime or identity theft. It's physically located an hour drive up the road on the Sunshine Coast, and it's resourced with counsellors and psychologists that help people through the event that they're dealing with. And so the benefit that I have is that I have this call centre that's telling me what the community is experiencing every day and how the criminals are evolving, and that keeps us honest about how we are applying our trade.

Robyn Williams: Yes, it's amazing, I went to a place in Edith Cowan University in Perth and there's a whole room there, they are tracking all sorts of things coming in from all sorts of banking systems to see whether there is a furphy coming through and they can then warn the people or warn the bank. And I've got this vision of there being various small dark rooms with various twisted people, nerds in strange clothing, existing on chocolate bars and maybe Diet Coke and all night going through, plotting. Have you ever come across the criminals unit yourself and are they like that?

David Lacey: I guess my apprenticeship was 20 years working in national security and law enforcement, and almost all of that time exclusively was working within agencies that were exempt from the Privacy Act, so they had extraordinary powers, they could collect anything, as long as it fit the particular investigation's domain. And in some respects I was the antichrist of privacy, and since establishing IDCARE it is actually the opposite of that, it's about how we protect people and their privacy and how do we educate them about what the risks are when bad things happen and what are the steps you can take to mitigate those risks. So my career to date has been this kind of ying and yang of privacy and personal information. And technology is an absolutely amazing thing that we should all embrace, but like anything there's risks, but there is useful steps you can take to mitigate that. So the value of the knowledge that we maintain is actually from you, it's from what you're experiencing. That's what keeps us current and that's what is really important.

Robyn Williams: So much for the background. Let's go to the second part of our discussion, which is from the crime in the lab to the courtroom, and so gathering and analysing and presenting evidence to the judicial system is a special kind of procedure. Maiken, take us to AFTER, as in the afterlife, but it stands for the Australian Facility for Taphonomic Experimental Research (say that when you're pissed!), which you now lead, and how Australia got to have the first body farm outside the USA.

Maiken Ueland: So a body farm is a place where people can donate their body to science, with the purpose of studying human decomposition, so how the body breaks down after death. And these were started in the US by a forensic anthropologist, Dr William Bass, and there was one particular case that he was working on where he ended up getting the age, the sex and the height of the victim correct, but he got the time of death (so how long the individual had been deceased for) wrong by over 100 years, which is quite outrageous. So you can't really say, oh yeah, he has been dead for a year and it has actually been 101 years. You can't really go to court with that. So allegedly this was the case that led him to open the very first body farm because he realised that we just don't know enough about decomposition and preservation. So what had happened in this particular case was that the body had been embalmed and that's why it looked so well preserved.

So he opened that very first facility in the US, and then it took about 20 years, and then additional of these research facilities...they call them body farms, we like to call them Taphonomic Research Facilities, it just doesn't sound as good in media. So after about 20 years, more of these opened up in the US in different climatic regions because we know that climate plays such a major impact on how the body decomposes. And if you look at the climate map, comparing the climate in the US and Australia, it's very different. And if we had similar maps of the tree coverage, for example, or if we look at the soil types between the US and Australia, if you looked at the type of insects, if you looked at the type of scavengers there would be, all of these are going to influence how the body is decomposing. They are going to be very different between the US and Australia. So that's why in 2016 we opened the Australian Facility for Taphonomic Experimental Research, and it was featured a fair bit in the media. And it's located in the outskirts of Sydney in a very remote location to mimic the kind of environment that the police would often get bodies being found in.

And at AFTER we are looking at four different types of research. We look at how we can search and locate for human remains and then how we can best recover these individuals and then determining their time of death, so how long they've been deceased for, and then lastly we look at how we can best identify these individuals. And we aim to better develop the current methods that we have but also developing new methods, all so that we can better assist law enforcement so we can ultimately provide answers to the families.

Robyn Williams: From what you say about getting the time wrong by 100 years reminds me of a lovely exhibition I saw in London, it was called The Last Tzar, because they were murdered 100 years ago, the entire family, and they couldn't actually find some of the kids, and they dug up another site because they happened to have some clues as to where it was, they were doing tests to find out whether it was in fact the family of the Tzar. And they roped in various other people who were connected, such as Prince Philip, they got his DNA and got a family profile and found indeed it was a couple of the boys who were involved. And they also managed to solve the problem...one of the survivors supposedly was the princess claiming to be the last one of the family. And they found out that she was in fact a cleaner or something else, which is amazing how you can now have the technology to find out all sorts of amazing stuff.

But Niamh, despite your efforts not to do what your parents did, did you eventually become a forensic chemist working on fire investigation?

Niamh Nic Daeid: The answer to your question is yes. So I teach fire investigation, and many of my research students have done work on both the fire scene investigation side of things but also analysis of debris, so materials you take back out of a fire. Fire investigation is many things, so an understanding of the combustion of different materials underpinning the work we do as fire investigators is having to have a knowledge of fire science and fire engineering, both essentially laboratory-based skills, and the two of them together create an overarching skill set called fire dynamics. So we have that.

When we you're a fire investigator you also do something that many forensic scientists don't do, and that is that you talk to real people, you talk to witnesses because we need to understand the story of what happened prior to the fire, what did normal look like, what was the building usually used for, who was the last person to leave, what's the lock-up procedures for them leaving that shop or premises or whatever it is, who saw the fire, what did they do, what did the firefighters do, where did they go, what colour was the smoke, what colour were the flames, where was the first fire discovered? And so on and so forth. So all of that witness information is really important for us.

So we get witness information, we've got a solid understanding of the chemistry and the physics and the engineering behind a particular building and how it will respond, and added to that we need to have an understanding of how electricity works because electricity is your friend in a fire if you are a fire investigator, because things will fail, so fuses or fuse boxes or appliances or whatever they might be will fail and will leave physical evidence behind them of the time of that failure. So you take those four blocks and you put them together when you walk into a black room that is blackened with black stuff and you're trying to figure out the black detail in the black background as to how and where the fire started and then what caused it to start and then why did it move to where it moves. So there is a very defined pathway in fire development that when you are skilled enough to know what you're doing, then you can find your way through that pathway.

I work on quite a number of different types of fire cases, and they can be anything from small-scale domestic fires to very large-scale. And one of the roles I am currently involved with is acting as an expert witness for the Grenfell Tower fire, so my job there was to work for the public inquiry and to review the cause of that fire; where did it start, and how did it start?

Robyn Williams: I wanted to ask you about forest fires and whether you can go into a forest fire and say fairly quickly whether it looks like lightning or whether it looks like some villain did it.

Niamh Nic Daeid: Forest fires are particularly challenging, they really are. I know it's a huge issue here in Australia, as it is in other parts of the world. There are particular techniques that you can use to try to track where the fire developed or where it might have started from, and often that's early news stories, early reports from people who have seen that first fire event occur. For things like lightning strikes versus some other activity, obviously you can track things like, well, was there a storm there at the time where the fire is alleged to have begun. But investigating wildlife fires is particularly challenging.

Robyn Williams: Dennis, DNA intelligence, why is this such an exciting area at the moment?

Dennis McNevin: Well, because it has opened up whole new possibilities for investigation of crime. So up until fairly recently, the way DNA was used in forensics was that there was biological evidence found at a crime scene, so it might be a bloodstain or saliva left on a glass or a drink bottle, and you then had a suspect and you took a reference sample from that suspect and you compared the two. And if they matched, then there was some evidence linking that individual with the crime, not guilt but there was certainly an association with that crime. And so you'd look at the other evidence to corroborate that.

But if there is no suspect that matches that crime scene evidence or there is no database hit, so the other way you can obtain a match is to search your DNA profile against a criminal DNA database. If you don't get a match to either of those, then traditionally that has been a bit of a dead end. But we now know that we can find other information about the donor of that DNA that might help us narrow a pool of suspects.

So, for example, we are able to predict the ancestry of that individual. And so these ancient lineages can be mixed, as they have done over the history of human evolution to produce different populations that can be combined in different ways to produce the people that we all are. And our job then is to predict what that individual's ancestors came from, and there techniques that we can use to do that but it's not always an easy task, especially in the modern world where there has been a lot of immigration, many marriages between cultures that didn't occur 100 years ago but which now do, so our genetics are very, very complex. But we do have tools that help us to make those estimations.

Robyn Williams: And when you make that sort of explanation in court, do they say, 'Oh yeah, that makes sense'?

Dennis McNevin: No, no, they do not. I will draw a distinction actually, that is not meant for court, that is meant for investigators because that information is designed to lead a forensic investigator to the suspect. Once you find your suspect, you can then take a standard DNA profile and match it to the crime scene evidence and that's much more easily understandable for the court.

Robyn Williams: Yes, well, when you think the DNA is about 3 billion base pairs, that's an enormous code. And what you get are bits of it, and so you're looking for patterns that might fit in here, there or somewhere else, and so it's not an infallible thing, is it, necessarily?

Dennis McNevin: It is not. I mean, certainly modern DNA profiles, the way that it's presented in court is as a probability. So, what's the probability that this profile would occur in a random individual in the population? Of course the more rare the chance, the more improbable that it will be found in a random member of the population, the greater the strength of that evidence because it's less likely to come from somebody else. But we don't always get full, clean, beautiful profiles, we often get very degraded profiles where we only see some of the markers that we are looking for, and in those instances the probability that a random member of the population could be the source is much greater, and so then that's a difficult job, is to explain that to the court about this reduced strength of the evidence.

Robyn Williams: And you're listening to The Science Show on RN, with a panel at the World Science Festival, on forensics and the future.

David, you may have gathered I'm fairly old-fashioned, and I do not have a mobile phone and therefore I cannot be zapped, as far as I can tell, and when it comes to banking I keep all my coins in a kangaroo scrotum under the bed. Am I safe these days?

David Lacey: You're safe. We should all have kangaroo scrotums.

Robyn Williams: How vulnerable is everybody else? What are you looking at in the ways of the complexity of the crimes these days? You hinted at it before but what's going on?

David Lacey: So the most recent surveying done by the Commonwealth government suggests that around 1.2 million Australians a year are falling victim to cybercrimes. But the more complex ones, and we are looking at anywhere between 200,000 and 400,000 people a year, is where criminals are looking through an online environment or off-line to start with but then online, to steal and misuse your personal information, and where that can lead to then applying for credit in your name, such as a mortgage or a personal loan or a mobile phone account or a government service. And at the moment if you're in that boat you will on average spend around 24 to 30 non-consecutive hours trying to respond to that event. You will probably have to engage at least eight different organisations about 20 times, and it will be on you to prove it. Most of our time is spent through counselling and coaching via knowledge exchange, it's about educating, and a lot of the people that are impacted by these types of crimes benefit from now that greater knowledge, and they feel more confident and comfortable about engaging online. So it's certainly impacting a lot of people and increasingly so.

Robyn Williams: And how many of you would there be, because surely with so much going on we need about several hundred, David?

David Lacey: No, we've got about 30 people now on the books. We started off with one and a half people in a garage six years ago. And I was very fortunate, I was working in a very senior position in government in a national security agency, and I was at an event like this in Melbourne, it was a bunch of financial planners and investors and I was presenting on investment fraud in my capacity of working for government. At the end of the conference we were milling about and I had an accountant from Sydney approached me, and he said, 'The tax office has just said that five of my clients have had their tax file numbers compromised, but they haven't told me anything about what I need to do about it.' And he was literally in tears, he was seeing his small business just slip through his fingers.

So I picked up the phone and I spoke to a colleague who heads up serious non-compliance at the tax office, he lives in Perth, and I spoke with another colleague who is a senior member of the Attorney General's Department. And I scribbled on the back of this conference agenda what was a response plan, and I rang this guy back and I said, 'Look, I've made a couple of enquiries, here's the five things that we recommend you do.' And his emotional state changed like that. And I thought why doesn't that exist? And at the time, by some miracle, all states and territories had agreed to this national identity security strategy, and one of the key pillars was a service that supports the community when this thing happens, and they knew the cupboard was bare, nothing had been done.

So I had a conversation, I said, 'Look, do you want me to explore whether we should set this up?' And they said, 'Sure Dave.' And so I did an 18-month feasibility study, spoke to community groups around the country, and what came away from that observation was: 1: it's real, it's en masse; 2: what people need is pragmatic support; and, 3: they don't want an IT geek, they want someone who could speak English and translate and can support them emotionally because it's quite a traumatic situation. So our counsellors say if you are not harmed by the crime, you most certainly will be by the response, that's the reality.

So the journey is very much a complex one, but it's one we had to make the decision early on; do we hire a bunch of IT people or do we hire a bunch of behaviouralists and then educate them in cyber and cyber forensics. And we went very much with the behaviouralists. And so they are an amazing team. And then the decision was, well, where do you put it? I said, well, I run a call centre, you may as well run it from the Sunshine Coast, so hence we moved from Canberra to the Sunshine Coast.

Robyn Williams: And if you think you've been zapped, where do you go? Who do you call first?

David Lacey: Well, most crooks are after your money, so it's not a bad idea having a chat to your financial institution in the first instance, but IDCARE is a free service and it's anonymous, we don't need to know who you are, in fact it's better we don't know who you are. We know we're a target. We've had attempts by foreign governments infiltrating IDCARE, and our natural defence is we don't know who you are, we know your first name and your post code, so if that's compromised, so what. If you come to IDCARE, you come early and we will give you that tailored response plan. Most of you probably haven't heard of it, but we get referrals from the Department of Human Services. So everyone in this room has a Medicare card, mostly. We get referrals from the tax office or from the police or from the major banks or from Telstra. So we are one or two degrees of separation from you, you just don't know it.

Robyn Williams: So much for that, and the third discussion is really going into the courtroom proper, and Dennis, when it comes to collecting the DNA and making sure we've got some sort of carriage, you don't just pick it up and put it in your pocket.

Dennis McNevin: DNA is ubiquitous, we all have it and we all shed it. And the problem is that there are many people who access a crime scene after the crime has occurred, and we have to make sure that the integrity of the DNA that has been collected from the crime scene isn't contaminated or polluted with other sources of DNA. So we have very rigorous procedures in place to try and guard against that sort of occurrence. You also have to remember that DNA collected at a crime scene could have been deposited before the crime was committed as well as after the crime is committed.

The other term that is used a lot in forensics and is very important is what we call 'chain of custody', accounting for the evidence from the time it's collected at the crime scene to the time it goes to court, who has had access to it, where has it been stored, under what conditions has it been stored. And we have to be able to demonstrate all of those things in court because they are frequent challenges, and for good reason. One of the worst things that could possibly happen in a DNA lab is that samples get mixed up, and I don't need to explain to you how that could lead to a grave...

Robyn Williams: Has that happened?

Dennis McNevin: Well, it has certainly been implied, yes. Modern forensic labs have very good, rigorous processes in place, but you can't be complacent because yes, it can be the difference between guilt and innocence and has a profound effect on someone's life.

Niamh Nic Daeid: One of the profoundly difficult areas of forensic science, and it's not just for DNA, it's for evidence in general, is about what we understand around the transfer of materials. So you're all sitting down on the chairs that you're sitting on, some of the fibres from your clothing will transfer to the chairs and you will pick up the fibres of clothing of people who've sat there before you, and what does that manifest itself like, and how long do those fibres persist after you get up and walk about?

And it's the same with DNA. If I shake Dennis's hand and then pick up my water bottle, then it's quite conceivable that I will transfer some of his DNA to an item he's never touched. And so it's the meaning of the trace in the context of a case that is really important. So that idea of transfer persistence or background abundance or how frequent things are is also something that is really, really important for us as forensic scientists to be able to understand and explain our evidence once we get into the courtroom.

Dennis McNevin: I mean, most of the challenges around DNA evidence these days are not around the science. The science is pretty well bedded down, it's how did it get there.

Robyn Williams: And Maiken, is your science also bedded down? You've been using pigs for a long time on your body farm to see how long things take to decay, and when you take an estimate from the bacon, does it match in court? If you said what the pig does and what the human does is kind of equivalent, does that stand up anymore?

Maiken Ueland: Pigs have been used because they have a similar internal anatomy, they have similar internal bacteria and they lack a heavy fur, which most humans do. There has always been these discussions on whether they decompose the same way that a human would, and we don't actually know. And there's some people that say if you want to figure out how a human decomposes, you have to use humans.

So when we opened AFTER in 2016, one of the very first studies that we did was to look at a comparison on visual changes between a human and pigs with the direct comparison between the two. And what we found in our unique environment is that human does not equal pig. They cannot really be used. And what we found was that the pigs go through the stages of decomposition in a very uniform manner. So the entire being would show one stage at a time, whereas the humans would go through something we call differential decomposition. That means that the way of determining times of death for a human is a little bit more complex because one part of the body will look a lot older than another part. It doesn't mean that you can't use pigs at all because humans can only be done at these very specialised facilities like AFTER, and it takes very specific ethic and legal requirements to use humans for research. But if you are going to use pigs you have to be very cautious and there needs to be some form of error that is being introduced in your time of death estimate.

Robyn Williams: And do you have many humans on your farm these days?

Maiken Ueland: We have 68 donors and we've been open for four years, so it's quite a substantial number, a lot more than what we predicted. We thought we'd maybe get 10 donors our first year, and we had 22. So it was a bit overwhelming, but it just shows the amazing support that we've had from the community and the massive support we've had from our donors.

Robyn Williams: And if I made an offer, would you have me?

Maiken Ueland: Of course!

Dennis McNevin: She'll sign you up on the spot.

Robyn Williams: Niamh, why was the 2009 US National Academy of Sciences report on forensics so important for you? And you mentioned Sue Black before, how is she involved?

Niamh Nic Daeid: It was a real watershed in forensic science history, not just in the US. And what the NAS Report, as it's called, essentially said is that there isn't really very much science behind them at all, so things like fingerprints, ballistics, matching bullets to guns, things like shoe prints or looking at the marks that your shoes make, tool-mark comparison, all of these comparative sciences had very little underpinning valid science to enable us to call them science in the first place. And that was quite shocking to many people. It was quite revealing. Since that time there has been a lot of research money released, particularly in the United States. We needed to make a change, we needed to try to look to see how are we going to input proper scientific work to underpin the forensic science evidence that is presented in the courts.

Fast-forward to 2016 and a further report came out from the US called the PCAST Report, and this report said you've had seven or eight years now to try to address the deficiencies you were told about in 2009, and you actually haven't addressed any of them, and in actual fact while there are some studies now looking at error rates in things like fingerprint comparison and there has been certainly advances in DNA technology, you still really haven't addressed these issues.

So when Sue and I worked together at the University of Dundee when I went over there, we said we need to try to do something about it, and we formulated a bit of a mad plan, and that plan was to bring forensic scientists into the same domain as all of the other people in the chain-the people who work at the crime scene, law enforcement, the scientists, the lawyers and the judges-and let's bring us all together to have an open, frank discussion for the first time about the challenges that forensic science faces and let's just lance the boil a little bit.

And so we did that and we had the most marvellous conversation in the Royal Society where they funded us to bring people from around the world together. And as a consequence of that conversation we were tasked with doing two things. One of the things was saying all of these challenges that we are now all agreeing forensic science faces, could the pair of you just fix that please, that would be great, fantastic. Okey-doke. And the other was we have a real issue and everybody here has said it, about how we communicate our science, and if we can't communicate it, then you can't understand what it is that we are trying to tell you because you, the public, are the people that actually make the decision, not us.

So Sue and I then went off and we wrote a grant proposal, there was a charitable trust called Leverhulme in the UK at the time and they had decided they wanted to fund centres for disruptive research, and we thought that sounds like us, so we're going to give that one a go. And we wrote a quite outrageous grant proposal into this trust, and we got shortlisted, much to our surprise, and what the trust did was they gave us an award of £10 million, so it's not small, for 10 years, so it's not a short timeframe, in order to go out and to disrupt the forensic science ecosystem.

And we bring people from around the world-Australia, America, other parts of the world-together with forensic scientists from those areas, together with some of the leading scientists in the field in an area we are interested in, together with the judges, and we bring all of these people together to say we have a problem and the problem is we don't understand, let's say transfer and persistence of DNA, how are we going to solve it? And we will sit there with all of these individuals, articulate the problem and start to work out a solution, and we use graphic artists to write the conversation for us. And these are the best communication tool I have ever come across because what we do in these conversations is if there's anybody sat around the groups that we work with-so judges, lawyers, scientists, forensic scientists, police officers-who are saying something that somebody else in the group doesn't understand, then they are allowed to play a 'blah, blah, blah' card, and you pick it up and you go...

Robyn Williams: Blah, blah, blah!

Niamh Nic Daeid: And it's great because what it tells you is it says 'I don't understand what you're saying to me', and the understanding in that piece of communication is so preciously important because if I can't understand you, we can't work together to solve the problem. And it's these simple things that make us stop, that are done with good humour and done with the right reasons that actually make us pause when we are trying to construct interdisciplinary research and really, really moves the conversation further forward. What we are able to do in two days of the strategic conversations is more than we've done in many, many, many years of trying in regards to solving issues in forensics science.

Robyn Williams: Maiken, imagine in your future at night, you've got two individuals in a car, and there's been something going on. What are the surprises that you might be looking out for?

Maiken Ueland: Well, we've spent years doing what we call baseline research. We've had our individuals in very standardised situations, so that we can see what happened in an as controlled environment as possible. We are in an outdoor scenario, so it's never going to be controlled as it would be in a laboratory, but as controlled as possible for us.

And then what we are doing now is we're moving more towards case-based scenarios, and we deal a lot with the police. I'm getting their advice on what kind of crimes they see regularly. And the situation there is looking at what happens in an enclosed environment. So when individuals are placed and sealed off, what happens to the decomposition rate there.

But one of the biggest findings we have had overall at the facility is that we see a process called mummification. And this is when the skin gets very dry and leathery and it slows down the decomposition. So where we expected based on the pig data and based on data from the US that the donors, for example, would become skeletonised, which is the endpoint after maybe a year, we are seeing that the decomposition rate is being slowed down and it takes a year-and-a-half to two years before we get to that skeletonisation. And this is having a massive impact on how we determine time since death. And we are also seeing this mummification very early on, which is very unexpected, and we see it year round. So we see it in all seasons, whereas mummification is something we always thought happened in very dry, hot environments, whereas in Sydney apparently it happens all the time. So now that we are moving on to these more case-based scenarios, we are learning more and more. And it has really shown us why we think these facilities are so important.

Robyn Williams: Let's now look at the future. And David, I don't want to tell you about some of the horror stories...well, the villains have now got quantum computers, but we'll come to that, that's something like a million times faster than ordinary computers.

David Lacey: Look, I think spoofing is going to continue on because I think technically the way a phone determines whether or not a phone number is spoofed or not isn't there at the moment, so the software application within your phone doesn't discern that it's not me calling you, it's someone else but it looks like it's me. So we think that is certainly predictably going to increase over the year.

We featured on Four Corners a few weeks ago in relation to romance scams and relationship scams, and 38 people, post that Monday episode, rang IDCARE and because of that episode said, 'I now realise it's a scam.' I think if anything in the environment, the more that you have that conversation at home and with your friends, the better and more resilient we will be as a community. So if that is any litmus as to how many other people are out there experiencing these things that currently don't know, then that's I think a really important take-away, is to have those conversations.

We've got a lot of young people who are getting jobs for the first time, they sit around the dinner table at night, the parents ask them, 'How was the first day at work?' And they say, 'I just did some transactions.' And mum and dad will go, 'Tell us about that.' 'I got money into my account, I withdrew it, I had to buy some bitcoin and then I sent it overseas.' And the next thing you know they are laundering money on behalf of organised crime. That's detected first because of that conversation at home. Investment fraud works because somebody is alone and they've got a superannuation balance and they want to invest. That's a conversation that also needs to be had with family and friends. That's how we can really disrupt the criminals, is by ensuring that we are having those conversations. The crooks will always leverage technology. Our challenge is how that technology can present evidence that can give a court confidence that this is the particular outcome or result that has occurred.

Robyn Williams: So Dennis, finally, what are your concerns about the issues for the future in DNA forensic work?

Dennis McNevin: I think most of the issues are going to revolve around genetic privacy. As more and more of the genome is revealed in the course of forensic and medical investigations, then more and more information about us is going to be made available. I'll paint a sort of picture of where I think the field of biometrics is going, all the things about our biology that make us who we are. So you can imagine that DNA is collected at a crime scene, you might search a database, find no hits, no matches, that DNA could then be used to predict your fingerprints, there is evidence to suggest that's possible. That means that we can then search a fingerprint database, so we can cross-interrogate databases.

We then find no fingerprint match, so then we go the next step and we produce a molecular photofit of that person's face. Again, there is evidence to suggest that that may one day be possible. Those facial characteristics could be uploaded to border crossings through the country so that if our offender tries to leave the country, their face might appear on CCTV, the facial metrics from the CCTV image could automatically match the DNA image that is predicted from DNA. That person could be pulled aside, questioned, a DNA sample taken, a cheek swab taken and then matched or not to the crime scene evidence. Some people might think that's a good thing, some people might think that's a dystopian future.

One of the very interesting developments in DNA is the use of genealogy databases in the US to solve crimes. Police are now submitting DNA to these companies, and perhaps some of you in the audience have used companies like 23AndMe or Ancestry.com. Well, there's another company called Family Tree DNA who do a similar thing and they have now announced that they are going to work with law enforcement to enable law enforcement to access their records so that DNA at a crime scene can be used to find putative relatives of the offender. And then family trees can be constructed in these genealogical databases to identify cousins or genetic relatives of the offender, to narrow a pool of suspects.

David Lacey: For us the challenge is multiple. One is the object changes every day. So it's not a body or it's not DNA. Every day there is a new technology in the marketplace, and the most recent I guess pre-trial report that I was involved with last week was the alleged perpetrator had breached a domestic violence order, and the allegation was that they had sent text messages to the complainant, and that was in contravention of that order. They were recommending that it wasn't them, their number had been spoofed.

So spoofing is where I call you and your caller ID looks as though it's something when in fact it's not. So we are seeing that as a general trend across the community at the moment where banks or MyGov or the tax office, the criminals are spoofing those numbers, so you are receiving a text message, it's entering the legitimate historical string of your messages, but it actually is being sent by a criminal. So that is now starting to escalate. It was occurring in North America over the last few years and now we are starting to see it-surprise, surprise-in Australia.

So in this particular context if the allegation is that there has been a breach of a domestic violence order through communication and then the defendant is saying, 'I'm sorry, my number was spoofed,' what we look for there is, well, what's the point of truth? In communications, telcos, if they do one thing right, it's billing. So the bill is often a very good point, looking at a call charge record, which is then used for the billing purpose, as to whether or not that transaction, that communication was evident in the call charge record. And in this particular case it was evident and evident in spades. And there's another attributes around that communication as well. So every mobile phone has unique identifiers, so not just your number but the device itself, and a call charge record is you're able to look at what type of communication was it, when was it sent, over what duration, to what receiver or who was the originator, who was the receiver or terminator, and the relevant mobile identifier. And so it was quite evident, it was quite probable that in fact the phone number wasn't spoofed.

Niamh Nic Daeid: And another aspect is what we're going to do at the crime scene of the future. We've talked about a digital crime scene, but also can we use digital tools like virtual reality or augmented reality to help us understand and investigate crime scenes in the future. And I think the other really key and critical area for me as we move further forward and there's two, one is around digital evidence. Digital evidence is going to be massive in our futures. We've heard about cybersecurity and how to keep ourselves safe, but what are we going to do with the vast amounts of evidence that are coming from mobile phones, from other digital devices, and how are our courts going to cope with that. So we are working with law enforcement and the judges and trying to work out just a strategy for how do we do that and how do we do it correctly and properly.

And then the last one is how are we going to teach the scientists to communicate, because that's the last really important piece, is to turn forensic scientists into forensic science communicators because they absolutely have to be able to communicate to you who have to make the decision about guilt or innocence and we have to be able to empower you to be able to make that decision effectively.

Robyn Williams: How are you doing that, are you bringing people like Amelia Fox or Alan Alda?

Niamh Nic Daeid: Not so much Amelia Fox. Alan Alda, yes actually. So we work with the Alan Alda Centre for Science Communication in Stony Brook in New York. We have a grant with them now also, and they have come and trained all of our team in science communication, so all of our PhD students, all of our postdocs, all of our staff are trained science communicators, and we pass that information out, we work with all of the science centres in the region, with the schools, in that region and beyond. So we work very closely with Alan.

Robyn Williams: He loves science. Very keen.

Niamh Nic Daeid: He does, he's fantastic, he's absolutely lovely, a really good supporter of this kind of work.

Robyn Williams: Whatever you think of Amelia Fox, so many people in the theatre and in television, the actors really do investigate some of the ideas and some of the science, which is...

Niamh Nic Daeid: Yes, when we work with Val, so I work with her from time to time on her books, and she is an author that puts a huge amount of effort into getting the science right, as many of them do. But at the end of the day, getting the science right and showing the meticulous nature of it is not going to fit into 45 minutes of a Silent Witness episode.

Robyn Williams: A final thought, I'd like you all to comment briefly in about two-and-a-half minutes. One of the things that you're illustrating is, one of my favourite words, consilience. And William Whewell, who first named the first person, who was a woman, to be called a scientist, way back, also loved consilience because what it does is takes many, many lines of evidence to find out whether something is true or not, as much as you can, no absolute truth, but...if you have 20 or 30 lines of evidence, you're pretty damn sure they are...you know, in climate science, this is what they are doing, you're measuring the temperature, you're looking at the chemistry of the atmosphere, you're looking at the way that animals change and go away, things decay, all those things together make you pretty damn sure that something is going on. So would you say that consilience is what you guys are all about?

Niamh Nic Daeid: I think that what you're saying is a really interesting suggestion, but we have to put it into the frame of the crime scene to court process. When you get to the courtroom, forensic science, the scientific part is a small part of a big chain, but we are actually quite a circumstantial part of it. And so within that little part there all of the little bits and pieces that make up the scientific block of evidence. I agree with what you're saying, so long as each of those individual parts are themselves scientific.

Dennis McNevin: I hark back to what I said before. I mean, there are no certainties. We are operating in a realm of uncertainty and that's the court, it has to decipher all the evidence that is put forward and put together a complex jigsaw puzzle where each piece has an element of uncertainty to it, and then you've got to come up with a conclusion based on all of those clues that are put together.

To carry on from what Niamh was saying and what you were suggesting...what's the term you used, 'consilience'? That's a word I'm going to put in my dictionary. There was a famous case in Australia of Farah Jama who was convicted of a crime that he didn't commit in Victoria here in Australia, based on DNA evidence alone. So this guy was convicted of rape based on a vaginal swab that had his DNA on it. Now, we haven't got time today to explain how that occurred but it didn't occur because he raped that woman, it occurred because of a very unlikely chain of events that could never have been predicted. But because the audience saw the DNA evidence, they said 'we don't need to know anything else' and they ignored all the other circumstantial evidence that was exculpatory. It was only the DNA that was inculpatory. You're working in a complex environment with many uncertainties.

David Lacey: Yes, 99.9999% of cybercrime never ends up in court, and the reason why that's the case is that criminals are mostly overseas. So where cyber forensics plays its role is to know that, that's where the threat is originating from, and determine how did they do it so that we can then look for measures and countermeasures to defeat it in the future. So it's a very broad church, cyber forensics, and the roles that it can play.

Where it's a domestic incident, where it is that 0.00001% of cases, absolutely, the crime scene of the future is the culmination of all of these disciplines. But as was said before, it's a small sliver of what is actually presented in court.

Robyn Williams: There you are, that's the future. Be very, very scared, but safe at the same time. Would you please thank the panel? Thank you.

We were at the World Science Festival in Brisbane with Professor Dennis McNevin, and Dr Maiken Ueland from University of Technology in Sydney, Professor Niamh Nic Daeid from the University of Dundee in Scotland, and Professor David Lacey from the Inaugural Chair of Cybersecurity at the University of Sunshine Coast in Queensland.

Next week in TheScience Show meet famed Professor Mike Archer from University of New South Wales who discusses the astonishing attempts to resurrect the Tasmanian Tiger and the remarkable gastric brooding frog.

Production by David Fisher and Emrys Cronin. I'm Robyn Williams. And please, have a safe Christmas.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NJR0-TXN5-S1PJ-00000-00Bird's eye view of a raging, rolling monster1998-02-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 2Bird's eye view of a raging, rolling monsterJOHN ELDER

From our vantage point in the air, the burning forest fire resembles a bloated fish, with its tail flapping against the town of Macedon.

The back is edging its way towards the Calder Freeway, about three kilometres away. Between the freeway and the burning forest there are small farms with not much growing and everything dry and ready to flare.

The belly of the fire has wandered across the railway line, is in the town and within reach of houses. It is being thumped to death.

It's about 2pm and the fire is clinging to the feet of Mount Macedon, between the eastern and western spurs.

You can smell the smoke up here, but it's not thick at 2900 feet. It stays low, coming out of every part of the blackened fish-forest like steam. It is white; dirty in parts where the flames have found finer fuel.

The smoke is heavy and white at the nose of the fire, on the north-western point. The wind is coming from this direction and all the smoke rolls into itself, feeding itself and choking the town. East of Macedon it spreads over grass plains to Gisborne, to Sunbury.

There are large ponds at the head and tail of the fire. Three water-bomber helicopters are doing a grasshopper ballet, into the ponds to fill with water and springing back into the air.

You hear them on the radio, talking about the bombing runs over the western flank. You see the helicopter following the burning perimeter.

You hear: "OK, I'm dropping the water now."

And then, after coming up from the smoke: "Did I get it?"

"Nice one," is the reply.

"Was it a bit late, Mike?"

"Yeah, but it was effective."

It goes on like this through the hour.

A Dromeder plane arrives to drop foam. Two helicopters are parked on the Macedon football field. There is no crowd watching.

Half the town has been closed. Police cars are parked across the street. Other streets are moving. You see cars on front lawns. People in their pools. A man is climbing on to the roof of his house to see what he can see. He's wearing red underpants and thongs.

Meanwhile, the radio has been talking about the western flank. "The whole western flank is a time-bomb . . . but we're not doing too bad," says someone I recognise as Mike.

The helicopters keep bombing the western flank.

The talk turns to food. One pilot wants to know if it has arrived. "We've been waiting for the refreshments to come out and . . ."

There is a brief bitch about air-attack firefighters always being forgotten.

Then the pilot says: "Seeing there's no food . . ."

And he goes back to the pond.

Photo: Dousing the flames: Fires at Mount Macedon yesterday are water-bombed by helicopter. Picture: PAT SCALA; Map: Close call.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H3J0-TXN5-R196-00000-00So this is Christmas ...2001-12-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 1So this is Christmas ...Lee Glendinning, Malcolm Brown, Linda Doherty and Daniel Lewis

Christmas dinners were abandoned on tables and decorations deserted to the ravages of wind and flames.

From the south to north coast, Canberra to the Hunter Valley, and the central west to Sydney, tens of thousands of people experienced Christmas Day in varying degrees of terror, despair, stoicism and frequent bravery.

Fire engines, adorned with tinsel and Merry Christmas signs, screamed down streets of Mulgoa, near Penrith. When they arrived at Les Torrensan's house in Mulgoa Road, he was close to tears. The fire, spreading from adjoining bush, ruined hectare upon hectare of crops on his property.

"There's 15 years of work and vegetation just ruined," he said. "I could see it all just jumping the road, just a law unto itself."

The middle of a new house he was building on the property caught alight, but he managed to douse the flames. "I was meant to be going to a Christmas party today," he sighed. "But I just can't leave not now."

In the lower Blue Mountains, Hala Swallow and husband Ian had watched a fire since it started as a whiff of smoke at a local swimming hole, Blue Pool, in Glenbrook Creek on Monday. Despite water bombing by helicopters, the fire kept coming and early yesterday afternoon they decided to evacuate. Ms Swallow called out: "Oh, Ian, we have left a big ham in the fridge."

He called back: "Well, it will be well done when we get back. Get in the vehicle."

Many fled with them as flames threatened thousands of homes and closed roads and rail lines.

Martyn Hurley, living near the railway line at Glenbrook, had the fire sweep through on Monday and yesterday went looking for his two pet goats. He found one, so badly burnt it could not stand on its hoofs.

Fires ravaged lookouts and destroyed tractors and a National Parks and Wildlife Service depot at Glenbrook. Jon Jackson, of Warrimoo in the Blue Mountains, suffered burns to the back from flying cinders after he left his Christmas dinner to run with a hose and buckets to help.

In Canberra, police drove through streets with loud hailers, warning western suburbs residents to prepare for evacuation when a forest fire at Stromlo threatened to spread. It was later contained.

The Governor-General, Peter Hollingworth, thanked firefighters for saving Government House at Yarralumla, after flames went within 200 metres of its boundaries on Monday. "I'd particularly like to ... express our appreciation to the emergency service, to the firefighters who've had to do a typically Australian thing, and that is work on Christmas Day to contain these fires that are all around."

Back at Mulgoa, Fred Grotto kept watch on his tractor as flames came within metres of two diesel fuel tanks. He would not leave his property. "It's a nice Christmas, isn't it?" he said.

Across the road, Mark Harrold was out the front of his property, his clothes and faces covered in ash. In his left hand he cradled a tiny possum, burnt and barely alive. "I've just found this on the road and I want to try to help it ... Our house is in danger and we don't know how close it will come but the best we can do is stay out here fighting."

urn:contentItem:4P6W-1DF0-TXN5-R2YY-00000-00Amid war and more, he's in perfect form2002-03-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisMETROPOLITANPg. 17Amid war and more, he's in perfect formADELAIDE WRITERS' WEEKSusan Wyndham

As Sebastian Junger waited to join the Northern Alliance attack on Kabul, he wrote in his notebook: "I don't know if I can explain how little I want to do this."

Covering the Afghan war for American media, the best-selling author of The Perfect Storm was under heavy shellfire, shrapnel had whistled by his photographer's ear, an AP reporter had been shot nearby and three journalists had just been killed in the

mountains.

Nevertheless, when the Northern Alliance rolled into the capital, Junger and his crew drove in behind the second tank.

One of the finest writers of what has been called "disaster chic", Junger has a knack for being at the centre of world dramas.

The former tree-seller, whose first book sold about 3 million copies and became a glamorised Hollywood movie starring George Clooney, has been transformed since September 11 into a sought-after expert on the politics of the Muslim world.

On the US presence in Afghanistan, he says: "I thought we acted with tremendous wisdom and strength, even the citizens of Kabul applauded the military action; the loss of citizens troubled the far-Left in America far more than the Afghan people.

"I have never been in a Muslim country where I felt resented as an American I have been received with more hospitality and kindness than in Ohio."

Published with exquisite good timing last September, Junger's latest book, Fire, is a decade's collection of journalism about hotspots ranging from a forest fire in Idaho to the killing fields of Kosovo and Sierra Leone and finishes with a piece on Northern Alliance leader Ahmad Shah Massoud before he was assassinated.

"Since his death or his martyrdom, as the Afghans see it he and his vision of a free and democratic country have been enshrined in the Afghan psyche," says Junger.

At Adelaide Writers' Week, Junger might just have parachuted out of Black Hawk Down in his khaki pants and black T-shirt over a body as lean and disciplined as his prose.

While other writers escaped from the heat of the day into a chilled glass, Junger was out running. He has always disliked comfort.

His fascination with dangerous work took him out of a middle-class Massachusetts upbringing and anthropology studies to a job felling trees, where he almost severed his foot.

From there he learned at a local port about a fishing boat that had sunk in violent weather and reconstructed the tragedy in forensic detail in The Perfect Storm.

He speaks with excitement now about changes in the world, such as the trial of former Yugoslav president Slobodan Milosevic.

"The massacres in Bosnia and the ethnic hatred there were much worse than in Afghanistan, but the West is blind to Western problems."

Before coming to Australia, Junger was back in Kosovo writing about the trafficking of women through brothels.

He will keep reporting on the relationship between Islam and the West, "the most important story in the world", but when he returns to New York he has to make time to begin a new book "non-fiction but it's not about war or the sea. It's very different for me".

Sebastian Junger will speak at a Herald/Dymocks Literary Lunch tomorrow. Bookings: 94494366.

ILLUS: Afghan hospitality ... Sebastian Junger. Photo: Bryan Charlton

urn:contentItem:451D-4W80-015G-T15J-00000-00<published>2002-01-30T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>HOME ENTERTAINMENT GUIDE; Pg. H07</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>In the hunt</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>David James</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">After a slow start, CSI may prove to be a sleeping giant, writes David James</p><p nitf:lede="true">S EEN as a promising concept spoiled by some muddled storytelling, it was a slow beginning for the Las Vegas-based CSI team last year.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But over the season it built a solid core of supporters both here and in the US.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The second series of CSI: Crime Scene Investigation has found its feet, however, and is one of the hit drama series of the present US season, consistently in the top five, with heavyweights ER and Friends.</p><p>"It's the crimes," says star William Petersen, as to why the show has taken off this year.</p><p> "As long as people keep doing this s . . t, we're still going to be in business."</p><p> Petersen stars as CSI team leader Gil Grissom and included in the s . . t his squad has to deal with this year is a case where the corpse of a scuba diver is discovered in a tree during a forest fire, and another where a dead body has been reduced to liquid.</p><p> The team's coolest new tool is a hi-tech supersniffer known as an electronic nose.</p><p> "We use it in a case where there's a murder in a boys' bathroom and the sniffer thing picks up an aroma of something that shouldn't be in a boys' bathroom," Petersen's co-star Marg Helgenberger says.</p><p> "But what we're all wondering is if Grissom gets a little love in his life this season.</p><p> Petersen chuckles as he responds: "Gil has a life -- he goes to work. Frankly, it's very similar to my life. I can't have a girlfriend either."</p><p> Helgenberger, who plays former one-time Vegas stripper turned forensic scientist Catherine Willows, sees Catherine as working twice as hard as anyone else to prove she has got the legit crime-solving goods.</p><p> Known in Hollywood for her forthright nature, Helgenberger recalls making headlines in Tinsel Town when she "bad-mouthed" producer Jerry Bruckheimer's movie Bad Boys, in which she featured.</p><p> "Jerry, naturally, wasn't impressed," she says.</p><p> "The problem was, when CSI came up, I discovered it was Jerry's series and he was in charge of who got the gig as Catherine.</p><p> "Thank God he's a forgiving man.</p><p> "The truth is, anybody who works in television and then complains about their creativity being thwarted should be taken out and drop-kicked."</p><p> Born Mary Helgenberger in North Bend, Nebraska, the 42-year-old actor was educated at Kearney State College and Northwestern University.</p><p> Teenage pocketmoney was earned working in a meat-packing plant.</p><p> "But acting was where I was at and I finally got my chance," says Helgenberger, who most recently was seen on the big screen in Julia Robert's Erin Brockovich.</p><p> "It's given me the best and worst things of my life.</p><p> "The best was, obviously, landing a role in a hit series like this and being a part of Erin. The great career low, however, was having to sit through Species II.</p><p> "Hopefully there's a few more seasons left in CSI and we can all live happily ever after. All I know is at the moment I'm having a hell of a lot of fun."</p><p>CSI: Crime Scene Investigation returns to Channel 9, Tuesday, 8.30pm.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P6W-1CJ0-TXN5-R20N-00000-00Column 82002-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESColumn 8Pg. 16Column 8

All sorts of people live in the Blue Mountains. Geoff Bates, of the Katoomba Scenic Railway, was at the Wentworth Falls fires speaking to a fireman the other day. When Elvis water-bombed the blaze, the fireman said, there were 15 phone calls of complaints from residents about the helicopter's noise.

A crew of four firefighters from Mt Tomah was sent to Lake Burragorang to help clear firebreaks. Bill Johns, of Mt Tomah, says: "The lake is laden with huge carp, up to a metre long. Suddenly a volcano of fire erupted on the top of the escarpment above the crew. Out of the blue arrived Elvis. As he swooped over to drop another load of water, one of the crew, Col, looked up and said, `I wonder what would happen if Elvis sucked up a carp? The headline would be Firefighter killed by falling carp. He would have carped it."'

"We're really into water conservation on the far North Coast," reports Anne Hay, of Golden Beach. "The Northern Star reported that a fire, threatening Brooms Head Caravan Park, was contained `after around 30 drops of water' from the Westpac helicopter."

Which brings us to the old, old Bushfire Urban Myth. A reader, Karry, says she found some old clippings from a San Francisco newspaper that told this story:Fire authorities in California found a corpse in a burnt-out section of forest while assessing the damage done by a forest fire. The deceased male was dressed in a full wetsuit, complete with dive tank, flippers and facemask. A post-mortem revealed that the person died, not from burns, but from massive internal injuries. On the day of the fire, the person went for a diving trip off the coast, some 35km away from the forest. The firefighters called in a fleet of helicopters with very large buckets. The buckets were dropped into the ocean for rapid filling ...

It had to happen . Don Christian reports: "Our local retirement village, a wonderful complex known as Fingal Haven, has an ornate front entrance with Fingal Haven mounted on a rock wall or it did have. Some local wit or vandal, depending upon your view, removed the G, leaving what some would judge to be the appropriate name."

A reader , so ashamed to have spent so much time with a calculator that he/she wishes to be anonymous, has taken issue with Yet Another Paper at the weekend. It said that repainting of the Eiffel Tower "began last month for the 18th time in its history. It will take 25 workers two years to cover the monument in 50,000 tonnes of lead-free brown paint". Says our calculating reader: "Assuming a six-day week with no weather breaks or holidays, that's about three and a bit tonnes per worker per day!" That work ethic is what has made France great.

We forgive Bruce Moore, now in Kathmandu and without his library to consult, who thought it was Sir Humphrey who gave the definitions of MBE, OBE, etc (Column 8, yesterday). As readers have told us, it was his private secretary, Bernard.
