urn:contentItem:57FX-0NH1-F0JP-W03H-00000-00State blazes as homes destroyed Pair seek refuge in dam2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4State blazes as homes destroyed Pair seek refuge in damAnthony Dowsley, Jon Kaila, Andy Burns and Angus Thompson, with AAP

FIREFIGHTERS and police will this morning assess the full extent of the damage caused by a grassfire that burned through 1100ha in central Victoria last night, destroying up to 20 homes.

The fire swept through the Chepstowe area, 30km west of Ballarat, about 6pm, destroying bushland and homes.

Four people were taken to hospital suffering smoke inhalation, while a father and son suffered minor burns as they fled the fire and took refuge in a dam.

The fast-moving fire, one of 13 burning across Victoria last night, was fanned by south-westerly winds.

Firefighters, supported by air water-bombers, battled the out-of-control blaze as it charged Lake Burrumbeet just after 4pm yesterday.

Water bombing aircraft, including the aircrane Gypsy Lady, were called to help firefighters quell the blaze.

Ray Allen and his son were lucky to escape with their lives after they were forced to abandon their car and run to a dam.

The pair suffered minor radiant heat burns to their faces and the exposed skin on their arms and were taken to the Ballarat Base Hospital.

Adding to the anxiety, the CFA website was inundated as people logged in seeking information.

Late last night, Carngham was under threat with CFA sources confirming the historic million-dollar horse-breeding property, Carngham Station, had been razed.

The station's live-in gardener, Ron Bolton, said the embers that started raining on the property quickly started an inferno.

``The CFA was actually on the grounds at the time, but they couldn't do anything to save it. It was just too hot,'' Mr Bolton said. ``The house I live in is still intact, but it's the only building left on the property.''

More than 200 cattle have been destroyed, and it is believed farmland had been burned.

Resident Noel Hayes said six or seven houses up the road from him had been destroyed, although this had not been confirmed by authorities.

His home was spared thanks to a twist of fate with the wind. ``The worst is past us now, the wind wasn't blowing our way, thank God,'' Mr Hayes said.

John Fraser said the fire came within 500m of his home.

``We have three homesteads and all the girls and kids were in there but the police came and got them out,'' Mr Fraser said.

``Usually we look for fires from the north-west but this one came through the back door -- we were so worried.''

Several families stayed to defend their properties but were solemn-faced when leaving through the checkpoint.

One local said it was ``devastating'' that people had lost their homes.

John Runnalls, licensee at the Burrumbeet Hotel, said despite large amounts of smoke in the area the town was protected from the main Chepstowe blaze by a lake.

Ann Searle, owner at the Snake Valley General Store, said they were waiting on instructions from the CFA whether to evacuate last night. People at the Lake Burrumbeet caravan park were warned by police to prepare for ember attack.

Another fast-moving bushfire near the Victorian town of Goroke was also causing alarm.

In NSW, firefighters were last night battling 140 blazes but the state escaped the catastrophe that had been feared. Thirty fires were uncontrolled..

Three boys arrested yesterday are suspected of starting a fire about 200m from homes in Sydney's west in 42-degree heat.

Firefighters are focusing on emergency situations in nine areas of NSW, Victoria and Tasmania as hot, dry and windy conditions envelop southeast Australia.

The worst-hit area in NSW was in the state's south, where temperatures hit the low 40s with winds of up to 90km/h.

Victoria's CFA will send 20 firefighters and an aircrane to help the effort in NSW, allowing its Rural Fire Service crews to move to northern fires.

A cool change was making its way across the state, but similar hot and windy conditions were expected later in the week.

In Tasmania, residents and tourists stranded on the Tasman Peninsula for five days have been led out of the devastating bushfire zone as fire crews continue to battle established and new blazes across the state.

There were 43 fires burning across Tasmania last night, five of which posed major threats.

The Bureau of Meteorology yesterday confirmed Monday was Australia's hottest day ever, with a national average maximum temperature of 40.33 degrees.

However the record is likely to last just 24 hours.

A high fire danger remains for Victoria today.

FIRE RATING ACROSS VICTORIA

Today: High, no bans.

Tomorrow: Rising to very high in north-central, southwest and northeast.

Friday: Severe across state, very high in east.

Saturday: Very high in the Mallee, northeast and north-central.

NT

Scores of guests yesterday evacuated the Kings Canyon Resort in central Australia, 300km from Alice Springs, as a bushfire burned through the site.

QUEENSLAND

Eight bushfires burning across Queensland with fire authorities on high alert with extremely hot weather about to hit the state.

NSW

More than 1200 firefighters backed by about 350 trucks and 63 aircraft were tackling fires across the state.

By yesterday afternoon more than 54,000ha had burned, with 130 fires burning, 40 of them uncontained.

The major fires were at Deans Gap, near Nowra, with 15ha burning, and Tarcutta, near Wagga, with 500ha in flames. Victorian firefighters were expected to help fight a massive blaze at Kybeyan, near Cooma.

ACT

A forest fire is burning in the ACT's south in Namadgi National Park. It is under control but worse conditions are forecast.

SOUTH AUSTRALIA

A string of bushfires continue to burn across northern South Australia, most in remote areas.

TASMANIA

Fires have destroyed at least 128 homes, mainly on the Tasman Peninsula. The damage to private property is estimated to be at least $42 million, but that figure is set to rise dramatically.

Forty fires continue to burn, with bushfire emergency warning issued yesterday for Montumana in the northwest.

VICTORIA

Homes were lost in Snake Gully and neighbouring Chepstowe, about 30km from Ballarat, with many more under threat.

At Kentbruck, in the southwest, a 9000ha fire was pushing towards Dartmoor.

A 500ha bushfire in the Wimmera was threatening several towns.

A grassfire burned 8ha at Sunbury.

urn:contentItem:44K8-YHB0-0197-851G-00000-00<published>2000-01-12T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LOCAL; Pg. 27</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firefighters' risk / System too old, CSIRO warns</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>SIMON BENSON</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BUSHFIRE fighters across NSW are putting their lives and those of others at risk by relying on 30-year-old fire behaviour models.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Scientists have found the models are inaccurate and potentially dangerous.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The CSIRO has issued a warning to all bushfire services in eastern States, claiming they were at risk if they continued to rely on their "fire-spread prediction tables" developed in the 1960s.</p><p>Research conducted by CSIRO's division of forestry has found that the old models under-estimated the speed at which fires spread by up to three times. It also under-</p><p>estimated the speed at which fires can develop and how they behave under different wind speeds.</p><p> This means firefighters are putting themselves in more danger than they realised every time they confront fires.</p><p> The research also applies to hazard reduction burning and back-burning (small fires deliberately lit in front of the main bushfire line to starve the fire of fuel).</p><p> The CSIRO division of forestry and forest products is midway through a four-year $6 million research study, named project Vesta, into the behaviour of forest and grass fires.</p><p> Bushfire services still rely on fire behaviour models -- developed by fire researcher Alan McArthur -- when planning how to combat a fire situation.</p><p> "What we have found is that fires accelerate more rapidly than we thought and it only takes a couple of minutes for it to happen," CSIRO research scientist Jim Gould said. "We hope to have a good prediction system within two years and we felt it was important to tell [bushfire services] of the weaknesses in the system and help them. They often put themselves in risky situations.</p><p> "It would be hard to say if past deaths could be directly related to the inaccuracies … there are too many factors involved. This type of research is for public good. This is one of the largest undertakings in fire science."</p><p> The CSIRO provides the information as a public service and does not gain commercially from any agency adopting its new modelling.</p><p> It will continue to update bushfire services to changing information.</p><p> "We are developing new equations which reflect a new relationship between wind and fire now that it is better understood," said Dr Gould.</p><p> A spokesperson for the Rural Fire Service said the findings were significant.</p><p> "They more or less confirm the strategies already adopted by the Rural Fire Service," the spokesperson said. "We were expecting results more or less along these lines and we have incorporated them in our training."</p><p> The research has found that a linear relationship exists between fire spread and wind up to 15km/h. However, the most dangerous aspect for firefighters is the discovery that over and above this wind speed, fire spread becomes far more rapid.</p><p> Dr Gould said there was a high potential for grass fires by the end of February and if the wet weather eases, forest fire danger could become very high due to the availability of fuel.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8B-R8P0-TXN5-V1DW-00000-00Carr lauds `fireman' Sam2001-12-31T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Carr lauds `fireman' SamHELENSBURGH THE REGION ABLAZEDANIELLE WOOLAGE

When NSW Premier Bob Carr yesterday hailed Helensburgh resident Sam Blackwell a hero, the council worker was lost for words.

"I don't know what to say. I don't think I am a hero. I just did what any neighbour would do," Mr Blackwell said.

The 62-year-old, who lives on the corner of Laurina Ave and Blackwell St, refused to leave his home despite three attempts by police to evacuate him when a firestorm ripped through the street.

As thousands of Helensburgh residents fled the inferno, Mr Blackwell, and former Rural Fire Service volunteer George Abrahams stayed put.

"I wasn't going anywhere," Mr Blackwell said.

"I told them the only way they would get me out was in a body bag.

"I was in the Darkes Forest fire in 1968 so I have had a bit of experience with this sort of thing."

Their brave stance in the face of a raging inferno saved nine of the 11 homes in the street.

The pair also released three trapped dogs from burning homes.

Armed with a garden hose, a water can backpack, a red hard hat and a torch, Mr Blackwell attacked spot fires on one side of the street, while Mr Abrahams used a garden hose to extinguish flames across the road.

Mr Abrahams, who was forced to take cover in his car as the firefront engulfed the street, described it as a scene from a Star Wars movie.

"All these embers were just flying towards me," he said.

"I would be lying if I said I wasn't scared. But we proved that if you have your wits about you, you don't endanger your life and you stay with your house, you can save it."

Mr Carr, who cut short a holiday to China to visit areas devastated by the State's bushfires, lauded the efforts of Mr Blackwell and Mr Abrahams yesterday.

"You are one of the heroes of this episode," he told Mr Blackwell.

Mr Carr was shocked by the trail of destruction left by the fire that ruined 10 homes in Helensburgh.

"It is tragic to see all these lost homes and all that they represent in terms of a family's hopes, sacrifices and aspirations," he said.

But despite the Premier's praise, both men have rejected the hero status conferred upon them.

"There is no such thing as a hero; we just do what we can to save our homes and our neighbours' homes," Mr Abrahams said.

Fortunately both men escaped the inferno reasonably unscathed.

"I felt a bit of a burning sensation on my backside when I was putting out my garage," Mr Blackwell said.

"My handkerchief had caught alight in my back pocket and singed my bum," he said.

"We let a few dogs out that were locked in some of the houses that burned down, and they got a bit of a singed behind too."

Two illus: BRAVE STANCE: NSW Premier Bob Carr hailed Sam Blackwell a hero yesterday. Mr Blackwell and neighbour George Abrahams saved nine of the 11 homes in Laurina Ave, Helensburgh. Pictures: KIRK GILMOUR MEETING TOWNSFOLK: NSW Premier Bob Carr talks with George Abrahams and other Laurina Ave residents Kevin Keane and his daughter Lauren Keane at Helensburgh yesterday.

urn:contentItem:4SVM-0G40-TXN5-S1NB-00000-00Poignant portrayal of a leader's dilemma2008-06-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisSPECTRUMBooksPg. 36Poignant portrayal of a leader's dilemmaNONFICTIONReviewed by Claire Scobie

The Open Road

By Pico Iyer

Bloomsbury, 288pp, $32.95

PICO IYER'S first impressions of the Dalai Lama are hazy. He was a disinterested schoolboy when his father insisted that they pay a visit to the deposed leader's home in Dharamasala. What stayed with Iyer, then 17, was a vision of swirling mist rather than the Tibetan monk's conversations on emptiness and reality. That was in 1974 and ever since Iyer has followed the Dalai Lama's passage "down from the mountaintop".

The Open Road is an account of this enduring friendship. As Iyer travels with Tenzin Gyatso, he explores how exile can bring opportunity. Even though the Dalai Lama still travels on the yellow identity card of a refugee, he views loss as transformative. For Iyer - who lost all his possessions, including eight years' worth of books, in a forest fire in Santa Barbara in 1990 - this is deeply instructive.

Pico Iyer, essayist, journalist and accomplished travel writer, portrays the Dalai Lama from three angles - in public, private and in practice. On the international stage, Iyer watches how Westerners project their dreams on to him. In part, because Tibet wears "the contours of a fairy tale"; in part, our need for the Dalai Lama to be "an emissary from some other world that doesn't exist".

Yet, the Nobel Peace Prize winner couldn't be more down to earth. He's not in the business of peddling the view that compassion falls from the heavens. It takes hard work. The Dalai Lama starts his meditation at 4.30am every day - and can do it while listening to the BBC World Service.

Iyer notices that the Dalai Lama is frequently dismissed when he speaks in English and is ignored when he talks philosophically. (Most people refer to his "presence and warmth".) He recounts how one Canadian journalist described the Tibetan leader, "as not exactly the brightest bulb in the room". Deliberately, Iyer believes, the Dalai Lama has spent the past two decades compressing millennia of Buddhist teaching into a modern doctrine of simple human ethics. But his "everyday humanity" comes at a cost. No one would dare ask the Pope if "he has dreams of women", yet the doctor of metaphysics is seen as fair game for any question.

So it's startling to be reminded that Tenzin Gyatso is still a student. In a telling detail Iyer recounts how, when the photographer Manuel Bauer, who spent more than three years photographing the Dalai Lama - in meditation, weeping, watching TV bare-chested - showed him the photos to check none violated his privacy, his subject questioned only one picture. It seemed to show, because of the perspective, that he was sitting higher than one of his teachers.

Such vignettes give this intimate and insightful portrayal of one of the world's iconic leaders great warmth. Iyer succeeds in de-cloaking the Dalai Lama, showing his many faces and, as with his other travelogues, does so with an excellent eye for detail. His descriptions of Dharamasala, a "wild globalised village", where Tibetan boys "roam around like packs of wild dogs" preying on starry-eyed Western women and Israeli backpackers seek hedonism and spiritual highs, are spot on.

It is there, among his own people, that Iyer records one of "the most moving moments". Witnessing the Tibetan leader with newly arrived refugees, Iyer describes how "when the Dalai Lama came into the room, it was as if the whole place began to sob and shake".

And this strikes at the core of the Dalai Lama's dilemma. Tenzin Gyatso "serves two constituencies - his own people and the world". The wider community wants him to be "a wise man, sitting above all nation-states and offering global counsel".

Meanwhile, his compatriots are desperate for a solution with China, as the latest wave of unrest in Tibet would indicate. As the exiled leader tries to follow the non-violent approach and still appease the younger generation of frustrated Tibetans, he's caught between a "monk's vision and a guerilla's".

Iyer has no answers. As much as he tries to be an objective journalist, he admits, "Something changed in me each time I left his company, even as I was telling my friends, heatedly, that humans never really change." In a sense, The Open Road tells us as much about the author and his subject as it does about ourselves. So often in trying to fathom this simple Buddhist monk, people become caught up in the mist. Iyer brings us back into focus.

PHOTO: Tenzin Gyatso ... the 14th Dalai Lama. Photo: Kate Geraghty

urn:contentItem:44K9-G640-0197-D4TC-00000-00<published>2000-02-04T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>NEWS; Pg. 4</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BLACK FRIDAY;<br/>Hotter, and then a brief sigh of relief</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By BEN HOOPER and KATE UREN</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SOUTH Australia's heatwave is set to continue well into next week.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast temperatures in the mid to high 30s over the weekend and most of next week.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Adelaide recorded a maximum temperature of 39.8 at 2pm yesterday, before a sea breeze blew in and the temperature started slowly dropping. By 6pm the temperature was down to a more comfortable 31.</p><p>Marree and Oodnadatta recorded the State's highest temperature of 45 while Cape Willoughby on Kangaroo Island was the coolest, with a maximum of just 19.</p><p> Statewide fire bans are in place today with the extreme temperatures and forecast 35 km/h northerly winds increasing the fire danger.</p><p> As the temperature soared yesterday SA Ambulance crews reported seven heat-related cases, mostly involving the elderly, and are expecting no relief.</p><p> And school students across the State stayed indoors for lunch, sport was cancelled and many children were dismissed early.</p><p> Fifteen students at Prospect Rosary primary school were allowed to go home because of the heat. However, according to the Education Department, less than 10 per cent of schools would have dismissed students early.</p><p> Country Fire Service crews fought a forest fire in Second Valley, on Fleurieu Peninsula, using two fire bombers to contain the blaze.</p><p> SA Water reported metropolitan consumption over the past three days almost matched the record of 1153 million litres on December 10, 1998.</p><p> Acting head of Water Services Peter Norman said while the systems were handling the demand well the "enormous" consumption was draining reserves which had led to more pumping from the River Murray.</p><p> Suburban shopping centres were hit hard by power cuts with thousands of outlets and customers left in the dark.</p><p> At the Findon shopping centre a power cut brought the centre to a virtual standstill for more than 30 minutes.</p><p> Australia Post, the National Australia Bank and the Findon library were all forced to close their doors during the power cut. Other shops, such as the greengrocer and newsagency, struggled to serve customers by torchlight.</p><p> But butcher Gary Davidson, whose scales and cash register are electronic, was forced to wait angrily in his empty shop for the power to be restored before he could serve customers.</p><p> "I'm losing money because I can't serve anyone," Mr Davidson said.</p><p> The Findon Fruit Market brought out old-fashioned scales to weigh produce and served customers by torchlight.</p><p> "We're back to the good old days," said greengrocer Sophie Stanef.</p><p> At Windsor Gardens, the blackout struck the Windsor Hotel at lunchtime, leaving 150 hungry customers waiting for their meals and manager Helen Ward outraged.</p><p> "It was absolutely bloody ridiculous, just shocking," Ms Ward said.</p><p> "This is about the sixth time it's happened to me in the last few months. It usually happens about 3.30pm, but today it was the worst possible time for us.</p><p> "I know it's hot and everybody's using their airconditioners, but they should be able to cater for all of this."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4MF0-0048-T3M2-00000-00<published>1997-10-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>US: DOWNER PUSHES FOR AUSTRALIA TO ALIGN WITH ASIA AT UN</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Greg Truman</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">NEW YORK, Oct 2 AAP - Australia today initiated a push to change its official United Nations alignment with western European powers to an Asia-Pacific grouping.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Under the present UN Regional Group System devised during the Cold War era, Australia was in the 27-member Western Europe and Others Group, a lobbying body and sometime voting bloc that was increasingly dominated by European Union nations.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Foreign Affairs Minister Alexander Downer said today the regional groups should be based on geographical lines and he would seekthe support of other nations to overhaul the current system.</p><p>"We are not being prescriptive about how these groups are to be restructured," he told reporters here.</p><p> "But from Australia's perspective, a long-term objective would be for a group to be created which is more consistent with our geographic location rather than us being in a group which is increasingly dominated by the European Union."</p><p> Mr Downer denied being in the Western Europe and Others group along with New Zealand and Canada, had disadvantaged Australia's campaign for a Security Council seat last year. He noted that Europeans were moving towards a greater unity in foreign policy, meaning other voices could be lost in the crowd.</p><p> "We are at the very beginning of this process and it will take some years to achieve," said the Foreign Minister who was yet to consult with Asian leaders about possible reform of the system.</p><p> "But it's a process that ultimately has to happen and I think somebody has to promote the process."</p><p> Mr Downer, in New York to address the UN General Assembly tomorrow (about 2.30am Saturday AEST), reiterated Australia's support for calls to ensure the United States paid its arrears to the UN.</p><p> The US Administration agreed to pay up to $ US800 million ($ A1.1 billion) of the estimated $ US1 billion it owes the world body, but the Congress in Washington continued to delay the payment.</p><p> Mr Downer said he would prefer if the US paid back "the full amount, but if Congress were to agree to ($800 million) that would obviously be considerable progress".</p><p> The Foreign Minister revealed here today that Indonesia had initially rejected Australia's offer of help to counter the forest fire crisis in the region.</p><p> Fire authorities in Australia believed the situation would not have reached disaster stage if they had been allowed to assist earlier.</p><p> "Their initial reaction was they thought they could handle the matter on their own, they weren't very enthusiastic initially," he said.</p><p> "But as time went on clearly the situation remained bad, even got somewhat worse and so they came back to us and said yes they would like some help."</p><p> Mr Downer said Indonesia had asked Australia to help about a week after assistance was first offered.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4P85-12V0-TXN5-R3BH-00000-00Evacuation order as Sumatra chokes1997-09-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESINTERNATIONAL NEWSPg. 12Evacuation order as Sumatra chokes* 'THIS IS A WARNING'LOUISE WILLIAMS Herald Correspondent in Jakarta

Indonesia has warned that evacuations must begin immediately from the northern island of Sumatra, where choking pollution from forest fires has reduced visibility almost to zero.

The Environment Minister, Mr Sarwono Kusumaatmadja, said Indonesia was facing a disastrous situation as thousands of forest fire continued to burn out of control, blanketing much of South-East Asia with heavy smog.

He warned the rest of the world to learn from Indonesia's environmental crisis and said his Government must toughen laws on land-clearing, logging and the use of fires in plantations and rice planting.

"You see disasters in Peru, Papua New Guinea, droughts in Australia - every nation will have its day of reckoning," he said. "This is a warning, don't be complacent."

Meanwhile, Malaysia announced it would be prepared to evacuate Kuala Lumpur, the capital, but only if the air pollution index reached 500.

Earlier this week, the index passed the hazardous level of 300 in two areas of the city, but yesterday it was down to a still unhealthy 139.

Mr Sarwono said visibility readings in the northern Sumatran province of Riau reached zero yesterday, and that his ministry was recommending immediate evacuations.

He said disaster plans were being drawn up for large-scale evacuations from other seriously affected regions, as well as the wide distribution of drinking water to tens of millions of people hit by drought caused by the delay in monsoon rains.

"This is a new situation that has to be taken very seriously," he said after meeting environment ministers from neighbouring Association of South-East Asian countries.

"It is a disaster scenario and we are not used to large-scale disasters. Previous fires were child's play compared with what we are facing now, and we have to come up with new systems and emergency procedures."

A strong El Nino pattern has delayed the monsoon rains in Indonesia, leading to a widespread drought, and scorching large areas of forest, much of it already damaged by logging and land-clearing.

Mr Sarwono said Malaysia and Singapore had agreed to co-operate with Indonesia in cloud seeding operations as well as sharing satellite pictures to monitor the location and intensity of forest fires.

He said Indonesia was investigating the possibility that the heavy haze over Java and Jakarta may be blowing from the Northern Territory and Queensland, where forest fires have been reported.

Officials said conditions were at danger level for at least 20 million Indonesians on the worst-hit islands of Sumatra and Kalimantan.

Mr Sarwono said 175 logging and plantation companies faced the withdrawal of their licences, hefty fines and public denunciation over the fires.

Illus: Heat haze ... an Indonesian woman waits to cross the main road from Palembang to Lahat in thick smoke from scrub fires. Photograph by REUTER/SUPRI

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PS0-0048-T483-00000-00<published>1997-09-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>HIGHLIGHTS OF THE AAP WORLD WIRE AT 1530 SEPT 25, 1997</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Sept 25 AAP - Australians with respiratory or heart conditions and pregnant women should consider deferring plans to travel to some smoke-choked regions of South-East Asia, the Australian government said today. (HAZE NIGHTLEAD)</p><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Sept 25 AAP - Deaths from drought-related famine and disease continued to mount in Indonesia's westernmost province today, with the Home Affairs Ministry here revealing 265 were now believed dead. (INDON DROUGHT)</p><p nitf:lede="true"> LONDON, Sept 25 AFP - The British government should proceed with caution in its attempts to persuade Saudi Arabia not to carry out a sentence of 500 lashes on a nurse found guilty of complicity to murder, the press said here today. (SAUDI NURSES UK. See also SAUDI NURSES SALAH)</p><p>BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Sept 25 AP - After 16 months of wrangling - and decades of sporadic violence - most of Northern Ireland's politicians have agreed to begin substantive peace talks on the future of the British ruled province. (IRELAND TALKS NIGHTLEAD)</p><p>SUVA, Sept 25 AFP - Fiji has been given official confirmation of its re-entry into the Commonwealth after a 10-year exile, Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka announced today. (FIJI COMMONWEALTH NIGHTLEAD)</p><p>HONG KONG, Sept 25 AP - Southeast Asia's currency declines and the forest fire ashes polluting the region's air are temporary crises, but it's important to remember to fight the causes when the dramas are over, World Bank President James Wolfensohn said today. (IMF NIGHTLEAD)</p><p>BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Sept 25 AP - Bosnia's two feuding Serb camps have agreed to hold elections that will test whether Bosnia's No 1 war crimes suspect is still supported by the majority of Serbs in the republic. (BOSNIA SERBS NIGHTLEAD)</p><p>SEOUL, Sept 25 AFP - Kim Jong-Il has received his third endorsement in a week to take over leadership of North Korea's ruling communist party, the North's state media reported today. (KOREA KIM NIGHTLEAD)</p><p> SAN DIEGO, Sept 24 AAP - US authorities investigating the illegal sale of Australian lottery tickets have moved a step closer to hitting the jackpot with the launch of extradition proceedings against the alleged mastermind of an international lottery scam. (US LOTTO)</p><p> HANOI, Sept 25 Reuter - Vietnam's new president used his acceptance speech to reiterate the country's need for far-reaching reform with the Communist Party firmly at the helm, official media reports said today. (VIETNAM PRESIDENT)</p><p> NEW YORK, Sept 25 AP - Investigators are looking into whether bundled wires caused the explosion that brought down TWA Flight 800 last year, the CBS Evening News reported. (US TWA NIGHTLEAD)</p><p> WASHINGTON, Sept 24 AP - In his earliest known use of the White House for fund raising, President Bill Clinton hosted a series of private breakfasts with wealthy Democrats to help raise money in 1994 for the party's health care fund, documents show. (US FUNDING)</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PS0-0048-T483-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="486"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:49JW-RDD0-01S8-G216-00000-00<published>1986-02-13T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>CYCLONE AREAS FACE FIRE THREAT</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>MARTIN H</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Cyclone areas face fire threat UNCONTROLLABLE fires could sweep north Queensland rainforest battered by cyclone Winifred unless rain fell soon, a fire chief said yesterday. The Tully fire chief, Mr Bob Long, said the area needed only a spark to start a forest fire that could run out of control for days. ""Every day of sunshine dries out the forest floor," he said. Mr Long said it could take the rainforest years to recover if a fire erupted now. ""If people don't observe the voluntary fire ban, lives could be lost as well as major properties," he said. Mission Beach and Bingil Bay were inhabited areas particularly at risk. The Innisfail deputy fire chief, Mr Bruce Dade, said the risk area covered from Mission Beach to Babinda and no rain was in sight. ""Foliage blown from trees is feet deep in some places in the rainforest," he said. ""It's tinder dry and it would only need a match for fires to start everywhere." Mr Dade said the fire risk was one of the most serious in the area for years. Surveys have found extensive damage to areas of the Barrier Reef worst hit by cyclone Winifred 12 days ago. Winifred tracked adjacent to the outer Barrier Reef from Cape Melville south, crossed the reef off Innisfail and hit the coast at Silkwood. Ground surveys found coral destruction 15i deep on reefs in the cyclone's path. According to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, surveys of the area only three weeks before the cyclone allowed scientists to see the before-and-after effects of a cyclone on the reef.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Scientists hope to find evidence to explain differences in the structure and composition of coral reefs in the Great Barrier Reef region. The Local Government Minister, Mr Hinze, said modern buildings in Babinda and Innisfail were not damaged by cyclone Winifred, proving the benefits of building regulations introduced four years ago. He said a department survey showed major structual damage to buildings to be worst in the two areas but no single family homes built in accordance with the new regulations had any structual damage. ""Neighboring older style houses were damaged substantially in some cases," he said. ""Damage to some buildings varied from minor roof and wall cladding failures to total structural collapse."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata Keep refreshing the page to see updates.

8.30AM: I'll leave you with this pretty cool rock-star wedding in the Illawarra. Find a way to put a smile on someone's face.

Thirroul's Beaches Hotel was taken over by music celebrities, television and radio identities over the weekend for what could be labelled the Illawarra's wedding of the year.

Frenzal Rhomb guitarist Lindsay 'The Doctor' McDougall married longtime love Jen Owens at Sublime Point Cafe on Saturday, with the full vegan reception of 250 people held at the local with an open invite to the public. See the photos.

8.26AM: If you're scared of flying don't watch this.

8.23AM: Do small schools still have a place in our communities? Take a look at this story and add your opinion to the readers' poll.

8.20AM: Kiama residents will be treated to a special glimpse into the life of Hollywood fashion legend Orry-Kelly when biographer Robert Parkinson gives a presentation at Kiama Library.

Until an article appeared in Vogue Australia in 1994, Orry George Kelly had been mostly forgotten by Australia, even though he was internationally recognised in the fields of film costume and women's fashion.

Parkinson has delved into the vivid life of this triple Academy Award winner in his book Orry-Kelly, Miss Weston's Protege. Read all about it.

8.14AM: Did you catch Season two of Fargo last night? Looks good. Did you catch up on the latest Bachelorette goss? Here's a snippet in case you missed it. Handsome rope technician Richie has been eliminated by Sam Frost in an emotional penultimate episode of The Bachelorette. Find out more.

8.07AM: If you've just joined us, good morning. Your in for a cooler day than yesterday with showers. If you're about to jump in the car or on a train you've got a clear run so far. For a quick news catch-up scroll down.

8.05AM: Seen this? Great idea for motorcycle rider safety.

7.58AM: Check out these oldies from the Bay Post. How many do you recognise? See the photos here.

7.50AM: Change in the wind for Kiama.

A proposed international competition to design a concept plan for the Kiama East precinct would seek to create a vision for the area, while preventing 'ad hoc' development.

At the meeting of Kiama council's Economic Development Committee in September, recommendations were made for council's consideration.

These included a proposed concept design competition for the Bong Bong/Terralong/Manning streets area, including the harbour precincts.

Read all about it.

7.46AM: Something for the golfers. Well golfers like me.

7.42AM: A light rain fell as a small group of family and close friends gathered for a simple, but moving tribute to Marnie Lee Cave on Wednesday.

Those closest to the 26-year-old planted a 'butterfly tree' not far from where she was found dead under the bridge at Mogareeka a week prior.

Patrick Aberdeen said Ms Cave was more than a friend to he and his partner, 'she was our little sister'.

'Everyone knew her as 'love' or 'darl' and was always greeted with a big hug,' he said.

'She was a lovely person with a beautiful personality. Full story.

7.21AM: Hey it's Thursday, time to plan your weekend's entertainment. Check out who's playing where in the Eurobodalla.

7.18AM: Looking for something to do this weekend? Don't forget Sculpture by the sea starts today.

Visitors to Sculpture by the Sea are advised to leave the car behind and take advantage of the hundreds of extra buses running for this year's exhibition.

The free display of sculptures on the Bondi to Tamarama coastal walk starts today, with hundreds of thousands of people expected to visit it until it finishes on Sunday 8 November.

7.12AM: Look who dropped into Nowra recently. The Shoalhaven Historical Society played host to NSW Premier Mike Baird at its Nowra Museum on Sunday.

Mr Baird toured the society's World War I commemoration exhibition, Not Forgotten.

Society president Lynne Allen said it was a huge occasion for the organisation.

'It's a big honour for us, a little volunteer run and funded museum to host the premier,' she said. Read all about it.

7.03AM: Last night's rain would have been a welcome relief for fire fighters on the Darkes Forest fire.

FIRE crews are keeping watch over a section of bushland at Darkes Forest that went up in flames Tuesday night.

The blaze began about 6pm in circumstances that are still being investigated.

It consumed 15 hectares of bush as 54 RFS firefighters grappled with dense vegetation and limited access.

It was 2am before the crews could go home. Full story.

It's another clear run for rail commuters and people hitting the roads. Take it easy though, driving conditions are wet.

Need a national news snapshot first thing - well, we have you covered.

'BENDIGO: Luci Mayer wants to know where she gets her nose from, and her chestnut-coloured eyes. The answer may lie in the face of a man she has never met, but who conceived her after a one-night stand with her mother 21 years ago. Her social media pleas have resurfaced this week. Read more

'WOLLONGONG: Time is running out to save the Port Kembla steelworks, said South Coast Labour Council's Arthur Rorris. Continue reading

'NEWCASTLE: A primary school has been forced to quarantine its vegetable patch after firefighting chemicals from Williamtown RAAF Base were detected in the school's bore water. It is understood at least one of the chemicals was detected at three times the drinking water standard.

'TASMANIA: Police say a protester who scaled the University of Tasmania's Centenary Building on Wednesday has been arrested and will be charged. Read more

'MANDURAH: 'We don't want it here.'

A Mandurah "bong shop" is already causing outrage in the community, despite it still being weeks away from opening. Read more

'BALLARAT: Ballarat Hospital was included in the highest comparative infant death rates for regional hospitals but its chief executive has defended the hospital's record. Continue reading

'ILLAWARRA: Thirroul's Beaches Hotel was taken over by music celebrities, television and radio identities over the weekend for what could be labelled the Illawarra's wedding of the year as Frenzal Rhomb guitarist Lindsay 'The Doctor' McDougall married longtime love Jen Owens on Saturday. Story, photos

'WA: Potentially life-saving mental health services are set to be provided to young people across the South West as part of a $1.8 million funding announcement by the state government. Read more

'WAGGA: A manhunt to locate two of the nation's most wanted criminals has made headway in the south, after father-and-son fugitives Gino and Mark Stocco were spotted in central Victoria. Continue reading

'MOREE: The woman charged with the dangerous driving death of a Moree man has been refused bail in court. The 38-year-old is facing one count of dangerous driving occasioning death and contravening an AVO, and will now be transported to a women's correctional centre in Sydney, where she will be housed until the case returns to court next week. Read more

'It was call 1267 and then call number 1271 to CrimeStoppers that provided the key breakthrough to two baffling murder investigations running in two separate states. The first call came through that not only provided a breakthrough but linked the two investigations in the most tragic way. The caller outlined that single mother, Karlie Jade Pearce-Stevenson and her daughter Khandalyce had been missing for six years. Continue reading

'It's stomach-churning, but a new treatment at a Sydney hospital has a 90 per cent success rate. Read more

'The Therapeutic Goods Administration is investigating a "Dallas Buyers Club" of doctors and patients importing potentially life-saving Hepatitis C medication from countries like China. Read more

'Deputy Liberal leader Julie Bishop has angered conservative MPs in her own party for failing to deliver a speech in praise of former treasurer Joe Hockey in the parliament or the Coalition party room. Continue reading

'NEW YORK: Disgraced former rugby league player Matthew Lodge faced a New York court on Wednesday, where a judge placed him on strict orders to stay away from the women he allegedly stalked and told "this is the night you die". Read more

'UNITED KINGDOM: A propaganda blitz has accompanied Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to London to see the Queen. The visit, the first by a Chinese leader in 10 years, is being portrayed as the dawn of a new "golden era" in Sino-British relations ' with lucrative trade deals in the wings. Continue reading

'VANUATU: A powerful undersea earthquake of 7.1-magnitude struck Vanuatu on Wednesday. Read more

'1824: Hume and Hovell convert a bullock cart into a boat in order to cross the flooded Murrumbidgee River.

'1854: Around 10,000 miners converge near Bakery Hill in Victoria to discuss their grievances for more rights on the goldfields.

'1872: The first overseas telegraph messages are received in Adelaide via the newly constructed Overland Telegraph Line.

Newcastle professor Graeme Jameson has won the Prime Minister's prize for innovation for his world-famous mining invention.

The University of Newcastle chemical engineer's work ' the Jameson Cell ' is estimated to have contributed billions of dollars to the Australian economy.

''If you're going to put your heart into something, you may as well tackle a problem that will make a difference because the effort will be the same,' he said.

Pg. 24</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Asia turns to burning issue of economics</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>EDWARDS N</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">ECONOMICS, not water, should be the prime weapon in the fight to control forest fires that rage through Indonesia each year and shroud the nation and its neighbours in a polluting haze, a forestry expert said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"Sending out firemen and planes full of water will not put these fires out," said Jeff Sayer, director-general of the Centre for International Forestry Research in Indonesia.</p><p nitf:lede="true">"The way to stop the recurrence of these fires is to change the economics of the region and improve the process of development."</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>QNP</p></bodyText></section><p>Water-bombing strategic tracts of burning forest in Sumatra and Borneo from the air was the heart of a plan devised last week by senior officials from Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore.</p><p>The plan has yet to be given the go-ahead by the governments of these four nations _ worst hit by fires which are set to clear Indonesian land for development but often rage out of control.</p><p>Commentators say fires on the scale of this year have not been seen since the great forest fire of Borneo in 1982-83 that devastated 33,000sq km of land.</p><p>Haze is not solely a product of Indonesia's burning forests, but also a result of pollutants from factories and vehicles.</p><p>Declaring a national disaster, traffic-choked Malaysia has sought to tighten emission rules and is restricting the number of cars admitted to Kuala Lumpur as part of a haze action plan.</p><p>Singapore is part of a four-nation group spearheading the global drive to reduce harmful greenhouse gas emissions _ born out of 1992's Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro _ by encouraging greener industrial processes.</p><p>Singapore has stepped up its air quality monitoring from every 24 hours to every three hours and, along with Malaysia and Indonesia, has issued warnings about exercising outdoors.</p><p>The pall of smoke also ignites economic losses. Indonesia's Environment Ministry estimates about 30 million cubic metres of forest are destroyed by fire every year, causing losses of 240 trillion rupiah ($A115.38 billion).</p><p>The haze led Kuala Lumpur to close its airport briefly this month, and there have been closures of Indonesian airports.</p><p>Environmentalists are not confident that slash and burn practices can be halted in rapidly expanding Indonesia, where big companies hungry to make profits and farmers who are simply hungry use fire as the fastest means of clearing land.</p><p>Climatic conditions compound the problem.</p><p>A Jakarta official said fires in Kalimantan and Sumatra's Riau archipelago, just across from Singapore and peninsula Malaysia, were worsened by a drought caused by the El Nino weather system which disrupts global weather patterns.</p><p>Meteorologists say this year's El Nino _ estimated to have already caused at least $A17.86 billion in economic damage _ could be the worst this century.</p><p>Reuter</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P8H-NRD0-TXN5-S0NV-00000-00Suharto counts cost of rescue package1997-10-10T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 13Suharto counts cost of rescue packageLOUISE WILLIAMS

Jakarta, Thursday

The International Monetary Fund's assistance package is likely to increase pressure on President Suharto to sacrifice national pride and family business interests to prevent an economic free fall triggered by corporate defaults.

Analysts say the Indonesian Government will seek strategies to bail out some of the country's largest corporate empires which are facing crippling US dollar debt repayments because of the dramatic devaluation of the rupiah.

Construction sites in Jakarta have fallen silent this week as developers, facing substantial short-term debts, have suspended work. Australian companies are reporting the non-payment of bills by many Indonesian customers.

Economists said IMF assistance was essential to prevent corporate bankruptcies and the disastrous social and political consequences of widespread lay-offs. The economic difficulties come at a time when Indonesia is facing crop reductions because of drought, a forest fire crisis, and heightened political volatility.

Growth forecasts have been revised down and price rises are expected for politically sensitive food items and petrol.

Both the stock and money markets reacted modestly to the IMF announcement with the rupiah moving up from 3640 to the US dollar to 3565 and the stockmarket gaining almost 1 per cent.

The IMF is expected to increase pressure for the scrapping of Indonesia's national car project - which granted exclusive tax and tariff concessions to one of Mr Suharto's sons - and of the expensive national program to develop an Indonesian jet. That project is controlled by the Minister for Technology and close presidential ally, Dr Jusuf Habibi.

Monopolies on products such as rice and flour are likely to be challenged and analysts say the overcrowded and under-performing banking sector will face closures and mergers.

"Indonesia now has to be mentally ready to face the consequences and put itself on a strict diet. There's no use in pursuing nationalist policies like the car and the plane if they cost too much," said the economist Christianto Wibisono.

"If the corporates go bankrupt, lots of people will lose their jobs, there will be political turbulence and social riots. So our present position is one of whether or not we want to survive. We have no choice."

Another analyst said: "Propping up private companies may be money down the drain but the question you have to ask is what happens if you don't prop them up. People are already being laid off. This is not a good scenario."

The national car project is backed by loans of more than $A1 billion from local banks and has attracted formal protests in the World Trade Organisation from Japan, the European Union and the United States over unfair trading conditions.

But Mr Suharto refused to cut back the project last month when a 25 per cent reduction in infrastructure spending was announced. Some commentators say an IMF-forced cut will be rejected.

urn:contentItem:4P8B-H1N0-TXN5-R0D9-00000-00IRA was testing super bomb, police claim2001-08-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESInternational NewsPg. 9IRA was testing super bomb, police claimNORTHERN IRELANDPaul Daley, in London and agencies

The serpentine connections and sinister activities of the Provisional Irish Republican Army are threatening international support for Irish nationalism and compromising the peace process.

Despite assurances from Sinn Fein, the republican movement's political wing, that three IRA men arrested in Colombia nine days ago had no links to the party, it appears one of them was Sinn Fein's unofficial ambassador to Cuba.

The men were initially suspected of training the country's rebels in bomb-making in return for heavy weapons.

However, British security forces said at the weekend that the arrested men were in South America testing a "super bomb" to be used in Northern Ireland and on the British mainland.

The arrests have damaged Sinn Fein's international standing and credibility in the negotiations brokered by London and Dublin over the disarmament of Northern Ireland's paramilitaries.

The arrests of the three, including Niall Connolly said to have been Sinn Fein's "fixer" in Havana for the past five years coincided with the IRA's claim that it had begun permanently decommissioning its weapons.

The IRA has since withdrawn its offer to decommission.

If Connolly was involved in the procurement of weapons for the Provisionals while the IRA publicly claimed to be disarming it would also damage Sinn Fein's claim that it had no influence over the IRA's activities.

Connolly, it seems, is an operative for Sinn Fein and the IRA which contradicts Sinn Fein's repeated assurances that the Provisionals operate independently.

British intelligence officials say the three IRA suspects were working on a vapour bomb capable of killing hundreds of people. They were arrested after Colombian authorities claimed they had spent five weeks in a large area controlled by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, or FARC, in which an explosion could pass unnoticed or be mistaken for a small forest fire.

A swab taken from the clothing of one is believed to have yielded traces of vapour bomb ingredients, and two others showed up drugs and explosives.

The arrest of the Colombia Three, as the British media have dubbed them, could not come at a worse time for the Sinn Fein leader, Mr Gerry Adams, who had been planning a trip to Cuba that was to include an audience with President Fidel Castro, who has been a staunch supporter of the IRA and Sinn Fein.

Washington has strenuously objected to the meeting.

But the arrest of Connolly, who British sources maintain was instrumental in setting up the Castro-Adams meeting, brings another element cocaine into the equation.

The FARC rebels being trained by Connolly and his associates support themselves in part through the sale of cocaine. Although there is no direct evidence that the IRA men were handling the drug, their involvement with FARC has created a tremor inside the CIA and British intelligence agencies.

Some reports say the United States is examining whether to effectively outlaw Sinn Fein as a result of the Colombian arrests. This would have a disastrous impact on its funding; Americans contribute almost $A1.5 million a year to the party's coffers.

ILLUS: Arrested ... Niall Connolly, said to have been Sinn Fein's ``fixer'' in Havana for the past five years.

urn:contentItem:4P8H-NPG0-TXN5-S0HM-00000-00BRIEFS1999-07-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWSIn Brief OverseasPg. 13BRIEFS

Vivid fireball over New Zealand

AUCKLAND, WEDNESDAY. A meteor exploded over New Zealand in daylight today, prompting hundreds of calls to emergency services around the country. Radio New Zealand said a forest fire near Napier on the east of the North Island appears to have been started by falling debris. The Carter Observatory in Wellington said the explosion and smoke around 4.15pm was heard and seen by people as far apart as Rotorua in the north and Nelson at the top of the South Island.

Daredevil dies in Norwegian jump

OSLO. A Norwegian parachutist who frustrated police and entertained the public with daredevil leaps from some of the world's tallest buildings has been killed in a jump from a cliff. Thor Axel Kappfjell, 32, became an icon to fixed object jumpers in Norway for his leaps from the World Trade Centre, the Empire State Building and the Chrysler Building in New York, the Eiffel Tower in Paris and even the Norwegian Prime Minister's office in Oslo. He was killed early yesterday when he jumped off the 1000-metre-high Kjerag cliff over the waters of Lysefjord, near Stavanger.

Minister stable after suicide bid

ANKARA. Turkey's State Minister for the Economy, Mr Hikmet Ulugbay, was in a stable condition today after a three-hour operation following an apparent suicide attempt last night, a senior hospital official said. "He is now under control and in a stable condition. There is no reason to worry about him," Dr Mehmet Haberal, chief doctor at Ankara's Baskent hospital, said. Mr Ulugbay, 60, a key figure in efforts to reform Turkey's deficit-ridden economy, had suffered no brain damage, he said.

Japanese are in the hot seat

TOKYO. Japan's high-tech toilets are giving a whole new meaning to the phrase "in the hot seat". Consumers keen on toilets equipped with heated seats and automated warm-water bidets are being warned of possible dire consequences after fires were sparked by worn-out wiring on older models. At least four fires this year have been traced to older versions of the "Washlet" toilets.

Clinton to visit Indian reservation

RAPID CITY, SOUTH DAKOTA. President Clinton, below, will become the first president in 63 years to visit AmericanIndian country on Wednesday, touring the historic Pine Ridge reservation to dramatise the grinding poverty many Indians face. Mr Clinton will travel to Pine Ridge, site of the 1890 Wounded Knee massacre and home of the poorest county in the nation, to announce more than $US1.5billion ($A2.24 billion) in new private investment programs and government assistance to provide housing and economic development aid toreservation Indians.

Kazakh officials to probe rocket crash

ALMATY. A Kazakhstan Government commission left for the central Kar-Karalinsk region today to assess the damage caused by Monday's crash of a Russian telecommunications satellite, the Foreign Ministry said. The RussianProton-K heavy booster rocket was launched on Monday evening but a malfunction detached the engine and parts of the booster, causing them to crash on to the steppe. The satellite crashed in the remote Altai region of Siberia.

type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Belanglo link probe</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>OWENS W</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p>HOMICIDE detectives are reinvestigating the killing of a female hitch-hiker, in a bid to determine whether she may have been the Belanglo serial killer's eighth victim.</p><p> If so, she would be the first victim dumped outside that notorious forest.</p><p> Backpacker murder squad police are reviewing the murder of Dianne Pennacchio, found stabbed to death in a state forest almost 200km south of the Belanglo State Forest "graveyard".</p><p> Detectives say the murder of the Queanbeyan mother, in September 1991, involved similar elements to many of the Belanglo forest killings.</p><p> Two detectives from Task Force Air have spent the past week in Queanbeyan studying evidence from the Pennacchio case, the first non-Belanglo murder confirmed under active investigation by the squad.</p><p> Mrs Pennacchio, 29, was last seen late at night leaving a hotel at Bungendore, east of Canberra, to hitch a ride home to nearby Queanbeyan.She never arrived.</p><p> Her decomposed body was found two months later in the Tallanganda State Forest, south of the Bungendore-Queanbeyan road.</p><p> Two forestry workers found the body face down, hidden alongside a log and covered with pine needles, about 10m from a forest fire trail.</p><p> Virtually all the Belanglo forest victims have been found in almost identical bushland settings.</p><p> Task Force Air commander, Superintendent Clive Small, had earlier said that the similarity of the Belanglo body sites could well mark the "signature" of a serial killer.</p><p> He said that specialist officers would analyse the detailed findings so far, but suggested that a pattern may be emerging from the nature and location of the death scenes.</p><p> "All we can do is follow the perimeter of the pine forest where we have found the bodies near all the fire trails," he said.</p><p> Mrs Pennacchio was savagely stabbed to death, as most of the Belanglo victims were believed to have been.</p><p> Police say there was no sign of a struggle where Mrs Pennacchio was found, suggesting she was killed elsewhere and dumped in the forest.</p><p> More than one person may have been involved, too, because a lone killer would have found it hard to lift and carry her heavy frame.</p><p> Police also believe that Mrs Pennacchio was probably sexually assaulted, based on the position of her jeans when found.</p><p> Some detectives believe that at least one of the Belanglo victims may also have been sexually assaulted, and no signs of struggle were found there, either.</p><p> But if Mrs Pennacchio was murdered by the Belanglo forest killer, she was the only victim who was married, a mother, not a backpacker and nearly 30.</p><p> A task force spokesman said that numerous other crime scenes have been visited by the squad's 35 detectives, but police have refused to name individual cases.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content><nitf:body.end><graphic><nitf:media><caption><p>Flashback: Police in the Belanglo forest.</p></caption></nitf:media></graphic></nitf:body.end></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4S25-20M0-TX5J-V0DJ-00000-00Humming along nicely2008-03-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisCARPg. 15Humming along nicely

AL GORE will hate you, children will love you, teenagers will envy you and old people will simply be amazed when you drive by in a Hummer H3.

People point and stare, frown and laugh, give a thumbs-up.

The H3 is certainly a divisive vehicle. Get used to being looked at and judgment passed over you and your vehicle.

Hummer began with the US Army Humvee in the 1991 Gulf War, then gradually became gentrified as people like Arnold Schwarzenegger began buying the civilian H2.

The H3 is the smallest, most civilised and least confronting Hummer yet.

However, it is hardly on Gore's must-buy list with a weight of 2.2 tonnes, a petrol appetite of 13.7 litres every 100km and CO2 emissions of 327g every kilometre.

Owners should be aware that about every 6000-7000km, it will generate its own weight in CO2. But the vehicle can't be written off for environmental reasons.

If you need a vehicle that will cover almost any terrain in comfort, then the H3 has a legitimate job to do and it does it well.

On the Australian launch in the hills surrounding the Yarra Valley wine district, the H3 mastered deep-rutted red soil, overflowing bog holes, sloppy claypans, steep boulder-strewn hills and forest fire trails.

The H3 feels stable and quiet on highways, wallows through corners with a fair amount of body roll and gets jiggly over potholes with its off-road-oriented rear leaf springs.

Soft, dry sand should be no problem. After all, with the right tyre pressure and plenty of momentum most 4WDs run through sand.

Steering is typically American -- vague.

The American vehicle is built in right-hand drive in South Africa. However, the designers have not done a great job in the left-to-right conversion process.

The heavy rear door is still hinged on the left which means you have to venture out toward passing traffic to load the vehicle.

And the foot-operated parking brake in the American version is replaced by an ancient umbrella-stick handbrake in the RHD model.

These went out with Hawaiian shirts and it's easy to see why. They are impossible to release with a ham fist.

You have to learn the brake's mechanical subtleties then execute a precise series of movements -- pull the button, then turn the handle, release the brake about halfway then wiggle it a bit more to get it all the way in. Don't forget to hold your tongue in the right position, too. Rush it or try to muscle the handbrake and it just won't release.

Handbrake aside, the interior is slightly better than the US version with a classy brushed aluminium centre stack and quality trim.

The seats are comfortable and look far enough apart to easily fit five adults.

The rear middle seat also has a pull-out drinks container.

The high floor means plenty of clearance and this is where the H3 excels as over rutted sand and dirt tracks there are no unnerving scraping sounds.

While the floor is high, the roof is low and the windows very narrow.

With no rear parking sensors, it is advisable to be vigilant of children and small animals when backing out of your garage.

Strangely, the flat-fronted Besser-block styling which the engineers admit has not been designed for aerodynamics has little wind or road noise at any speed.

Bodywork is a mixture of metal and plastic.

The reason for the plastic panels is to keep weight down, reduce scratching from brushes with scrub such as lantana and they are cheaper to replace.

Under the bonnet is a raucous 3.7-litre five-cylinder Vortec petrol engine specially designed to fit the H3. It quietens down at highway speed, but it is a little underdone for the 2.2 tonne vehicle. More appropriate diesel and V8 models are coming in 2009.

It is mated to a five-speed manual which has a truck-like throw without being notchy or vague.

A four-speed auto is available for an extra $2000, but it is slow and hunts around, as well as being even less economical.

The H3 sits on 16 x 7.5 inch alloy wheels with 75 per cent high-profile tyres which are good for ride quality, noise and over rocky terrain, but not much chop for twisty tarmac.

Standard features in the H3 are cruise control, electro-chromatic rearview mirror with eight point compass, power windows, fog lights and halogen headlamps, remote entry with panic alarm, single in-dash CD, cloth seats and 60/40 split rear seats.

urn:contentItem:56PB-KYX1-F0JP-W03F-00000-00Calm in the wilderness2012-09-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisESCAPEPg. 8Calm in the wildernessChanel Parratt

New adventures await at this East-meets-West resort in the beautiful mountains of British Columbia, writes Chanel Parratt

WE'RE under an evacuation order from the Canadian Mounties. A forest fire 13km away is threatening the Cariboo region of British Columbia.

Fortunately, the Echo Valley Ranch & Spa is as green as a ranch can get. It is so well watered that the helicopters water-bombing the fire are using the ranch's well-stocked trout pond to refill their buckets. Smoked trout now.

Impeccable timing on my part I'd spent the previous morning fly-fishing before the choppers took their fill.

Norm and Nan Dove bought the property 22 years ago. Their original plan to live on the ranch and build extra accommodation for visiting family and friends soon changed.

Walking around the ranch one morning, Norm says: ``We thought perhaps this was a little too indulgent to have all for ourselves.''

Over the next five years, the Dove lodge and cabins were built and they opened for business. The cedar wood used in the construction of the lodge and cabin buildings was also used on the Thai spa creating a beautiful continuity across this East-meets-West ranch.

The 65ha property is surrounded by four unique biomes: the canyon, with its hoodoos and sand spirals; grasslands, where ranches run between 10,000 and 15,000 head of cattle and farm hay; the marble mountain range, which you look out to from the property; and the flatlands, with lakes and marshes.

Guided day trips head in all directions. You can explore by foot, horse, 4x4 and plane the ranch has a private landing strip.

I stayed in a premium room in the Lookout Lodge, where I could appreciate the view to Mt Bowman. The simplicity of the room, with wooden floors and furniture, plush king bed, feathery pillows and thick white linen, created a sense of luxurious country hospitality.

That same feeling extends to the kitchen, where chef Jason Folk serves meals along the kitchen bench. You can help yourself to as much or as little as you like before settling at one of the long communal tables.

Dinner on the first night was a tender beef osso bucco that I could pull apart with my fork. On the last night, there a barbecue around the campfire ribs, lamb cutlets, roast duck, salmon, beef rissoles for burgers, salad, roast potatoes, coleslaw and fresh watermelon.

Breakfast each morning was a variation of sausages, crispy bacon, fried eggs, salmon and vegetable omelet, roast tomatoes, mushrooms, french toast with maple syrup, strawberries, fruit salad, yoghurt, cereal and toast.

Lunch consisted of grilled tuna, cold cuts of roast duck, turkey, ham and beef, hearty soups, fresh vegetables, leafy greens and, of course, dessert apple pie or creamed rice. The cookie jar is always full.

Don't be fooled by all the good country eating, there were plenty of vegetarian options and they work with food intolerances, too.

Folk's farm-to-fork approach is easily achieved, with an organic vegie patch metres from the kitchen.

Echo Valley is a place to recharge your batteries in whatever way works for you.

Frisbee with Norm and Nan's eight border collies is my pick, although a hammock the location of which I refused to disclose was a nice spot to listen to the wind and the tic-tic-tic of the sprinklers.

The BaanThai spa pavilion, designed by Thai architect Dr Pinyo Suwankiri, is beautiful. Inside the pavilion, imported teak furnishings, Thai silk and hand carvings create an authentic space, and the ginger tea is the first step towards calm.

My Thai massage was a combination of gentle stretching, pressure-point release and massage. Similar to Chinese meridians, the goal is to unblock your sen lines, releasing built-up toxins, restoring energy flow, increasing circulation and have you walking out feeling great.

The following morning, I traded a sleep-in for Thai yoga. I learnt how to massage and apply pressure to different parts of my face to stimulate lymphatic drainage and help improve circulation. Gentle poses followed by jovial Thai music and dancing had everyone in stitches at the end.

There's a third element that helps make the ranch unique its relationship with the indigenous First Nations people.

A close friendship with Rose, one of the few hereditary chiefs of the Shuswap people, means outdoor adventure organiser Darrel Nippard can take guests to the High Bar Indian reserve for a 4x4 tour of the Fraser Canyon and river.

On the tour, we explore the remnants of fortune-seeking Chinese gold miners. An old stone dam and wooden flume from the mid-1800s still stands. The arid desert is covered in sage bush and tiny cactus.

Nippard taught us about his favourite pastime panning for gold. Our group of seven managed to find about $1.50 worth of gold dust between us. Not the early retirement I was looking for or the giant nugget the kids were chasing, but fun just the same.

Further up the river, we tried our luck salmon fishing. A net on the end of a long pole produced results in seconds as the salmon made their annual migration upstream to lay eggs.

Nippard has a wealth of knowledge when it comes to edible foods. Cactus that tastes like watermelon and a tart purple berry half the size of a blueberry were ``good eating''.

Back at the ranch, indigenous artist Michael Blackstock had arrived to do his third tree carving next to one of the ranch's springs. Water is very much a living thing for First Nations people. Blackstock carves faces into trees near each spring as a way to protect this vital life source. I was lucky to witness the blessing ceremony for all three carvings the following day, where tobacco smoke and dry leaf circled the trunk of each tree.

There are 35 Tennessee Walking Horses for you to ride.

Horseback adventures range from lessons and beginner trails to day rides.

Wranglers are at the ready to help you get the most out of your ride.

Try as they might, they couldn't completely get me over my nervous indifference towards horses.

I am, however, a step closer to understanding how my 164cm frame could control such a beast granted they gave me one ready to retire.

The writer was a guest of the Echo Valley Ranch & Spa.

Go2

CARIBOO

Getting there

By air: Fly to Vancouver and arrange a charter flight to the ranch.

By road: Echo Valley is 435km from Vancouver, a five-hour drive.

By rail: Catch a train to Kamloops station, a two-hour drive from Echo Valley. Transfers can be arranged through the ranch.

Staying thereEcho Valley Ranch and Spa, see evranch.com

urn:contentItem:6FNN-3DR3-RWMW-P31K-00000-00Dangerous trees being felled after forest fire in inaccessible location2025-04-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisDangerous trees being felled after forest fire in inaccessible locationKatrina Lovell

The blaze burnt about an acre of land.

Fire crews were called to a blaze in an inaccessible part of the Framlingham Forest on Saturday, April 26, 2025.

A Country Fire Authority spokesperson said the fire started about 1.12pm which burnt about one acre near Purnim.

He said it was in an inaccessible part of the forest, and bulldozers had been called in to fell a number of dangerous trees as a result of the fire.

A fire investigator attended the scene on Sunday, April 27, 2025 to help determine the cause of the blaze.

Fire crews were also called to reports of a grass fire along the Cobden Warrnambool Road at Naringal East on Sunday.

But when they arrived on scene it was a tree on fire and it was extinguished within about 10 minutes, the spokesperson said.
