Walking around the ranch one morning, Norm says: ``We thought perhaps this was a little too indulgent to have all for ourselves.''

Over the next five years, the Dove lodge and cabins were built and they opened for business. The cedar wood used in the construction of the lodge and cabin buildings was also used on the Thai spa creating a beautiful continuity across this East-meets-West ranch.

The 65ha property is surrounded by four unique biomes: the canyon, with its hoodoos and sand spirals; grasslands, where ranches run between 10,000 and 15,000 head of cattle and farm hay; the marble mountain range, which you look out to from the property; and the flatlands, with lakes and marshes.

Guided day trips head in all directions. You can explore by foot, horse, 4x4 and plane the ranch has a private landing strip.

I stayed in a premium room in the Lookout Lodge, where I could appreciate the view to Mt Bowman. The simplicity of the room, with wooden floors and furniture, plush king bed, feathery pillows and thick white linen, created a sense of luxurious country hospitality.

That same feeling extends to the kitchen, where chef Jason Folk serves meals along the kitchen bench. You can help yourself to as much or as little as you like before settling at one of the long communal tables.

Dinner on the first night was a tender beef osso bucco that I could pull apart with my fork. On the last night, there a barbecue around the campfire ribs, lamb cutlets, roast duck, salmon, beef rissoles for burgers, salad, roast potatoes, coleslaw and fresh watermelon.

Breakfast each morning was a variation of sausages, crispy bacon, fried eggs, salmon and vegetable omelet, roast tomatoes, mushrooms, french toast with maple syrup, strawberries, fruit salad, yoghurt, cereal and toast.

Lunch consisted of grilled tuna, cold cuts of roast duck, turkey, ham and beef, hearty soups, fresh vegetables, leafy greens and, of course, dessert apple pie or creamed rice. The cookie jar is always full.

Don't be fooled by all the good country eating, there were plenty of vegetarian options and they work with food intolerances, too.

Folk's farm-to-fork approach is easily achieved, with an organic vegie patch metres from the kitchen.

Echo Valley is a place to recharge your batteries in whatever way works for you.

Frisbee with Norm and Nan's eight border collies is my pick, although a hammock the location of which I refused to disclose was a nice spot to listen to the wind and the tic-tic-tic of the sprinklers.

The BaanThai spa pavilion, designed by Thai architect Dr Pinyo Suwankiri, is beautiful. Inside the pavilion, imported teak furnishings, Thai silk and hand carvings create an authentic space, and the ginger tea is the first step towards calm.

My Thai massage was a combination of gentle stretching, pressure-point release and massage. Similar to Chinese meridians, the goal is to unblock your sen lines, releasing built-up toxins, restoring energy flow, increasing circulation and have you walking out feeling great.

The following morning, I traded a sleep-in for Thai yoga. I learnt how to massage and apply pressure to different parts of my face to stimulate lymphatic drainage and help improve circulation. Gentle poses followed by jovial Thai music and dancing had everyone in stitches at the end.

There's a third element that helps make the ranch unique its relationship with the indigenous First Nations people.

A close friendship with Rose, one of the few hereditary chiefs of the Shuswap people, means outdoor adventure organiser Darrel Nippard can take guests to the High Bar Indian reserve for a 4x4 tour of the Fraser Canyon and river.

On the tour, we explore the remnants of fortune-seeking Chinese gold miners. An old stone dam and wooden flume from the mid-1800s still stands. The arid desert is covered in sage bush and tiny cactus.

Nippard taught us about his favourite pastime panning for gold. Our group of seven managed to find about $1.50 worth of gold dust between us. Not the early retirement I was looking for or the giant nugget the kids were chasing, but fun just the same.

Further up the river, we tried our luck salmon fishing. A net on the end of a long pole produced results in seconds as the salmon made their annual migration upstream to lay eggs.

Nippard has a wealth of knowledge when it comes to edible foods. Cactus that tastes like watermelon and a tart purple berry half the size of a blueberry were ``good eating''.

Back at the ranch, indigenous artist Michael Blackstock had arrived to do his third tree carving next to one of the ranch's springs. Water is very much a living thing for First Nations people. Blackstock carves faces into trees near each spring as a way to protect this vital life source. I was lucky to witness the blessing ceremony for all three carvings the following day, where tobacco smoke and dry leaf circled the trunk of each tree.

There are 35 Tennessee Walking Horses for you to ride.

Horseback adventures range from lessons and beginner trails to day rides.

Wranglers are at the ready to help you get the most out of your ride.

Try as they might, they couldn't completely get me over my nervous indifference towards horses.

I am, however, a step closer to understanding how my 164cm frame could control such a beast granted they gave me one ready to retire.

The writer was a guest of the Echo Valley Ranch & Spa.

Go2

CARIBOO

Getting there

By air: Fly to Vancouver and arrange a charter flight to the ranch.

By road: Echo Valley is 435km from Vancouver, a five-hour drive.

By rail: Catch a train to Kamloops station, a two-hour drive from Echo Valley. Transfers can be arranged through the ranch.

Staying there

Echo Valley Ranch and Spa, see evranch.com

urn:contentItem:4P7G-YNN0-TXN5-R1YK-00000-00CATTLE FARMERS READY TO TORCH RAINFOREST1989-08-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWS AND FEATURESPg. 15CATTLE FARMERS READY TO TORCH RAINFORESTENVIRONMENTRICHARD HOUSE Source: The Washington Post

SAO PAULO, Friday: With the nation's forest wardens on strike and its scientists locked in a bitter debate about how much of the Amazon forest has really been destroyed, Brazil's cattle ranchers are preparing to take advantage of the coming dry season by setting alight huge areas of the rainforest.

Satellite images produced by the Government's National Space Research Institute showed that last year the burning of Amazonia produced an immense pall of smoke, shrouding Bolivia and even stretching down towards Antarctica. On the technician's monitor, images from a US satellite already show fresh pinpricks of light, each a 1.6 kilometre-wide forest fire.

Carbon emissions from the Amazon burnings are estimated to be half those of Japan's industry and urbanisation, and thus to contribute significantly to global warming. Since June, teams of woodcutters have been felling underbrush and branches that by now are almost dry enough to set ablaze massive tree trunks.

By the month's end, most of Amazonia's airports will be closed by the choking, dense pall of smoke that obscures the sun for weeks. Car crashes among smoke-blinded drivers have started again, and at least one wildlife park has been torched.

In April, President Jose Sarney issued an angry challenge to his international critics. He dismissed World Bank estimates of deforestation as exaggerated and promised to control this year's burning by deploying an army of forest wardens from the Government's new environmental institute.

But after suffering budget allocation delays, the institute has been paralysed by a month-long strike by 80 per cent of the wardens. Without co-operation from the armed forces, it is forced to charter commercial aircraft. "We just can't get people into the areas where deforestation is taking place," said its president, Mr Fernando Cesar Mesquita. But he added that 1989's deforestation would follow a declining trend seen last year.

"I think this year the burned area will be much smaller and the situation is now under control," Mr Mesquita said. The 1986 inflation-fighting economic plan produced a domestic boom and spiralling land prices that encouraged cash-rich farmers to carve out new cattle ranches, he said, but that money had been spent.

"The moment of truth came when the Government stopped its incentives program. Until then, all occupation of Amazonia had been encouraged by the administration. From now on, anyone wishing to make an investment must use his own money," said Mr Mesquita.

Ranch life - Cariboo

New adventures await at this East-meets-West resort in the beautiful mountains of British Columbia, writes Chanel Parratt

Fortunately, the Echo Valley Ranch & Spa is as green as a ranch can get. It is so well watered that the helicopters water-bombing the fire are using the ranch's well-stocked trout pond to refill their buckets. Smoked trout now.

Impeccable timing on my part I'd spent the previous morning fly-fishing before the choppers took their fill.

urn:contentItem:52ST-R5S1-F0JP-W2X4-00000-00Letters2011-05-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisFEATURESPg. 17Letters

Portable loos a waste of cash

THE idea of providing portable toilets to late-night revellers is ridiculous.

Do that and you may as well provide free cabs to avoid drink-driving.

There's no limit to the money that could be wasted to pander to selfish people who have little self-control or respect for their community.

When government is forced to step in and alter people's behaviour because the population shows little control, that's how ``nanny states'' develop.

If you can't control your drinking or your speeding, don't whinge when government takes control away from you or just fines you for being so foolish.

Brett Curtis

Queenscliff

* WRITE to The Manly Daily and you have a chance to win a three-month subscription to Australia's top-selling food magazine Delicious, packed with tempting and achievable recipes, plus foodie guides to Australia and overseas.

Headline angers terror survivor

I HAVE to lodge a complaint.

What's up with those headlines? ``Manly survivor gets the last laugh on bin Laden'' and ``You had it coming,'' MD May 4. Come on! That is completely irresponsible and not at all what I said to you.

You called me for a comment and I conveyed a message of tolerance. But, instead of reporting our conversation, you published my story under a banner of revenge.

I communicated forbearance and you chose to make me a target.

I know it's a journalist's job to make the news interesting.

Yet, by sensationalising my comments, you are just contributing to the overall problem; inflaming the fear and anger; and making the world less safe for us all. In your future writings, I urge you to contribute to the wellbeing of our community, not aggravate it.

Peter Grasse, Terror attack

survivor, Manly

Toddler's finger stuck in plughole I WOULD like to express a huge thank you to the Forestville-Frenchs Forest Fire and Rescue officers and Frenchs Forest policemen who attended my grandson's house on Saturday morning.

My two-year-old grandson, Ben, got his finger stuck in the bath plughole. He was very upset and distressed but the caring, compassionate way the officers responded to my grandson was very professional and much appreciated.

Great job fellas. Well done.

Dennis Gilmour

Forestville

Internet will bring down al-Qaeda

THEY can keep killing all the Osama bin Ladens there are but the only thing that will defeat extremist Islamism are its own peoples. Just like the communist wall came down over night, that's beginning to happen now in the Arabic countries through accurate information made available through the internet etc.

By all means keep up the surveillance and smart bombs or surgical raids but bring on the geeks.

John May

Dee Why

Economy in ruins or good shape?

BRONWYN Bishop claims the Labor Government is ``totally incompetent'' at managing the economy, despite the inconvenient truth of our economy being one of the best performing in the world.

So, is the economy in ruins because of Labor, or in fine shape because of the Howard legacy?

You can't have it both ways.

RE: hospitals if we could lure Andrew Wilkie to leave Tassie and be our local member instead of Bronwyn, we'd be laughing.

Tony Abbott offered him a billion dollars to fix Royal Hobart Hospital last election.

Kelvin Carlson

North Narrabeen

quickview

AFTER a few beers, bladder discomfort soon follows. Not all hotel patrons remember to relieve this before departing. As the source of this problem, the hotels of Manly could share responsibility with the local council of providing adequate outdoor facilities for urination after closing time. Portaloos or the equivalent could be placed near hotels, before sunset on busy weekends and removed early the next morning.

Mick Norton, Fairlight

* RE: Vineyard Childcare Centre, this is a great centre. The staff are fantastic with the kids. The food is also amazing. The kids are cared for so beautifully by the wonderful staff. Parents wouldn't keep sending their their children and then siblings there if it wasn't. My daughter and her friends love going to this centre.

Cassie Thomas, Mona Vale

* DON Moller's persistence in trying to have the Seaforth TAFE reopened after 11 years is truly remarkable. Both political parties are not in favour of reopening the Seaforth TAFE, because it is too small and the area is well served by the Brookvale TAFE. Also the surrounding streets cannot handle the additional traffic and parking demand that reopening that TAFE would create. Time to move on Don.

George Citer, Seaforth

* WHAT about opening the toilets in Manly Police Station as late night toilets? It's close to the taxi rank and should stop people shooting up.

Online comment from Eva

urn:contentItem:4592-1SR0-0197-849F-00000-00<published>1999-01-03T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:35Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FULLPAGE, FEATURES; Pg. 138</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Shock rock</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>Nui Te Koha</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">It is a plan sure to be greeted by Metallica fans in the same way they met the hard rockers' country-flavoured Load LP three years ago -mouths agog and tears of disappointment welling.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Metallica is set to announce a collaboration with conductor-composer Michael Kamen, with a view to doing live dates in the US.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Kamen, better known for his symphonic efforts than loud riffs, pre-empted the announcement by posting word of the teaming on his official website.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>Kamen and Metallica will play in San Francisco in the next few months.</p><p>ET belts up</p><p>ET -the extraterrestrial star who, for a decade, has been off-limits to advertising campaigns and endorsements -will do a TV commercial for seat belts.</p><p> Steven Spielberg's production company, Amblin Entertainment, says ET will star in a series of "Buckle Up, America" safety campaign commercials.</p><p> "We hope ET can become the (forest fire campaigner) Smokey the Bear of highway safety," an Amblin spokesman says.</p><p> Do-re-me-me-me-me</p><p>SINGER Julie Andrews -recovering from a throat operation -has told BBC radio: "I intend to be singing by early next year."  Andrews' courageous comment follows reports in which her husband, filmmaker Blake Edwards, was quoted as saying his wife would never sing again.</p><p>TV's ebony and ivory</p><p>WHEN it comes to TV viewing habits in the US, the difference is black and white.</p><p> Neilson media research says the top-rated sitcom Seinfeld was number one in white households last season. But in black homes, it rated 50th. This season, Friends was number one with whites, but 91st with African-Americans.</p><p> Conversely, Between Brothers and the Steve Harvey Show programs with predominantly black casts -are tops with black audiences, but don't even make the top 100 for white viewers.</p><p> Producer Norman Lear, the creator of hit black family show The Jeffersons, said: "Nobody elected for things to go this way. It's grown up around us and the networks feel they have to live with it."</p><p>The end for Penn</p><p>SEAN Penn -stung by across-the-board bad reviews for his new film Hurly Burly -says he is quitting acting.</p><p> "This is it," Penn told The New York Times last week. "I'm not going to act in movies again."  Penn -reportedly frustrated with bad films and with the films he loves attracting small audiences -says he will concentrate on directing.</p><p> "I'll fight the fight as a director," he said. "It's a better fight."  But Hollywood has reacted doubtfully to Penn's comments.</p><p> "He won't quit," said Jack Nicholson. "He's not going to give up acting," added Warren Beatty.</p><p> Odd couple</p><p> Former 90210 and now Charmed star, Shannen Doherty has jumped back on the Hollywood merry-go-round quicker than she revived her career. The reformed party-girl is now dating Counting Crows band member Adam Duritz who once dated Friends' Courtney Cox, a cast-mate of Doherty's most recent beau, Matthew Perry.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4P89-SGS0-TXN5-V214-00000-00Grenade injures 281998-10-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWSInternational NewsPg. 13Grenade injures 28

BEERSHEBA, Israel.- Twenty-eight people were injured yesterday in a grenade attack by a Palestinian in the main bus station in this southern Israeli town, Israeli radio said.

An eye-witness told Israeli army radio that a young Palestinian man threw two grenades into a crowd waiting for a bus.

The assailant was grabbed by members of the crowd, roughed up and then handed over to the police.

A car which may have been driven by an accomplice was seen leaving the scene of the attack and police were using a helicopter to try to track it down, the radio said.

Beersheba hospital officials said two of the injured were in a serious condition while the others suffered only slight injuries.

Israeli radio said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who is attending peace talks with Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat in the United States, had been informed of the attack by his military attache, General Shimon Shapira.

Capsize claims five

KUALA LUMPUR.- Five people are confirmed dead and another 10 are missing after a boat capsized in rough seas off Malaysia's south-western state of Malacca, police said yesterday.

Another 16 people swam to safety when the vessel, heading to the mainland from the Pulau Besar island resort, ran into big waves and overturned at midnight on Sunday, the official Bernama news agency said.

Marine police and fisheries department personnel, aided by local fishermen, are trying to locate the missing boat as there may be passengers trapped inside.

It was unclear whether the vessel belonged to the company operating the regular ferry service between Malacca and Pulau Besar or was owned by the resort.

`Miss Marple' dies

LONDON.- The showbusiness world is mourning actress Joan Hickson, who played Miss Marple in the BBC television series, after her death at the age of 92.

Ms Hickson died at the weekend in a hospital in Colchester, Essex, said her son Nicholas Butler.

She made her acting debut in 1927 and had a long stage career before taking on her most famous TV role as the shrewd detective, which ran from 1984 to 1992.

The Miss Marple series was sold to more than 30 countries, including China and the Soviet Union and made Ms Hickson an international star.

She was awarded an OBE in 1987.

She started her screen career in 1933 and was in more than 100 films.

Logging firms fired

JAKARTA.- A western Indonesian court has found two local logging firms guilty of causing environmental destruction and pollution by deliberately lighting fires, a newspaper report said yesterday.

The South Sumatran regional court found two out of 11 forest concession holders guilty of environmental damage and ordered them to immediately reforest their areas, the Kompas daily reported.

The two convicted firms are PT Musi Hutan Persada, belonging to Indonesian timber tycoon Prayogo Pangestu, and PT Inti Remaja Concern.

The court also ordered the two to create forest fire-fighting squads and to pay all court expenses.

The nine other firms were freed of all charges but the report did not elaborate on their reasons.

urn:contentItem:4J92-5V80-TX52-N349-00000-00Some bright spark2006-02-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisMAGAZINEPg. W02Some bright sparkWITH PROFESSOR CHRIS DANIELS

A TV commercial about fire prevention features a smoke-blackened firefighter saying ''Bushfires are a part of life of Australia''. But what does that mean exactly? Do we need bushfires? Can we never prevent them? Is Australia more prone to bushfires than elsewhere in the world? And, finally, is our bush adapted to fire and if so how?

Fire plays a complex role in Australian ecosystems. We live in a fire-prone environment because of our climate. Short, wet winters and a warm spring promote rapid growth. Long, hot, dry summers (which run to April) accompanied by north winds and low humidity dry off undergrowth and create the tinder and fuel for forest fires. Many other parts of the world do not have environmental and climatic conditions to make their areas so fire prone. Wet or short summers, cooling breezes or lack of flammable material make other regions safer.

But of course it takes a spark to start a fire. The primary natural fire starter is lightning. We don't have many summer storms, so lightning is less of a risk than in other locations. So on the face of it, we may be more fire prone but should have fewer fires than, say, the fir forests of the United States.

But the vast majority of fires here and throughout the world are started by people (either indirectly or directly). In Adelaide, the Kaurna people have been firing the plains for up to 40,000 years to clear undergrowth, to catch and kill animals, create paths and promote new growth, and to establish new plant species.

The flora of our environment is adapted to such events. Fire triggers many seeds to open. Either the heat cracks the shells, or chemicals in smoke start the seed growth. In other types of plants, burning to its roots stimulates underground runners to spread the plant. Many trees have buds beneath the bark which will sprout new branches when the limbs burn. So fire promotes biodiversity.

But we can have too much of a good thing. Obviously, very frequent fires will kill off all the plants and there will not be new seeds. Such areas become choked with a few weedy species whose seeds blow in from surrounding areas.

Alternatively, no fires is also not an option. Localities which have not suffered a fire for very extended periods also wind up with only a few species. Those short-lived plants, which need fire to germinate their seeds, will have long since died off and their seed is gone. Also the numbers of large trees which are usually controlled because the seedlings are regularly burned will increase in number and grow huge. So instead of a mixture of plants, we have a dense forest. Fire is tough on the animals in the area, and many species may be destroyed if fires are too large and too frequent. But burnt-out trees have hollows and the new shoots of the many new plants provide food. So, provided the area can be recolonised by animals from other areas, a fire can provide new resources.

The role of fire is one of the most complicated components of our environment. It is bad, but also good. Frequent small ''cold'' fires may reduce the chance of a big firestorm by removing fuel load and weeds, but may not be hot enough to stimulate natural germination of native species and will, of course, kill animals.

But not burning at all is also not the answer. Getting the balance right is a huge challenge for firefighters and biologists.

Professor Chris Daniels, University of Adelaide, is co-editor of Adelaide, Nature of a City (www.biocity.edu.au).

BURNING ISSUES

* Fire-stick farming by the Kaurna people established a patchwork of environments on the Adelaide plains.

* Early settlers, unused to bushfires, were amazed at the speed a fi re could travel.

* Aborigines kept away from thick stringybark forests in part because of fear of forest fires.

* The 1983 Ash Wednesday fires eradicated the brown bandicoot from the Kyeema Conservation Park south of Adelaide.

* The small size and number of leaves on grey box trees is a protection against fire: There simply is not much to burn.

urn:contentItem:4J3P-F6Y0-TX52-J2XG-00000-00FIRE BATTLE2006-01-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1FIRE BATTLEFlames destroy houses, threaten towns as thousands join fightBlazes threaten stateSarah Wotherspoon, Mary Bolling, Danny Buttler and Terry Brown

THOUSANDS of firefighters battled raging bushfires across the state yesterday as Victorians sweltered through temperatures above 40C.

Homes were destroyed in Anakie, near Geelong, and fires threatened the Gippsland towns of Erica and Yallourn, and North Tyrendarra near Portland.

The state's biggest blaze, in the Grampians, burned more than 100,000ha, threatened Halls Gap and surrounding towns and forced the evacuation of the Wallaura hospital.

A wind change about 6pm turned the blaze towards Ararat.

As Victoria recorded a top of 44C and powerful wind whipped across the state:

A TOTAL fire ban was declared in Victoria's northeastern district for today.

A HELICOPTER used to help fight the fires crashed at Latrobe Regional Airport.

A FIRE at the Yallourn power station cut two generators after flames hit the building, but the state's power supplies were not threatened.

THOUSANDS of homes were left without power as thunderstorms and increased demand hit power supplies.

THE HEAT played havoc with the Australian Open tennis, slashing attendance figures and forcing the cancellation of outdoor matches.

AMBULANCE officers treated more than 70 people for heat-related illness, including 10 taken to hospital with heat exhaustion after a fun run in Ocean Grove.

Continued Page 4

From Page 1

MELBOURNE recorded its second day in a row above 40C, the first time it has happened in January for six years.

SURF lifesavers rescued 66 people as an estimated 230,000 people flocked to beaches to cool off.

A ''significant number'' of houses were burned when fire swept through Anakie. Six aerial water bombers and about 200 firefighters battled the blaze, which had razed more than 2000ha by yesterday evening.

The fire was so intense flames could be seen 30km away in Geelong and ash reportedly landed on the beaches in Ocean Grove, Sorrento and Portsea.

A woman told Sky News last night she thought six and as many as 10 properties had been destroyed.

More than 150,000ha of public and private land burned across Victoria as a fierce northwesterly wind pushed firefighters to the limit.

Up to 2000 DSE and CFA firefighters and 250 fire trucks battled through the day and into the night.

Fires in Erica, near Moe, burned more than 4700ha in the Moondarra State Park and surrounding areas.

Erica residents were on high alert last night as a southerly wind change pushed the fire their way.

The Moondarra State Forest fire was spraying embers near the townships of Tyers and Yallourn North.

A red glow engulfed Yallourn North last night as residents braced for the worst with the fire about 4km away.

In Tyrendarra, fire swept through the town after it broke containment lines and jumped the Princes Highway.

About 1000ha was burned and several farm buildings lost.

Halls Gap was under threat last night as the fire front headed for the town having burnt more than 100,000 hectares.

Halls Gap resident Fred Warren, 42, said: ''We are preparing for the fire front to come along.''

''It is too late to get out of here now. There is none of that rubbish. We will stay and fight. That is all you can do,'' he said.

There were also unconfirmed reports of stock losses, and two out-buildings in Newbridge, 22km west of Bendigo, have been destroyed.

A fire-fighting helicopter tipped over yesterday as it took off at the Latrobe Regional Airport in Morwell, and the pilot received minor injuries.

A firefighter was injured at Steels Creek in the Yarra Valley.

As the fires raged, extreme heat caused the third straight day of Australian Open match cancellations. Games on outside courts at Melbourne Park were suspended at 10.23am -- before their 11am start -- under the extreme heat policy.

Ground pass sales were substantially down on Saturday, as was ticket and catering revenue, with just 22,679 people through the turnstiles.

As Melburnians did what they could to escape the heat, power crews worked to restore power to thousands of homes.

About 70,000 Powercor customers lost power on Friday night after wild weather took out sub-stations in the state's west.

urn:contentItem:49P2-MYD0-01S8-D056-00000-00<published>1995-12-15T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>RICHARDSON PLEADS FOR WINDIES TO UNITE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>ROBERT CRADDOCK</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">WEST Indies captain Richie Richardson has made an impassioned plea for Caribbean unity as a once mighty cricket dynasty threatens to self-destruct.Richardson is always a diplomat, but even his placid nature is being strained by the forest fire of controversy raging in the West Indies following Brian Lara's withdrawal from the tour of Australia.The West Indian hierarchy is chronically embarrassed by the leaking yesterday of tour reports from England revealing that Richardson described Lara as "egotistical" and feared Lara wanted his job as captain. A board meeting in the West Indies today will discuss Lara's future."I have not been reading the papers, but have heard Brian and the board have been making statements," Richardson said after a closed training session here yesterday."All these comments are being made and I don't think it is really good. ""Whatever our problems we have to remain quiet and get together," Richardson said. Richardson spelt out his belief that the game is bigger than individual players."Cricket will always be here. We have just got to play it hard, enjoy it and move on. The players move on but the game will always be here. "Richardson, who spent almost a year out of cricket with chronic fatigue problems, can empathise with Lara.Lara has been quoted as saying "cricket is ruining my life" which is an extraordinary statement about a game which has given him more than $3 million in career earnings in a land where many people cannot afford a meal."</p><p>It can be really tough," Richardson said. "People expect you to do well and you don't have much time to focus on what you have got to do.Sometimes you just want to be in your room, but everyone wants you to do this or do that. Everyone wants a piece of you."It gets on top of your after a while. It is unfortunate that Brian is going through that at the moment. It's life. But there are ways of dealing with it. Sometimes you just have to cut yourself off from people. "The West Indies today faces Sri Lanka at the Adelaide Oval and he is adamant his side can regain the winning habit."There will be times when things do not go so well but we are just having a lull at the moment," he said. "With hard work we will be back where we were 10 years ago. We have won before and we can win again.WEST INDIES: S Williams, S Campbell, P Simmons, C Hooper, R Richardson, S Chanderpaul, R Harper, C Browne, C Ambrose, C Walsh, I Bishop.SRI LANKA: R Mahanama, C Hathurusingha, A Gurusinghe, A de Silva, A Ranatunga, H Tillekeratne, R Kaluwitharana, K Dharmasena, C Vaas, P Wickramasinghe, M Muralidharan.END OF urn:contentItem:7V0X-08W1-2RR2-D1S4-00000-00Man on arson death charge2009-02-14T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:34ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 1Man on arson death chargeAlmost 2000 houses confirmed destroyedDewi Cooke and John Silvester, With Miki Perkins, David Rood, Jason Dowling

A WEEK after Australia's worst peacetime disaster, police have arrested a suspected arsonist and pinpointed "ground zero" - the spot where someone lit the blaze that killed around 100 people at Marysville.

The first breakthrough in the huge investigation was made public yesterday when a 39-year-old Latrobe Valley man was charged with intentionally lighting the Churchill bushfire that killed up to 21 people.

Angry onlookers beat on the door of a prison van outside the Morwell court as the accused, whose identity was suppressed by court order, was taken to Melbourne.

He has been charged with arson causing death and deliberately lighting a bushfire. Both counts relate to fires started at Churchill on last Saturday. The man was also charged with possessing child pornography.

Police sources revealed last night that he had been under surveillance for days and had been arrested quietly on Thursday before neighbours suspected he was a target.

"They want to hang him," a Gippsland policeman said.

Police and prison officials decided to move the man to Melbourne for his own safety. He was in protective custody last night and will appear in the Melbourne Magistrates Court on Monday.

"There are prisoners who have lost relatives in the fires," a Corrections Victoria source said.

Assistant Commissioner Dannye Moloney said: "We have a very emotive environment out there. People are pointing fingers. People are jumping to conclusions. Rumours and innuendoes are being spread."

In other developments:

Former Supreme Court judge Bernard Teague will head the royal commission on the fires. It is scheduled to deliver an interim report before the end of the year and a final report by July 2010.

Families of those who died in the fires will be given a $10,000 bereavement grant from the $100million so far raised by the bushfire appeal. The grant is the first allocation from the Victorian Bushfire Appeal Fund, which will be administered by a panel headed by former Victorian governor John Landy.

A group of forest fire experts accused Environment Minister Gavin Jennings of trying to deceive the public over fire-reduction burning.

Hundreds of tradesmen and planners have offered help to rebuild more than 1800 homes destroyed in the fires, leaving 7000 people homeless.

The first six of up to 20 Indonesian forensic police will arrive in Melbourne tomorrow to help identify bodies of fire victims, a task that could take six months.

Premier John Brumby declined to comment on yesterday's arrest, but said arson was an unspeakable and heinous crime.

The charge of arson causing death carries a maximum penalty of 25 years' jail, while intentionally lighting a bushfire has a penalty of up to 15 years.

It is understood police found child pornography images on computer files belonging to the suspected Gippsland arsonist on Thursday afternoon. He was arrested around 4pm and held overnight for his own safety while investigators searched his house.

He was not present at his remand hearing in the Morwell Magistrates Court yesterday and did not apply for bail.

His legal aid lawyer said the man was in a "fragile mental state".

Two of the accused man's supporters in court during the remand later told journalists to "back off". As police escorted a van carrying the accused out of the court complex, locals hurled abuse and struck the van.

Meanwhile, investigators confirmed that the fire that wiped out the town of Marysville and nearby Narbethong, killing up to 100 people, began around 2.30pm last Saturday near the abandoned Murrindindi sawmill, south of Yea.

Forensic examination indicates the fire was deliberately lit. Police appealed for anyone who visited a popular swimming and camping spot near the mill site in Wilhelmina Falls Road on Saturday to contact them urgently.

Detective Superintendent Paul Hollowood of the Phoenix taskforce said: "We believe the mill site is ground zero. ... This was not an attempt to burn down the mill but a deliberate attempt to create a bushfire on a massive scale."

After touring the razed towns of Marysville and Kinglake, Major-General John Cantwell, the man in charge of leading Victoria's bushfire recovery effort, said yesterday the destruction ranked "alongside some of the worst I've seen in combat."

General Cantwell has requested more troops be sent to the Kinglake area to reinforce basic services as people begin to return to the area.

Every family affected by the bushfires will be allocated a case manager to assist with issues such as insurance, rebuilding and managing estates.

PHOTO: An angry local yells abuse as an alleged arsonist is driven from the Morwell police station yesterday afternoon. PICTURE: PAT SCALA

urn:contentItem:3S8P-BVX0-0048-T391-00000-00<published>1998-03-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Western Australian Regional; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: THICK SMOKE HAZE FROM WILDFIRES BLANKETS CITY ON BORNEO</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">JAKARTA, Indonesia, March 21 AP/AFP - Smoke haze from wildfires blanketed East Kalimantan province on Borneo island today, attacking the health of residents and forcing drivers to switch their headlights on in the dim daylight.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The official Antara news agency said health officials in the provincial capital Samarinda, about 1,200km north-east of Jakarta, advised people to stay indoors or to wear masks if they go outside.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> It said doctors had treated thousands for upper lung infections since fires started in forests near the city in January.</p><p>"It irritates our eyes and we can't breathe," said one resident, identified by the single name of Ina.</p><p> "My family stays at home. Now, everybody is coughing. That's why I can't go to the office and the kids stay at home too," said Ina.</p><p> Many offices were shut and teachers complied with an Education Department order to close down schools.</p><p> The Health Department said it had distributed 20,000 masks.</p><p> On the streets, traffic slowed down as visibility was cut to only a few metres. Many cars switched on their headlights for safety.</p><p> Visibility in the major coastal oil city of Balikpapan was also reduced to metres, forcing disruption to some flights, airport officials said, adding that the runway remained open.</p><p> Pedestrians and motorcyclists donned masks as the smoke thickened in the city, some 125km south of Samarinda, while new fires erupted around the boomtown.</p><p> The fresh blazes were mostly to the west and south-west of Balikpapan, within 10km of the city, and were razing forests and bushland.</p><p> Large fires were also raging in the Bukit Suharto forest area, about 40km to the north, with flames licking at the main highway linking Balikpapan and Samarinda.</p><p> Yesterday, Nurdiansyah, an official in the governor's office in drought-affected East Kalimantan province, said more than 127,000ha had been blackened since fires started there in January.</p><p> At least 400 fires are burning in six districts, including two forest conservation parks.</p><p> He said cloud-seeding efforts have failed so far to produce significant rain to ease drought and wildfires.</p><p> Meteorologists have blamed the weather phenomenon El Nino for keeping seasonal heavy monsoon rains from falling.</p><p> Last year wildfires across Indonesia produced a thick smoke haze that threatened the health of millions over much of South-East Asia.</p><p> The new fires have raised fears that the haze might return over a wide area, perhaps even worse this year.</p><p> Officials have blamed forestry and plantation companies as well as farmers for starting fires to clear land cheaply.</p><p> Fires have also been reported on Sumatra island.</p><p> Dozens of fires had been deliberately lit by farmers and plantation and timber firms, sending sparks and hot ash across the area's rugged jungles and forest canopies to start fresh blazes elsewhere, they added.</p><p> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting even worse," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management  Project in Samarinda.<br/></p><p> "When anyone starts a fire now, it is almost impossible to control."</p><p>AP was</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:459G-YP50-015G-T18N-00000-00<published>2002-03-09T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:54:34Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WEEKEND; Pg. W04</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Junger the restless</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">The world isn't big enough for renowned war correspondent and author Sebastian Junger. Shaunagh O'Connor discovers the secrets of a life less ordinary</p><p nitf:lede="true"> SEBASTIAN Junger would still be sleeping on the floor had his girlfriend not insisted he get a bed like a normal person.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> But comfortable bedding is not a priority for the foreign correspondent who likes things rough, dirty and dangerous in the world's trouble spots.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> And the author of The Perfect Storm isn't into shopping expeditions.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "I think a lot of men are like that. I'm just not that interested in my surroundings, materially speaking," he says.</p><p>The bestselling American writer, whose The Perfect Storm became a movie starring George Clooney, doesn't need possessions to be a happy man.</p><p> On a tour of Australia to promote his latest book, Fire -- a collection of previously published pieces of journalism -- Junger seems to have the world at his feet.</p><p> He's "doing a job that I'm absolutely in love with" and goes so far as to say he's at the peak of his life.</p><p> All the doubts about his worth and ability that he says so haunted him during his 20s have fled.</p><p> "That's probably the greatest blessing -- that I don't live with self-doubt."</p><p> Adding to such blessings are the Storm movie deal, the money that goes with being a key figure in the publishing industry, a movie-star physique and outrageously good looks.</p><p> Junger, who works for Vanity Fair and has written for Harper's and National Geographic Adventure magazines, has carved himself a profitable niche as the man who reveals the amazing stories no one else has considered writing.</p><p> The Perfect Storm was a factual account of the freak killer seas that sank the fishing boat Andrea Gail off the coast of Gloucester in the US.</p><p> Fire reproduces Junger's investigative magazine pieces, filed after trips to war-ravaged and terror-filled Kashmir, Kosovo and Sierra Leone, and into the heart of an enormous US bushfire.</p><p> He won't say too much about his next project, but it will continue the work he does to bring enlightenment to his readers, this time with a US-based event.</p><p> He wants to keep writing, become a father one day, make some television documentaries.</p><p> "I feel like I'm running out of life -- like everyone is, but I want to do it all."</p><p> Junger is one of those writers who always wanted to be published but never quite got around to it.</p><p> "I've just turned 40, and when you turn 40 you think about your life. I couldn't believe it had been 10 years since my writing got going, and, looking back, how lost and confused I was."</p><p> At that time, 10 years ago, Junger was working as a tree climber, a well-paid but life-threatening job lopping branches off enormous trunks.</p><p> He had a well-documented accident involving a chain saw, a tall tree and a deep gash to his leg.</p><p> "It didn't hurt at all," he says now. "It hurt later when they stitched it.</p><p> "If you're badly hurt like that you go into shock almost immediately. I pulled it open to see if my achilles was intact.</p><p> "It was completely undisturbing to do that. I couldn't pull someone else's leg open, but once you're injured you have a clinical detachment."</p><p> The incident gave him the idea to write a book about dangerous jobs. That never eventuated, but submitting pieces on the topic to magazines meant editors got to know him "as the dangerous-jobs guy".</p><p> He took himself to the forest fire that gives Fire its title and also to Bosnia on a self-appointed work assignment, teaching himself journalism along the way.</p><p> Next came a book contract to write Storm and a characteristically anti-establishment move on Junger's part to reject the life of bestselling author to pursue foreign correspondence.</p><p> "In America, if you write a bestseller the next thing you do is sign a book contract to write your next book. No one departs from that,' he says.</p><p> "It's stupid to, because that's when you're worth the most amount of money."</p><p> Junger, the once solitary, focused child from a happy, nuclear Boston family, was his school's star long-distance runner.</p><p> He studied cultural anthropology at college purely for interest's sake, and has his physicist father to thank for his writing style: explanations of what a war zone looks like, how a forest fire grows, what an Albanian's body looks like two months after it is shot by Serbs.</p><p> "He gave me this curiosity about how human society works, about history, about how the natural world works," he says.</p><p> "He would explain things to me, like why the moon has phases and how eclipses work. He couldn't walk down the street without explaining how something worked. It drove my sister crazy, but I loved it."</p><p> Junger sports just the right amount of jet-lag stubble, hiking boots and jeans. On the cord around his neck is a boat hook given to him by his best friend, who has the matching one.</p><p> The two small, heavy pieces of metal are designed to interlock without ever wrenching apart, Junger explains.</p><p> After a book tour through Germany, Junger will return home to his apartment in New York and a hug from girlfriend and fellow journalist Victoria Bruce, author of No Apparent Danger, a publication about a tragic volcanic eruption.</p><p> The pair have been a couple for a year, but Bruce lives in Maryland, more than three hours away by car. So where is the relationship going?</p><p> "I don't know. I don't want to leave New York and she doesn't want to leave Maryland, so you can draw your own conclusions," Junger says, laughing at the personal question.</p><p>J UNGER got to know the politics of Afghanistan before September 11 on one of his assignments and has his own take on the terrorism emanating from that country today.</p><p> "It doesn't take that much organisation to do some car bombs in the US, and they're not doing it. The best they have come up with thus far after September 11 is the shoe bomber, and that guy didn't have his s . . . together, " he says.</p><p> "That's the al-Qaeda operative they sent to hurt the US in retaliation for the operation in Afghanistan? That's what they came up with? Then they have some work to do."</p><p> Junger's comfortable body language shifts to an embarrassed squirm when asked what he makes of his sex-symbol status, earned through a combination of brain and brawn.</p><p> It's flattering, he says, but it's also "a little excruciating".</p><p> "But if you don't block it out you'll find yourself a 45-year-old man going downtown to have a facial," he says.</p><p> "That's where it leads to. You end up having to play that game. You don't want to turn into that guy."</p><p>FIRE</p><p>by Sebastian Junger, Fourth Estate,</p><p>rrp. $27.95</p><p> WHERE filmmakers once looked to books for inspiration, they're now increasingly turning to the novella-sized articles found between the pages of the likes of Vanity Fair and Esquire magazines.</p><p> Sebastian Junger saw his Vanity Fair story of a monster storm become a book, and then a movie, The Perfect Storm.</p><p> Proof of Life started as a Vanity Fair article about kidnap negotiators.</p><p> Another Russell Crowe vehicle to have its germination in the pages of Vanity Fair  was The Insider. The story of a tobacco industry whistle-blower and the aftermath of his 60 Minutes appearance became the film.</p><p> An article in New York Post about the lead singer of a Judas Priest tribute band hand-picked to replace the band's real-life lead singer inspired the Mark Wahlberg film Rock Star. But things quickly turned sour with filmmakers removing all reference to Judas Priest when they asked for script approval.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4P8B-H2Y0-TXN5-R0RF-00000-00A Cole climate2000-04-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:54:35ZLexisNexisGOOD WEEKENDPg. 78A Cole climateView from the couchGlyn Davis

At the height of their brieffame, Lloyd Cole and the Commotions toured Australia. For a band formed by philosophy students at the University of Glasgow and known for their arch literary references and homage to musical heroes, the audiences of screaming girls seemed incongruous. Inexperienced, flustered and riding on the unexpected success of their first album, Rattlesnakes (1984), the Commotions stumbled through various capital cities before hightailing it back to the UK.

They did not return.

Despite a shifting line-up, the Commotions managed two more records - Easy Pieces in 1985 and Mainstream in 1988. The constant borrowings continued; Mainstream opens with the famous first chord from the Beatles's Hard Day's Night, before reprising the themes and melodies of earlier outings. The "pretentious pop" label that clung to the band probably didn't help them sustain mainstream success.

By 1990, Lloyd Cole had moved to New York and become a solo artist. As a survivor of the Scottish music scene, he brought a love of whisky/beer "boilermakers" to his new city. "Within my limited circle," he said later, "my first year in New York is semi-legendary." But Cole did go on to make some impressive albums - the inevitable Lloyd Cole in 1990, Don't Get Weird on Me, Babe in 1991, Bad Vibes in 1993 and

the excellent but commercially unsuccessful Love Story in 1995.

By now, sales had dwindled, Cole was no longer a marketable commodity, and the record contract ended. He remained known principally for that first magic album, Rattlesnakes, recently named by New Musical Express as one of the Top 50 albums of the '80s. That debut included sublime moments such as Perfect Skin, the title track, and Forest Fire. Cole could craft a lovely simile ("her heart is like crazy pavement, upside down and back to front") and memorable tunes.

His voice could carry the ennui of being mid-twenties, heartbroken at midnight, but ready to pull on the black poloneck and hit the streets again.

The shy but amiable English-born Cole found New York disappointing. Work was hard to find, and promised new projects died without issue. A series of acoustic club dates to promote the solo albums won critical success but did not lift sales. Cole eventually joined a new band, the Negatives, and an album is expected in the next few months.

Late last year, he quit New York for a quiet life in western Massachusetts with his wife and two small children. He joked about teaching creative writing - a perhaps necessary new career, given meagre returns from a decade in the Big Apple.

Lloyd Cole was a fleeting star, remembered only in discounted "best of" collections or as a contributor to the soundtrack of There's Something About Mary.

At 38, he has described himself to Time Out as "kind of old and on the scrap heap". Yet he has produced an impressive body of songs, showing that wit and intelligence can count for something in pop music. His solo albums reveal a growing depth and maturity, a journey from meaningless stardom to something more engaging.

And all done with self-deprecating humour. "Lay your head upon my shoulder/ let it rest there for a while," he sings on his last record. "I guess that I'm still good for something/ once in a while."
